column1: <div>

About the Artist/Teacher Institute (aTi)

aTi is a transformative professional learning experience and artistic retreat unlike any other where teachers participate in hands-on workshops in the visual, performing, literary and digital arts taught by master teaching artists. It's no wonder that more than half of aTi participants have attended the program more than once. Many participants say that aTi has changed their careers by impacting the way they teach and how students learn. Others emerge deeply connected or reconnected to the creative process.  The majority experience both. We welcome you to explore aTi’s impact both in and out of the classroom by browsing participant scholarship reports, lesson plans, workshop projects and testimonials.

column1: What We Need:

We need to raise $3,750 to provide NJ teachers with over 250 hours of workshops in art and technology. We are asking our donors to bring in $4,150 before fees on Indiegogo. With $3,750 in our scholarship fund, we can send more than a dozen teachers to aTi to gain skills in art and technology that enhance their professional practice and student learning.

column2: >If we do not reach our goal through the Impact: aTi Campaign, we will be grateful for whatever donations we've received so far. Something is better than nothing and our teachers will be thankful for your generous support whether or not we get the full amount. If we raise more than our goal, any additional monies will still go straight to the scholarship fund.

Participants at the Artist/Teacher Institute (aTi) are instructed by renowned Master Teaching Artists with adult learning and PreK-12 classroom experience. They are practicing dancers, musicians, authors, and artists who perform, publish, and exhibit their work internationally. Their commitment to arts education, teacher professional development and student-centered learning in and through the arts is world class.

We need your support to transform teachers and students in and through the arts!

Donate what you can to our Impact aTi Campaign to help fund scholarships for teachers to attend the Summer 2015 Artist/Teacher Institute and tell your friends to do the same. Any amount helps. Whoever refers the most donors wins a prize!

Visit our page at www.njati.org to find out more information about aTi, workshops, instructors, dates, scholarship reports, lesson plans, and teacher projects. We also have videos of our workshops on YouTube.
Thank a teacher for their work in the classroom and then share aTi scholarship opportunities with them. They will thank you for it.
Share our campaign on social media with these hashtags:
#njati
#artsmatter

aTi is a co-sponsored program of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts/Department of State, a partner agency of the National Endowment for the Arts and Arts Horizons. Additional funding has been provided by The Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation. For over 36 years, Arts Horizons has impacted the lives of more than 9 million children and adults through the power of the arts. We are committed to making the performing, visual, literary and media arts and artistic expression equitable and accessible to diverse people of all ages and abilities. We believe that the arts are fundamental to a child's education, stimulating learning, enriching the teaching process and providing lifelong learning. Our exceptional programs are customized to meet the unique needs and goals of your population and site. We provide:
Engaging residency programs conducted by professional teaching artists
Interactive live performances
Participatory arts workshops for seniors that promote well-being
Adaptive programs for populations with special needs and children in hospitals
Professional development for teachers and staff that builds skills in and through the arts

About the Artist/Teacher Institute (aTi)aTi is a transformative professional learning experience and artistic retreat unlike any other where teachers participate in hands-on workshops in the visual, performing, literary and digital arts taught by master teaching artists. It's no wonder that more than half of aTi participants have attended the program more than once. Many participants say that aTi has changed their careers by impacting the way they teach and how students learn. Others emerge deeply connected or reconnected to the creative process.  The majority experience both. We welcome you to explore aTi’s impact both in and out of the classroom by browsing participant scholarship reports, lesson plans, workshop projects and testimonials.
Read More About Our Campaign:
WWW.NJATI.ORG
About Impact: aTi

Scholarships for full-time NJ teachers to attend aTi subsidize up to 90% of the program cost. Teachers who apply for and receive a scholarship select from a variety of arts workshops that aTi offers.  Scholarship recipients complete all the requirements stipulated in the application including submitting a creative scholarship report that captures that aTi experience.Reports are available here.
Topics include but are not limited to: Creative Movement, Creative Writing, Digital Arts, Music, Theatre, Visual Arts.
What We Need:

We need to raise $3,750 to provide NJ teachers with over 250 hours of workshops in art and technology. We are asking our donors to bring in $4,150 before fees on Indiegogo. With $3,750 in our scholarship fund, we can send more than a dozen teachers to aTi to gain skills in art and technology that enhance their professional practice and student learning.

If we do not reach our goal through the Impact: aTi Campaign, we will be grateful for whatever donations we've received so far. Something is better than nothing and our teachers will be thankful for your generous support whether or not we get the full amount. If we raise more than our goal, any additional monies will still go straight to the scholarship fund.

Accueil et Intégration BSL organise un projet de mosaïque
interculturelle sous le thème «Entre deux cultures», qui vise à rassembler des jeunes Québécois adoptés ou
métissés avec des immigrants pour faire un projet de création artistique sous forme

des mosaïques pour exprimer leur identité culturelle.

L’aide précieuse que vous nous
apporterez permettra d’offrir 8 ateliers de mosaïque aux jeunes adoptés ou métissés
de la région Bas-Saint-Laurent, ainsi que la réalisation d’un film documentaire
avec une vidéaste professionnelle.
Pour la production de cette
vidéo nous avons besoin d’équipement professionnel et de une postproduction de
qualité. Nous avons d’ores et déjà le financement pour réaliser une partie du
projet, cependant il nous manque toujours 3500$ afin de subvenir aux coûts de matériaux, de
production, post-production, montage, mais également pour la promotion de notre
film et sa diffusion dans les salles de cinéma.
Les personnes qui nous aideront
à financer ce projet auront toutes une place réservée pour la première
diffusion du film.
Nous avons ramassé $155 dans la première partie de la campagne pour ce projet. Pour prolonger la campagne de financement jusqu'à avril 2015, voici la deuxième partie! L'intégralité de la somme
récoltée sera investie dans le projet ""Entre deux cultures"".
Tout don est le bienvenu, il
n’y a pas de petite contribution, chaque pierre est importante pour nous aider
à bâtir notre projet.
Même si vous ne pouvez pas nous
aider, s’il vous plait, n’hésitez pas à en parler autour de vous, à passer le
mot et à utiliser les outils de partage de Indiegogo !
Un grand merci à tous !

About the Project:

I am thrilled to announce my first curatorial project, There and Here, which will run from March 26 to May 14, 2016 at Hamilton Artists Inc.'s James Gallery. Featuring work by emerging artists Nedda Baba, Diana Hosseini, and Nikkie To, There and Here looks at how young female artists of colour are dealing with themes relating to representation, identity, and immigrant experience in their studio practices.The artists and myself are excited to be mounting this unique exhibition at Hamilton's oldest artist-run centre. 

We would like to use this opportunity to publish a catalogue to accompany the exhibition, which would provide a theoretical framework for viewers through exhibition texts and image documentation. Our $620 funding goal will cover the printing costs of the catalogue and a small honorarium for an invited writer to write an essay for the publication. If we reach our goal, we'll be able to publish 150 copies of a full-colour catalogue, which will be made available to visitors throughout the exhibition free of charge. 

Thank you in advance for your support! Please join us for the opening reception of There and Here on Saturday, March 26 from 2-4pm. 

About the artists:

Nedda Baba, born in
Hamilton, Ontario in 1993, is currently pursuing a Bachelor of Fine Arts in
Visual Art at York University. Inspired by the tensions between subject and
authority, her work is reflective of personal narratives and how they subvert
the perceived objectivities of dominant discourses in education, religion, war,
and the media. Her practice vacillates between staged studio pieces, found

materials, and interactive installations. See Nedda's website HERE.

Diana
Hosseini is a Toronto-based visual artist who makes kinetic sculptures and
installations. She holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Medical Anthropology and Studio
Art from the University of Toronto as well as a Master’s of Fine Arts Degree
from the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design. Her work has been exhibited in

solo and group exhibitions in Toronto, Montreal and Halifax. See Diana's website HERE.

Nikkie To is a Chinese-born Canadian painter and
multidisciplinary artist. She received
her Honours Bachelor of Arts in Studio Art from McMaster University in 2014,
participated in Red Gate Residency, Beijing in 2015, has run a successful
Indiegogo Artist-in-Residence Crowdfunding Campaign, and has received the
Capacity Building Initiative: Travel Grant from Canada Council for the Arts.
Her work has been exhibited in Hamilton, Toronto, and Beijing, as well as
having been published in Incite Magazine, ON
Publication), ON
column2:
and The Artist Catalog, NY. See Nikkie's website HERE.

Abedar Kamgari is an emerging artist and the curator of There and Here. Her studio practice focuses on an

column1: exploration of personal identity by means of an investigation of immigrant
experience. The perception and representation of women of colour within
Canadian society are ongoing areas of research fuelling her practice. Abedar currently
resides in Hamilton while pursuing a BFA in Studio Art at McMaster University. Her work has been exhibited in Hamilton, Toronto, and in the United States,

and is owned in private collections in both countries. See Abedar's website HERE.

help us produce the world’s largest cyanotype, which will be created by having

column2: Science course at Central Saint Martins School of

column1: Art and Design in London, and soon discovered a mutual affection for
alternative photographic processes. As artists and photographers, our practises
both explore humanity’s relationship with the Universe through imagery that considers the source of light, both solar and interstellar in origin, in the production
of our work. During the Story of Light Festival, we hope to highlight
the use of the sun’s energy, and our material
connection to the broader Universe as a source for creativity and inspiration.
The focus of Jaden’s hybrid art-science practice is an investigation of the
material that defines our identity as human beings and the connection of our
corporeal matter to the broader Universe. Melanie researches the parallel
histories of photography and astronomy since the 19th century and how both have
mutually, symbiotically contributed to our understanding of the Universe.
proposed project is to provide a deeper understanding of the way light energy
(electromagnetic radiation) can induce a chemical reaction within
photosensitive emulsions to produce works of manmade creativity and
imagination.
Hopefully, we will inspire
others to continue to explore the concepts and techniques we present, building
their own body of ‘photopoietic’ art.
What
motivates us to be a part of The Story of Light?
highlights the importance of light in our understanding of the universe, in the
broadest sense. With the increasing availability of telescopes, microscopes and
other optical equipment, we can look closely at objects we may have not had
access to before. More ‘amateur’ scientists are emerging to see the universe in
high definition, and as artists and philosophers we consider the cultural
impact of these. We were motivated to get involved with The ‘Story of Light’ as
our own artwork, research and interests mirror the main themes behind the
festival. Both of our artistic practices involve the manipulation of light as
an art material, in and of itself, and the optical use of light to view the
universe in depth. We would like to become involved in ‘The Story of Light’ to
encourage the local community of Goa to explore the use of light and simple
chemical compounds to produce creative, expressive artwork. In an age that is
becoming increasingly digital and ostensibly more complex, we would like to
focus attendees’ attention upon the simple elegance of ‘photopoiesis’ --
creating visual poetry with light.

column1:
More of Melanie's work can be seen here: www.melaniek.co.uk

","Melanie
& Jaden have been selected to serve as artists-in-residence for The Story of Light Festival in Goa, India!
With your support we will create
a world-record setting cyanotype on one of the city’s beautiful beaches, as
well as a body of work, inspired by the Festival’s theme, for exhibition in
January 2015.
Children and adults alike will
help us produce the world’s largest cyanotype, which will be created by having
participants lie atop the print and then develop the print together in the
salty waters of one of Goa’s beautiful beaches. The resulting print will be

donated to a local arts charity or community centre.Your contribution will help us cover the cost of our flights (which are rather expensive around the Holidays), local transportation, visas, as well as extra materials to produce our work and test our large cyanotype.
Contribute
at any level and receive an invitation to our private exhibition in London next
January showcasing the work we produced during our period in residence!
We will
be in Goa from mid-December to mid-January, with the debut of our work and
the attempt to break the record for largest cyanotype occuring during the
Festival itself:
14-18 January 2015
Want to
know more about who we are and what we will be doing there?
We (Melanie and Jaden) met as
students on the MA Art & Science course at Central Saint Martins School of
Art and Design in London, and soon discovered a mutual affection for
alternative photographic processes. As artists and photographers, our practises
both explore humanity’s relationship with the Universe through imagery that considers the source of light, both solar and interstellar in origin, in the production
of our work. During the Story of Light Festival, we hope to highlight
the use of the sun’s energy, and our material
connection to the broader Universe as a source for creativity and inspiration.
The focus of Jaden’s hybrid art-science practice is an investigation of the
material that defines our identity as human beings and the connection of our
corporeal matter to the broader Universe. Melanie researches the parallel
histories of photography and astronomy since the 19th century and how both have
mutually, symbiotically contributed to our understanding of the Universe.
The overarching aim of our
proposed project is to provide a deeper understanding of the way light energy
(electromagnetic radiation) can induce a chemical reaction within
photosensitive emulsions to produce works of manmade creativity and
imagination.
Hopefully, we will inspire
others to continue to explore the concepts and techniques we present, building
their own body of ‘photopoietic’ art.
What
motivates us to be a part of The Story of Light?
The ‘Story of Light Festival’
highlights the importance of light in our understanding of the universe, in the
broadest sense. With the increasing availability of telescopes, microscopes and
other optical equipment, we can look closely at objects we may have not had
access to before. More ‘amateur’ scientists are emerging to see the universe in
high definition, and as artists and philosophers we consider the cultural
impact of these. We were motivated to get involved with The ‘Story of Light’ as
our own artwork, research and interests mirror the main themes behind the
festival. Both of our artistic practices involve the manipulation of light as
an art material, in and of itself, and the optical use of light to view the
universe in depth. We would like to become involved in ‘The Story of Light’ to
encourage the local community of Goa to explore the use of light and simple
chemical compounds to produce creative, expressive artwork. In an age that is
becoming increasingly digital and ostensibly more complex, we would like to
focus attendees’ attention upon the simple elegance of ‘photopoiesis’ --
creating visual poetry with light.
More of Jaden's work can be seen here: www.jadenhastings.com
More of Melanie's work can be seen here: www.melaniek.co.uk",2.0,0,"2 Campaigns

column6: >The Dormalou Project Story

column1: wife, native Houstonian and eternal dreamer. Over time my dreams evolve, but my dream of working
with child artists, giving back to the community, and owning my own galley has
never changed.  As a matter of fact, the more
active that I became in the Houston art scene, the more this dream became
something that couldn’t be contained.  Finally,
after several written proposals (to no one) and several ideas (that never satisfied
me), the idea of starting a mobile art gallery emerged and manifested itself.  Two months later I bought a  1996 Ford Econoline RV Cut-Away (shuttle bus), and suddenly the dream became reality.
As a mother and an artist, it is
very important to me that my children are exposed to the arts. Unfortunately, many
schools, communities and families lack the resources or desire to make this a
priority. Fortunately, my kids experience and are influenced by art on a daily
basis, but there are many children who do not have that opportunity.  Those children deserve a creative alternative
and I intend to be one of those alternatives. With much work and the help of
fellow artists, who are willing to volunteer their time and knowledge to
growing interest in the arts among local youth, I know that Dormalou Project

will be successful.

The Bus: 1996 Ford Econoline RV Cut-Away
Dormalou Project is, essentially, an art gallery-on-wheels with an
emphasis on growing future artists and creating community based art projects.
The birth of this project came out of a desire to 1) run an alternative art
space that is accessible to anybody, anywhere 2) have a space to showcase
serious artists with a commitment to making art, as well as, giving back to the
community and 3) instill the need and desire for creativity and art in the next
generation.
<span>Each
featured artist is encouraged to assist Dormalou Project in designing and/or
volunteering a community based event.
come from?
Dormalou is the combination of two names: Doris Marie and
Mattie Lou. Doris Marie was my cousin, sister, and best friend. Unfortunately,
she passed away when we were both sixteen years old. It was a very hard loss
and her memory influences much of my work.  Mattie Lou is the name of my late maternal
grandmother. I lost her in May of 2012. She was my #1 fan in everything I do and
one of my favorite people. Her loss was the hardest of all. It is with great
love and affection that I name this project after them. I only wish that they
could be here to share in its success.
Are you a nonprofit organization?
No.
Dormalou Project is a for-profit art gallery.
However, a portion of our profits go back into the community by way of
our free monthly arts and crafts tables, discounted pricing for schools and
non-profit organizations, several free workshops, charity fund-raising, and
annual scholarships.
What type of scholarships?
Dormalou Project will give two scholarships at the end of
each school year. One scholarship, The Doris Marie Hawkins Scholarship, will be
given to one graduating senior enrolling into a two year or four college
program for the visual or performing arts (including music). The second
scholarship, The Mattie Lou Henry Scholarship, will be given to one graduating
senior enrolling into a two year or four year college program for literary art.
Each student must be recommended by a teacher or school official.
What will you do with the money?
The
money that Dormalou Project raises will help to make-over the exterior of the
bus, including graphics and a professional paint job with the help of Galveston
artist Gabriel Prusmack, various cosmetic and mechanical repairs, electrical work
for display lighting, air conditioning, interior rehab and installation of
display panels, a wheelchair lift, art supplies for our free crafts tables, and

a community block party to celebrate, once the renovation is complete.

What happens if you don’t raise all the money?
If we don’t raise all the money, then we will continue to move
forward with all of our plans
column2: however, it may be a much longer process because

column1: we will not have the funds needed to finish sooner. We will still be successful
in that we have introduced Dormalou Project to many more people. But, we would
really like to ride through Houston’s Art Car Parade in 2015.
What kind of shows will Dormalou Project have?
Like many art galleries, we’ll have art shows that showcase an
individual or a group of artists. Our events will include artists of all ages
and career levels. Shows can include visual art, literature, music, and
performance.  We will also take our shows
to art markets and festivals, while always including in our schedule a free
arts and crafts table for the kids (and adults) that attend. Dormalou Project
will also be available for school visits, organization visits, private parties,
etc.
<h1><b>Other
Ways You Can Help
For those who can’t contribute money,
there are other ways you can help:
·
Help me get the word out by posting
a link to this campaign via your social media sites
·
Come party with us on Dec 13 during
our <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/events/598496196923468/?ref=3&amp
column2: ref_newsfeed_story_type=regular"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">Pop-Up Art Show and Party, featuring over 20 artists, at Independence Art

column1: Studios as we celebrate the launch of this campaign.
·
Sign up for the newsletter, like us
on Facebook, and follow us on Twitter. We would love to see you at our future
shows.
·
Donate new or used art supplies for

our free kids crafts and events.

Some Perks

For the New Year we've both learned to trust each other and take one step at a time on what some might say is a leap of faith. With both of us having a secure relationship with God, we'll both overcome these small obstacles. For the past year we've tried to conceive naturally, but it's been a little challenging on both ends. Some days are mentally and physically draining. So, just imagine how many Red Bulls I have to drink. Oh! and not to mention my lower back problems I’ve suddenly acquired. Nevertheless, it’s one thing to put all of our energy into fear, doubt, worries, giving up and throwing in the towel but then again that would result into troublesome thoughts. But neither one of these are an option, we’re both natural born fighters.

As a teen my fiancé has persevered through some difficult times. She experienced having a 7lb tumor on her left ovary which resulted in a left Oophorectomy at the tender age of 15. Several years later she suffered the gruesome pain and agony of an ectopic pregnancy which also resulted in the removal of her right fallopian tube. So, you see? We have a little mix &
column2:
match thing going on here as to why it makes it a little less than possible to concieve naturally. But with friends and family praying by her side she was able to overcome and pull through such a horrible situation not knowing the nightmare it would cause her almost 20 years later. I mean she's literally Super-Women, Iron-Women and one of the toughest UFC fighters all balled into one beautiful specimen of a lady.

When I first met my fiancé our time was shared with laughter and jokes all the time. Laughter always plays a centric part of our relationship. Whether we’re out on dinner dates, trips to the farmers market picking out weird looking vegetables like Asian egg plants, showing off our signing vocals during Karaoke night while mumbling the words to Marvin Gaye's ""let's get it on"" we never fail to amuse each other and those around us. Two weeks before I mustard up enough courage to get on one knee to ask my beautiful lady if she’d start and finish the rest of her life with me until the both of our last breath (luckily enough for me her reply was ""YES"") she recieved a phone call from her Doctor saying that she had abnormal findings and she needed to come in ASAP. Sadly it was cervical cancer, and that my dear friend is when our whole world turned gloomy. At that very moment it simply changed the perception for our families and the both of us. After that very moment it made us value and cherish every single moment that we're blessed to have on God’s green earth.

It's taken a couple of weeks, days and hours to grasp, the concept of the treatment she would have to endure, but I can tell you this, we've never stopped laughing, smiling and cracking Jokes with each other. When life hands you lemons sometime you gotta suck it up and make lemon pie or lemonade. Right? We’ll, we've spent countless hours researching and studying the success rate and cost of the IVF procedure. Thus far we’ve managed to save 1/3 of the cost of the procedure which will be $16,000. However, time is a ticking away and it seems like we're running out of options. Our testimony is not another sad story or cry for help in order to raise donation for the IVF process. This is simply a blessing that I can vent out to the social media world and maybe just maybe somebody out there can relate to our struggle, and rejoice with us. The past, present, and the future are a constant reminder that our situation will change for the better.

for my patients and to keep myself healthy. From personal experience I can tell
you that it is a versatile and resilient tool, serving both the practitioner
and the recipient.

column2:
>

","Hi!  I'm a thangka painter - which means I paint Buddhist and Hindu deities.  I also practice a Buddhist healing practice called Chod and that is what my campaign is about:  I want to create a large painting (45” by 56”) of the Chöd

column1: practice in a traditional style but for a Western audience. My goal is to
paint a beautiful, detailed, and awe-inspiring educational tool for
practitioners who are learning the
practice and visualizations.   My fundraising goals are to raise money for residency fees at the
Movement Center to allow me to work on the painting as much as possible and not have to work on other commissions.  Paintings like this traditionally can take
a year to complete.  I plan on
working on it for one to two years.
You can see more of my work at LauraSanti.com to see I have the
skill and perseverance to complete a painting like this.  And you'll
enjoy the art!
column2: -DYou can buy prints of my art here: LauraSantiSacredArtChöd is a Tibetan Buddhist healing ritual

column1: practice, between six and eight thousand years old - predating all known
religions. It is a complete spiritual practice for self-cultivation and
self-realization as well. When I was practicing acupuncture, I was advised to do Chöd
for my patients and to keep myself healthy. From personal experience I can tell
you that it is a versatile and resilient tool, serving both the practitioner
and the recipient.
Anyone in the health professions could
benefit from learning this practice and doing its short, silent form for their
patients as well as for their own health. Chöd is subtle and powerful. Simple to do, but effective.
Chöd is also something that people without the funds to attain a
formal healthcare education can learn.  The Movement
Center asks for only a small amount of money to initiate and  teach people
the practices, because we want to give these tools to anyone who sincerely
wants them.
Chod visualizations are at first complex and unusual, coming
from a different cultural mindset, and then later beautiful and powerful the
longer they are practiced.  I think as westerners it is easy to
get caught up in the unusual aspect and then not be able to wait for the
practice to take root and unfold.  I want to
help people past these first hurdles.
My Chöd teacher, Lama Tsering Wangdu Rinpoche (LamaWangdu.org),
completed the traditional training, which included practicing in 108 cremation
grounds in and around Tibet. He is a lineage holder of the Longchen Nyingthig,
Shije, and Chöd practice traditions. He has been recognized as a living
treasure by the people of Nepal, where he has lived since the Chinese
occupation of Tibet.  In 2000 the Dalai Lama directed him to establish a new
monastery there to teach others his practice. He is now the abbot of Pal Gyi
Langkor Jangsem Kunga Ling Monastery in Boudha, Nepal. He met my guru, Swami
Chetanananda (www.Chetanananda.org/home/about/bio/),
in 1996 and asked him to carry on the lineage. Chetanananda agreed.
Chetanananda and Lama Wangdu then taught Chöd to students at The Movement
Center, where I study. Rinpoche currently divides his time between Nepal and
Portland, where we teach Chöd and conduct it for the public on a regular basis.
This painting
would be part of the Movement Center’s outreach to the Portland community and
the world at large to inform and inspire people about this tool that can help
people improve the quality of their life.
My teachers have given me their blessing and encouragement in
this project. It is up to me to find a way.  I invite you
will join me in the process -  it will be fun to see the painting
unfold here and on my Facebook page, Laura Santi Sacred Art.  contact me if
you have any questions or wishes for different types of perks (gifts!) at Laura@LauraSanti.com
thanks for reading!
Laura",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Portland, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/a-large-awe-inspiring-thangka-painting-of-the-tibetan-healing-practice-chod/pica
0,"

column2: >Northern Spark—the annual, dusk until dawn arts festival that lights up Minneapolis on the second Saturday of June—is turning 5 in 2015!
column3:
>To celebrate our 5th year, we're challenging our fans and friends to help us fund five new artist commissions for Northern Spark 2015. 

The festival is presented by Northern Lights.mn, a Minneapolis-based non-profit arts organization whose mission is to transform our sense of what’s possible in public space by supporting artists in creating and presenting interactive, technology-focused, site-specific art. 

Since 2011, tens of thousands of pedestrians and glowing cyclists have gathered for one night each June to experience what happens when artists take over the city in unexpected ways. Think: giant projections on buildings, breath-taking performances under bridges, and surprising encounters with artists.

column2: >“There’s really nothing quite like it. Hundreds of creative thinkers connecting with a single goal of making this one night of art take place. This is what it means for a community to have a soul.”
column3:
> 

- Piotr Szyhalski, participating artist, NS 2011-14
column5: >This year we are raising funds to directly support emerging artists presenting at Northern Spark 2015. Every dollar raised helps them bring their vision to life. THE IMPACT
The Northern Spark festival offers hundreds of local and national artists a huge, public platform.

Artists benefit from a truly unique opportunity to stretch the boundaries of what's possible, launch or build their careers, and often create larger than life work on a massive stage. In turn, our audiences get to witness and participate in once-in-a-lifetime experiences.

Moreover, we partner with cultural institutions to keep their doors open and admission-free for special late-night programming. This allows people to take risks on new artforms and experiences.

Community events of this scale and magnitude don't happen often or easily.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The biggest challenge of an outdoor festival is inclement weather. After four festivals, we've learned a few lessons about organizing an all-night, outdoor festival. On the bright side, the Farmer's Almanac forecast for Minneapolis in mid-June 2015 is “hotter and drier than normal.” Still, we'll be making some format changes this year to better support individual artists, their projects, and the festival experience in the event of rain.
<div>
Your continued participation in and enthusiasm for this beloved event is one of the big reasons we keep doing it.
Simply put, we do Northern Spark for you—and we wouldn’t want to do it without you! Please donate what you can and help us spread the word.

“It was fun to be a part of a city alive with people and art late at night. “

“I was surprised and delighted to see so many people of all ages walking around and taking it all in, even at 3 am. The area was filled with art lovers and it felt safe wonderful to explore the city at night.”

“When it was 5:30 in the morning and my friends and I were taking the last free bus from the Soap Factory to the Walker, and we were all covered in paint and glitter, we burst out into """"I Don't Want to Wait"""" and even random people we didn't know joined in.”
“The best thing about NS was the community that was created by sharing the challenge of staying up all night. There was this feeling of ‘we are all in it together!’ “
“There was fantastic energy…you could tell people were loving strolling outside on such a beautiful night and craving artistic inspiration.”
“…it provoked thought, stirred the senses (sight &
column2: sound), and made me want to see more.”

column1: “I loved not knowing what was going to happen next.  It was a beautiful evening and we just headed out into the night, ready to be surprised.”

","Northern Spark—the annual, dusk until dawn arts festival that lights up Minneapolis on the second Saturday of June—is turning 5 in 2015!  To celebrate our 5th year, we're challenging our fans and friends to help us fund five new artist commissions for Northern Spark 2015. The festival is presented by Northern Lights.mn, a Minneapolis-based non-profit arts organization whose mission is to transform our sense of what’s possible in public space by supporting artists in creating and presenting interactive, technology-focused, site-specific art. Since 2011, tens of thousands of pedestrians and glowing cyclists have gathered for one night each June to experience what happens when artists take over the city in unexpected ways. Think: giant projections on buildings, breath-taking performances under bridges, and surprising encounters with artists.

“There’s really nothing quite like it. Hundreds of creative thinkers connecting with a single goal of making this one night of art take place. This is what it means for a community to have a soul.” - Piotr Szyhalski, participating artist, NS 2011-14This year we are raising funds to directly support emerging artists presenting at Northern Spark 2015. Every dollar raised helps them bring their vision to life. There's a big difference between what $1000 and $5000 can mean to a project's success, and ultimately how that translates to everyone's experience of their projects. That is why we have set our sights on $25,000 to support five emerging artist projects.

The open call selection process is a unique opportunity for any emerging artist to have a chance to show their work at the festival. The call for 2015 projects is currently open (details here). Artists and teams will be selected in January.

Raising these critical funds now will allow us to give projects and artists the attention they deserve in the months leading directly up to the June festival.   (Read: No more Spring crowd-sourced funding campaigns! )
If you've loved Northern Spark in the past, this is your chance to give back.   Donate now to be part of the next festival in a necessary and meaningful way.
Why is funding needed?
Our event is free to attend. Keeping it accessible is important to us.

Supporting artists in the creation and presentation of art in the public sphere is not free. In fact, it requires additional resources because the infrastructure for necessities like lighting and electricity simply isn't there.

The inaugural Northern Spark event was a pie-in-the-sky idea made possible largely through a major government grant that is no longer available to us. We now rely on several income sources, including the government, foundations, businesses, and a lot of individuals, like you!
Here's how your dollars directly support Open Call projects:
Artist fees
Technical support (i.e. engineers, producers, electricians, etc)
Site permits and security
Electricity, lighting, and audio support
Signs and materials
Clean up
Cherry pickers!
THE IMPACT
The Northern Spark festival offers hundreds of local and national artists a huge, public platform.

Artists benefit from a truly unique opportunity to stretch the boundaries of what's possible, launch or build their careers, and often create larger than life work on a massive stage. In turn, our audiences get to witness and participate in once-in-a-lifetime experiences.

Moreover, we partner with cultural institutions to keep their doors open and admission-free for special late-night programming. This allows people to take risks on new artforms and experiences.Community events of this scale and magnitude don't happen often or easily.
Your support makes all the difference. Help us continue to energize our creative community and vibrant city!
THE PERKS
Help us commission five new art projects, and pick up one of our great perks, like:
Limited Edition Commemorative Art Prints by NS Artists:                                   Piotr Szyhalski (2011), Robin Schwartzman (2012), Jenni Undis (2013),  &     Kate Casanova (2014)
An original experience - Project yourself onto the Gold Medal silos with Luke Savisky and 4 friends!

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The biggest challenge of an outdoor festival is inclement weather. After four festivals, we've learned a few lessons about organizing an all-night, outdoor festival. On the bright side, the Farmer's Almanac forecast for Minneapolis in mid-June 2015 is “hotter and drier than normal.” Still, we'll be making some format changes this year to better support individual artists, their projects, and the festival experience in the event of rain.
THANK YOU!
Your continued participation in and enthusiasm for this beloved event is one of the big reasons we keep doing it.
Simply put, we do Northern Spark for you—and we wouldn’t want to do it without you! Please donate what you can and help us spread the word.
Thank you for your support!
The 2015 team: Ady, Alyson, Kerri, Matthew, Sarah, Steve, Tyler, and Will.#nspk #Spark5
Northern Lights.mn is a 501(c)3 arts organization. All gifts are tax-deductible (minus the fair market value of any claimed perk).

Note: Offline giving is also accepted, 100% tax-deductible, and very much appreciated! Make checks payable to ""Northern Lights.MN"" and mail by Dec. 31st to: Northern Lights.mn • 2751 Hennepin Ave. Suite 231, Minneapolis, MN 55408

MORE ABOUT THE OPEN CALL The call for 2015 projects is open until Monday, January 12, 2015 at 9pm CST. For the 2015 festival, artists are being asked to propose ideas that explore the fundamentals of what makes Northern Spark unique—nighttime, light, duration, participation, innovative art, unique memories, and community. We are interested to see how artists propose to build on that tradition. Find out more details here.

WHAT OTHERS SAY ABOUT NORTHERN SPARK
“It was fun to be a part of a city alive with people and art late at night. “

“I was surprised and delighted to see so many people of all ages walking around and taking it all in, even at 3 am. The area was filled with art lovers and it felt safe wonderful to explore the city at night.”

“When it was 5:30 in the morning and my friends and I were taking the last free bus from the Soap Factory to the Walker, and we were all covered in paint and glitter, we burst out into """"I Don't Want to Wait"""" and even random people we didn't know joined in.”
“The best thing about NS was the community that was created by sharing the challenge of staying up all night. There was this feeling of ‘we are all in it together!’ “
“There was fantastic energy…you could tell people were loving strolling outside on such a beautiful night and craving artistic inspiration.”
“…it provoked thought, stirred the senses (sight & sound), and made me want to see more.”

Project Overview
I am an artist and 2014 BFA graduate of Westminster College who
creates large scale sculptures and installations from found plastic objects
such as bottle caps and shopping bags.  Recently I applied to the show
“Multiplicities: New Directions in Fiber” at the IMAGO Gallery in
Warren, Rhode Island.
My sculpture, Bolbitous Aqualescent was
accepted.  It is made from over 18,000 plastic bottle caps and
thousands of shopping bags.  My work requires the help of a community of
over 150 people (listed below) to collect the tens of thousands of
plastic objects for my art.  Their involvement is a crucial part of my
art making process as well as the conceptual framework of it.
I have created this Indiegogo project to once again call on the help of a community to help me ship Bolbitous Aqualescent
to the exhibition in Rhode Island.  I live over 500 miles from the
gallery and cannot afford the shipping costs all by myself to get the
sculpture to the exhibition.  That is where you come in! I was really
excited to find out my work was accepted, but was disappointed when I
took the 6 foot long box to UPS only to find out that it will cost $185
to ship it to RI and another $185 to ship is back after the show.  The remainder of the funds raised will be used for the material costs of: the signed photo print rewards
column4: and the shipping costs to get the rewards to you.

column1: Even if the project is not fully funded any money that is raised will still go towards the shipping cost and I will try to come up with the rest.  I really do not want to have to withdraw from this great exhibition.
Being
a recent college graduate with living expenses and now college debt to
repay, I cannot cover the shipping costs on my own.  Please help me get
my sculpture to Rhode Island.
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
<div>
Having my sculpture in this show will be a mile-marker on my journey
to reaching my dreams.  Being included in the exhibition gives me great
exposure to a whole new community of people who have not seen my work
and it will be a great addition to my resume for graduate school.
Thank you so much for your help!
Below
is my artist statement that gives you an overview of my art, my process
and my conceptual thinking behind the work.  Also, you will find the
list of names of those who have contributed to my work so far! Help me
fund this project and you will be added to the list! You can see all of
my work by checking out my website, stevetotin.com
Artist Statement
My work is an investigation of the energy that resides in mundane
plastic objects. Many of the objects we consume are made of plastic - a
material engineered to last thousands of years, yet it makes up a
majority of disposable products. Throughout the objects’ short
lifecycles, we use them once or twice before we toss them. During that
short period of time, our physical interactions with those objects
transfer energy to them, energy that is lost when the objects are thrown
away. Those objects become lost fragments of reality, minute traces of
human presence that are scattered across landfills and landscapes. Those
fragments create a broken sub-reality, a reality we willingly yet
unknowingly create. It is our creation of and interaction with those
objects that creates this sub-reality
column2: however, no one wants to claim

column1: this reality as theirs. We go as far as paying to ensure that these
fragments are taken to the dump so we are no longer connected to them.
My work reveals this sub reality through the aggregation of found
plastic objects. I rely on the help of over 150 people to collect the
objects I use.  Their efforts are essential to not only the creation of
my sculptures, but also the conceptual framework of it. My work brings
the discarded fragments of our lives together, allowing the sub-reality
they create to be observed and analyzed for its aesthetics, its energy
and its involvement in the world we live in.
Photos of Rewards
Photo of Trametes Sulphureus mini-installation for the art collector level reward.
They are made of found plastic shopping bags and thread and are attached to the wall with small pins.
Photo of a wooden Node sculpture for the Art Patron level reward.
Node No. 1 (of the dance)  Dimensions: 20"" x 13"" x 11"" (The Art Patron backer's piece will be a similar dimension, but a different shape)
The
sculpture you will receive will be made using the same technique and
style as this one, but will be one of a kind in form!  It will be made
to hang on the wall.

Hayden Mershimer, Hillary Leslie, Holly Reid, James Geramita, Jayne
Piscorik, Jenna Meighen, Jessica Olson, Joe Totin, John Larotonda, Jon
Rhoads, Joseph Bandi, Joseph Kerley, Josh Daisley, Joy Hancox, Julian
Martinez, Kaija Gäbrielle Mulvin, Kalaway Voss, Karen Carenbauer,
Katherine Francois, Kathy Blumer, Katie Robinson, Kayla Magusiak, Kelsey

Risks &

There are very minimal risks involved with this project.  I can have the photo prints signed and mailed within a month, the ""Trametes Sulphureus"" mini installations are already created and ready to ship and I will have plenty of time to make the wooden ""Node"" sculpture and have it shipped to you by December if you fund at the Art Patron Level.  If there is more than 1 Art Patron backer then it will take longer to make the wood sculptures but I will do my best to get them to you as soon as possible while updating you with progress photos via email.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

• Please help me to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Share with your friends and family on all the different social media sights that you use daily!
• You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for your help!

Risks & Challenges

There are very minimal risks involved with this project.  I can have the photo prints signed and mailed within a month, the ""Trametes Sulphureus"" mini installations are already created and ready to ship and I will have plenty of time to make the wooden ""Node"" sculpture and have it shipped to you by December if you fund at the Art Patron Level.  If there is more than 1 Art Patron backer then it will take longer to make the wood sculptures but I will do my best to get them to you as soon as possible while updating you with progress photos via email.
Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Please help me to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Share with your friends and family on all the different social media sights that you use daily!
You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you so much for your help!",7.0,0,"1 Campaign

Help Make My Trip to Canada A Success! 

I am currently looking for help to gather supplies for my artist in residency in Quebec. I am staying in Dragon Dance Artist Residency in Trois-Rivières Quebec for the month of July!

The money I raise will go towards supplies, to create a large body of work. I will will be producing numerous large monoprints. 

www.stacystreeter.com

About the Artist
column3:
/>

Stacy Streeter is an artist who creates work about a personal narrative that deals with loss and grief. She uses multiple media such as printmaking, video, and sculpture to convey her ideas. She currently teaches Photography at Flagler College in St. Augustine Florida.

Stacy went to the University of Central Florida (Orlando, Florida) were she earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in Studio Art in 2009. In May of 2012 she completed her Master of Fine Arts degree from the School of Art and Art History from the University of Florida (Gainesville, Florida).

www.stacystreeter.com


Where Your Money is Going- What I Need

The money I raise will go to supplies to create a large body of work. I will will be producing numerous large monoprints. I am also going to be experimenting with Akua Liquid Pigments to create detailed monoprints. 

I need supplies such as:

column1: • BFK paper
• other fine art papers
• paper tear bar
• Akua Non Toxic ink
• newsprint
• paper towels
• plates

The Impact

This Artist Residency will not be successful without your help. I need help gathering all the supplies that I need to have a productive summer. I am continuing my personal work that deals with loss and grief. I want to continue with my past work and experiment with new techniques and materials. 

Other Ways You Can Help
• Make some noise and tell a friend about my campaign
• Use the Indiegogo share tools!

What's in it for you?

First, I would be forever grateful. Second, there are a lot of cool prints that will be created during this residency that you could have your pick from. There are prints of all prices and sizes.  See the images below for reward examples!
The Rewards
Here are a few examples of what the rewards prints might look like...
column5: /> Hand Pulled Monoprint- Small
column9:
/>

""Multiplying Rabbits"" Framed Each (32"" x 24"")

Sponsor us for the MAK Games!

We are  big fans of the MAK Center for Art and Architecture at the Schindler House and we’re delighted to be able to combine that with our love of tennis and compete in the 2015 MAK Games tournament. The competition is a fund-raiser for the MAK Center—they need us, and we need you to help with our registration donation. 

We need a minimum of $500 to qualify for the draw. If you help us compete for the MAK Cup, you’ll be supporting the ONLY art institution in the world that presents contemporary art and architecture programming while stewarding three landmarks of modern architecture by R.M. Schindler. 

Not to mention, your donation will give us the chance to compete on the stunning infinity tennis court at the Sheats/Goldstein Residence, a classic by architect John Lautner.

Any amount is welcome—no donation is too small! You will be thanked on the program and on the website, and at $100 and above, you’ll receive a MAK Center Friendship which ushers you into one of the most dynamic and interdisciplinary cultural scenes around.

  • All contributions are tax-deductible to the extent of the law.

Please support us,

And tell your friends!

Joseph Stalin
(Ioseb Jughashvili) was one the biggest figures in 20th century world politics.
As a leader of Soviet Union, Stalin was involved in World War II and played the
decisive role in the victory of Allies.
Before his rise to
power, Stalin was based in Georgia the post Soviet Republic, where he was born
(Gori, 1878) and started his revolutionary activities. After being expelled
from Georgian Orthodox Tiflis Spiritual Seminary, he gradually became one of the biggest
revolutionary names in Caucasian region. Two most significant accomplishments
during his revolutionary youth are considered the 1907 Tiflis bank robbery,
(theft of 341,000 Rubles, roughly USD 3.4 millions adjusted for inflation) and
the establishment of an underground secret printing house. The latter supplied
Eurasian region with illegal revolutionary print materials including
socialistic proclamations, banned publications etc. The printing house played a
deciding role in successful accomplishment of 1917 Russian revolution.
The secret printing
house itself is located under a small residential house in Tbilisi, Georgia.
The only way leading to the printing press was laid through the well located in
the yard. The underground tunnel connects the well and the underground space.
At the moment the historic printing house (including the underground printing
press) is in extremely poor condition and needs immediate restoration.
The total amount
needed for printing house restoration is USD 80,000. The amount will be spent
on restoring the residential and underground printing spaces and turning it
into a unique museum representing socialistic revolutionary movement.
The funds will be
allocated for following tasks by same priority as mentioned below:
·
Pumping the
ground waters, the main threat for the underground museum
·
Cleaning the
well, reparation of the ladder to comply with safety regulations
·
Installation
of the underground ventilation system, lighting etc.
·
The
restoration of printing press, which is heavily rusted but still preserved
·
The
refurbishment of the residential house, where Stalin and his associates lived
·
Interior
decoration of the house and the basement
·
Reparation of
existing exhibits and the collection of new ones
We are a team of
enthusiasts interested in preserving cultural heritage of our city (Tbilisi).
We are actively involved in restoration of abandoned historical places, trying
to revive them. We hope that your contribution will allow us to save the unique
place and make it available to thousands of visitors.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h3><span style=""font-size: 1.17em
We are a French art duo, called Kolkoz, and we are doing an installation for a project in Mexico city. Our work focuses on creating simulations, in order to question reality.

The installation we're presenting in april in Mexico, UBIK, is a public art project, where a desert landscape made of cactus will be mounted on a trailer and pulled by a truck around the city for four days. UBIK will enables the spectators to see art outside the museum.

We wanted to reverse the journey's idea : instead of traveling in the landscape, the landscape is traveling around us, which will increase the photographic desire of the citizens. By using the cactus as a symbol of the country, and in relation with the foundation myth of Mexico, the installation moves the landscape towards the spectator in order to remind him that culture, history, and art can be present in his everyday life.

For now, we have the truck, and the trailer, the driver but we need you to finalize the production cost ! With the money we will buy everything to put together the installation, such as the cactus, pay for the construction of the piece and the assembly team.
Thanks for your support !
","UBIK

Project Summary

Over the past few months, I have had the privilege of collaborating with Bay Area-based choreographer Erika Tsimbrovsky, visual artist/sculptor/designer Vadim Puyandaev, and video/lighting designer Lucas Krech on a new and ambitious interactive performance-installation production.

Entitled Minotaur, this project is inspired by the Minotaur of Greek mythology, a half-bull, half-human creature with royal and godly origins, who is trapped within the labyrinth designed by Daedalus. In our project we present the Minotaur as a mutant of our contemporary world, with desires for love, pleasure, power, and flesh, that can never be satisfied. When Minotaur premieres, the audience will experience a labyrinth of feeling and sound and will enter a convoluted world of flesh and spirit.
An Audio-Visual-Kinetic Experience

Equal parts sculpture, multimedia installation, and dance performance, Minotaur will feature a modular architecture, adapting to multiple gallery, concert stage, and outdoor settings. Dancers will performatively inhabit and explore a transparent labyrinth, whose surfaces will be animated via live painting, light and video projection, and sonic vibrations.

This labyrinth will by no means be insular or exclusive: as video and sound continuously collected from the performance/exhibition space are processed and transmitted into the labyrinth structure, the visual and auditory sensations within the constructed space are radiated back onto the audience.  As such, boundaries between internal and external spaces will become porous, and the experience will be immersive and unpredictable for audience members and performers alike.  No two performances will be the same!

Minotaur will be premiered during the 2012-2013 season in San Francisco (venue to be determined). We hope to subsequently present it in a variety of venues in the San Francisco Bay Area, nationally, and internationally.
<h3><strong>What We Need &amp
<div>

Currently, we are in our first production phase, on a residency at the Paul Dresher Artist Residency Center in Oakland, CA. We have been operating thus far on a minimal budget, which has limited our capacity to construct the multimedia labyrinth.

In order to move forward with this project, we are reaching out to you to help us cover our material expenses. These include the cost video, audio, and lighting equipment, as well as the hard transparent plastic material to be used to build the labyrinth walls. Due to its specific physical, reflective, and resonant properties, this material will be indispensable for the production.
The total estimated cost of these materials is $20,000. However: if we meet (or exceed) our $10,000 funding goal, we will be well on our way.
Future anticipated expenses include venue rental, transportation, and artist and technical staff fees.

In return for your generous tax deductible contribution, you will receive an exciting and diverse array of rare, customized gifts--ranging from limited edition T-shirts and tote bags, to exclusive interviews and masterclasses, to original compositions by Alexander Sigman--not to mention free tickets to a Minotaur performance!
If you donate at the highest levels, you will be the proud recipient of an original oil on canvas painting, costume, or life-sized sculpture by Vadim Puyandaev!
N.B.: Proceeds go to Avy K Productions, Erika Tsimbrovsky and Vadim Puyandaev's non-profit fiscal affiliate of the Dancers Group. As such, all donations are tax deductible.
The Impact

Exploring timeless, mythological themes, and timely urban social and environmental issues through movement, visual media, music, and architecture, Minotaur promises to engage and inspire a wide audience. Given the work's universal relevance and  imminently adaptable format, Minotaur bears great potential to be featured on international festivals and exhibitions.

This project has also offered a rare opportunity for the four main artists involved to collaborate in a sustained, productive,  and meaningful way. It is hoped that this production will spark an enduring working relationship among the artists.
Erika Tsimbrovsky and Vadim Puyandaev have been captivating Bay Area and international audiences with their interdisciplinary ""audio-visual-kinetic"" works for the past two decades.
Here are excerpts from The Book, their 2011 performance-installation combining dance, live painting, music, video, and audience participation.

Alexander Sigman's award-winning instrumental, electroacoustic, installation, and intermedia compositions have been featured at major international festivals, venues, institutions, and galleries.  In the past few years, he has collaborated with filmmakers, video artists, choreographers, and product designers. His first portrait recording was released in March on
detritus II, for video and electronics.

Lucas Benjaminh Krech has designed over 300 operas, dances, plays, and performance pieces across the United States and Europe. Installation, lighting, and video art has been shown at Black Rock CIty, SOMArts, Studio Gracia, and others.
Please visit Lucas' website for more information.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
<div>

If you are not currently in a position to contribute financially, no worries--you can support our project simply by helping us get the word out. Please watch this space for updates, and ping your social media networks!
Please let us know if you have any questions.
Thanks in advance for your a-maze-ing support!
Sincerely,
Erika, Vadim, Alex, and Lucas

Our Story
<div>
<span><span style=""color: rgb(47, 47, 47)
column5: >We are bringing young people together to design and construct basketball backboards from salvaged materials. The creative expression empowers kids, the construction creates jobs, and the installation creates pride in the community. This is the beginning of change in Hale County.

column1: In June 2011, in Hale County, Alabama, six
designers found themselves face-to-face with tornado damage, poverty and
staggering unemployment. We spoke with many residents about living in the Rural South. What we
heard was a resounding call for “something to do.” Young people want
purpose, through jobs or recreation. We want to give them purpose,

through both.

The goal of COMMON Hoops is to engage youth (ages 12-17) by creating jobs, teaching new and transferable skills, and allowing them to enjoy basketball in a new way. By designing and building basketball backboards, young residents are empowered. They take away valuable skills and give back to their own communities. COMMON Hoops can be expanded to support similar communities across the country. So we plan to combine design with basketball.
How We're Doing It
<div>
<h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-size: 14px
column3: >These basketball hoops, hand-built in Hale County and crafted from found materials -  including road signs - allow kids to use their creativity to create beautiful backboards that bring DESIGN and BASKETBALL into their community. Kids in the community will take pride knowing they helped to design and build the hoops that will soon be hanging in neighborhoods like their own. Each backboard will find its home with kids in both public and private lands. When you support COMMON Hoops, you create jobs, foster mentorship and revitalize parks.

column1: This campaign is to help get the project going. Your money goes towards hosting events where kids will design and build hoops. Participants will be taught basic design principles, guided through the construction of their hoop, and offered the opportunity to mentor other students in future sessions.
Funding Goal
column6: >Our goal is to secure at least 30 pre-orders for these hoops. But there are lots of ways to help out by buying a t-shirt or a COMMON Hoop photo print. Please share our story with your friends using our the sharing buttons on this page. You can find us on <a href=""http://twitter.com/commonhoops"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: rgb(255, 0, 87)
column8: target="""" title="""">Twitter and
column10:
target="""" title="""">Facebook to follow our progress. 
Thank you for your support. (T-shirt colors above subjet to change)

column1:
Hoops and sweet gear will ship out Autumn 2011. 

Our Community Partner

HERO (Hale Empowerment and Revitalization Organization, Inc) works as a catalyst for community development in areas of the Alabama Black Belt to end rural poverty. As a non-profit housing resource center, HERO provides community resources, housing education and community development.

COMMON Hoops is a fiscally sponsored project of Hale Empowerment and Revitalization Organization, a 501(c)3 non profit organization. Donations should be made payable to Hale Empowerment and Revitalization and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Greensboro, Alabama is a special place in one of America’s poorest counties. Its a place where social ventures are bringing promise of a new creative economy. The population is around 2,700 people, many of who we had the great pleasure and honor to meet and even become friends with in Greensboro. You can learn more about Greensboro here.
COMMON is one part community
column3: and one part collaborative brand. A living network of creative people rapidly prototyping dozens or hundreds of progressive businesses designed to solve social problems. Connected to a brand that’s community designed, community owned, and community directed.

column1: About Us

We are six designers who are united by a passion for social change. We joined forces in Greensboro, AL, during the 2011 Project M Lab to make a difference with a community unlike any we’d ever known. Learn more about us here.
","Our Story

We are bringing young people together to design and construct basketball backboards from salvaged materials. The creative expression empowers kids, the construction creates jobs, and the installation creates pride in the community. This is the beginning of change in Hale County.
In June 2011, in Hale County, Alabama, six
designers found themselves face-to-face with tornado damage, poverty and
staggering unemployment. We spoke with many residents about living in the Rural South. What we
heard was a resounding call for “something to do.” Young people want
purpose, through jobs or recreation. We want to give them purpose,

through both. The goal of COMMON Hoops is to engage youth (ages 12-17) by creating jobs, teaching new and transferable skills, and allowing them to enjoy basketball in a new way. By designing and building basketball backboards, young residents are empowered. They take away valuable skills and give back to their own communities. COMMON Hoops can be expanded to support similar communities across the country. So we plan to combine design with basketball.
How We're Doing It

These basketball hoops, hand-built in Hale County and crafted from found materials -  including road signs - allow kids to use their creativity to create beautiful backboards that bring DESIGN and BASKETBALL into their community. Kids in the community will take pride knowing they helped to design and build the hoops that will soon be hanging in neighborhoods like their own. Each backboard will find its home with kids in both public and private lands. When you support COMMON Hoops, you create jobs, foster mentorship and revitalize parks.

This campaign is to help get the project going. Your money goes towards hosting events where kids will design and build hoops. Participants will be taught basic design principles, guided through the construction of their hoop, and offered the opportunity to mentor other students in future sessions.

Funding GoalOur goal is to secure at least 30 pre-orders for these hoops. But there are lots of ways to help out by buying a t-shirt or a COMMON Hoop photo print. Please share our story with your friends using our the sharing buttons on this page. You can find us on Twitter and Facebook to follow our progress. Thank you for your support. (T-shirt colors above subjet to change)
Hoops and sweet gear will ship out Autumn 2011. Our Community Partner

HERO (Hale Empowerment and Revitalization Organization, Inc) works as a catalyst for community development in areas of the Alabama Black Belt to end rural poverty. As a non-profit housing resource center, HERO provides community resources, housing education and community development.

COMMON Hoops is a fiscally sponsored project of Hale Empowerment and Revitalization Organization, a 501(c)3 non profit organization. Donations should be made payable to Hale Empowerment and Revitalization and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
Greensboro

Greensboro, Alabama is a special place in one of America’s poorest counties. Its a place where social ventures are bringing promise of a new creative economy. The population is around 2,700 people, many of who we had the great pleasure and honor to meet and even become friends with in Greensboro. You can learn more about Greensboro here.
About Common
COMMON is one part community
column3: and one part collaborative brand. A living network of creative people rapidly prototyping dozens or hundreds of progressive businesses designed to solve social problems. Connected to a brand that’s community designed, community owned, and community directed.

column1: About Us

We are six designers who are united by a passion for social change. We joined forces in Greensboro, AL, during the 2011 Project M Lab to make a difference with a community unlike any we’d ever known. Learn more about us here.",3.0,0,"1 Campaign

2 - q t p o c  m o n t r é a l  2 0 1 2 is dedicated to 2-Spirit indigenous queer and transfolks of colour, with gorgeous art, oral history, artist talks, community lectures, in different languages and from different continents.

It'll run from August 10th to August 19th at articule artist-run centre in Montréal. In my secret mission, this show is going to ignite the city's first ever 2-Spirit Queer and Trans People of Colour Pride Week. Aaaaaaah!

Ange Loft graduated from the Centre for Indigenous Theater and tours with the music and art performance act Yamantaka Sonic Titan. For 2 - q t p o c Ange will be unveiling the Cult of Kateri: Aboriginal Armour and Accessories.

Textaqueen shows art from National Portrait Galleries to tattoo parlours, and they'll be showing folks of colour in their own fictional post-apocalyptic movie posters. The image for this campaign is theirs.

Rising star Walter K Scott exhibits visceral and provocative screenprints, video and across the continent, and produces the cult zine Wendy, about the traps and vices that can ensnare an young contemporary art career.

Adee Roberson has been heralded as a leader of Black american political, musical and visual subculture through her art, magazines and band the New Bloods, and she'll be showing layered collages of family and politics.
Kesso Saulnier is a Guinean Quebecer francophone who stitches comic strips ten feet long, this time in interpretations of songs sung by Big Mama Thornton and Billy Holliday.
Leroi Newbold will show a machine stiched xeroxed mixed media graphic novel archive of his childhood, survival, thrival, blackness, ancestors and a castle full of cats.
There will be more, including graphic memoirs of a Canadian refugee detention centre.
We are raising $3000 to go towards work transportation, rights to exhibition, installation, workshop facilitation, translation, invitations, travel and accomodation, and more.
Contributions will earn you perks, like screen printed posters, screen printed tshirts, and even a thank you video!

We love you. x o x o

Plus Confidence in You Is an organisation designed to promote body confidence and having a positive body image. The whole team behind the project recognise that growing up when you look different from others is tough - especially when the media is telling you that your body doesn't look just how it should.

So... They have come up with an exciting concept - The Definition of Size Art Exhibition! The more we can surround ourselves with photos of bodies of all sizes and the more we can see strong, confident women  rocking their bodies and doing their thing, the easier life will come.

The Plus Size Art Exhibition is designed to showcase stunning artistic images of women sized everything between a dress size 20 and a dress size 30. The art exhibition has been a long time coming and as such a lot of work has had to go into it - and now thanks to this funding project you have the chance to be involved in something different!

The Exhibit Itself

‘Plus Confidence In You’ is working on creating an explosive, eye opening, breath taking art exhibition which will be held in London  (date to be confirmed). Late 2013 saw a mini exhibition unveil some of the first images of the exhibit and they have gone down a storm. Finally a chance to see ladies that are plus size (and all sizes on the scale) looking fabulous, glamorous and most importantly - happy and confident!

Support From The Media

The media is quickly catching on to the fact that things need to change. That is why we're happy to say that we have been sponsored by a number of large name companies including Evans, Yours Clothing, Simply Be and Lush Cosmetics. We also have a fantastic team of photographers, hair stylists, fashionistas, models, makeup artists, media bods and more! We're a massive happy family working hard to put on this exhibition with a different and now we want you to be involved too!

Where You Come In

The art we create is just that, ART. The reason we are working on such a ground breaking and controversial project is to support the plus size and body confidence movement. Society is changing, people are changing. Art and fashion should follow suit.

Every man woman and child deserves to have a voice. Now is your chance to say you were a part of history.

We have a number of funding packages which means that you can get involved as little or as much as you would like. Every single donation is SO gratefully received and you really will be helping to create something different.

For media requests and further information please feel free to get in touch.

Thank you for taking the time to check out my campaign. I’m Steven J Read, a
Minnesotan sculptor transplanted to Pennsylvania.  Currently I am working on my solo show, “Wooded Folk” opening March 2014.  Wooded Folk is an exploration of new ways of
seeing and interacting with the natural world.
Wooded Folk uses a variety of materials and means to show that we still
can have meaningful connections to nature in our tech world without having
to cast away the “new” and become luddites.  The objects that I create start their growth
in the small stories from my history and combine the worlds of tech and
traditional to show that both can have a new, holistic way of
interacting.  Some of the techniques that
I employ are 3D modeling software, 3D printers, laser cutters, hand tools,
traditional wood carving techniques, and carpentry.  The end goal of Wooded Folk is an entire gallery installed with these objects, creating a space for the viewer to
explore how they are connected and new ways to connect to the natural world.
What compels me?
I have been lucky enough to live
and grow up with a direct interaction with nature.  Being raised on a farm and spending time in
the woods of Minnesota has allowed me to have a very personal connection to
nature.  I want to help people see that
there are ways to connect to nature without having to build their own version of Thoreau’s
cabin.  With your help, I will be able to obtain the materials needed to give each piece of Wooded Folk
the best capability to express these emotions and ideas without compromising on materials or methods.
Where your help goes.
Your funding
will allow me to get the materials that I will need to bring my ideas to
life.  Within the world of Wooded Folk, I
have being working on a series of pieces about the process of making firewood and the impacts that they have throughout the different webs of
life in the world.  One of the works that
I am planning to make with your support is a geometric splitting
log made out of acrylic mirror and a stack of split logs made of the same
acrylic mirror and corrugated white plastic.
The second piece that your funding will unlock is a large installation
comprised of a sound element of a recording of the woods augmented with
birdcalls and a set of 6-12 different 3D printed bird models.  The birds will be printed with the different
collared filaments that represent their natural color schemes.  This array of colored printer filament will
be made possible by your donations.
There are many other works that are stuck on the drawing board, but with
your help, their paths will be unblocked.
What I have to offer
you.
Because you are helping me, I
want to be able to provide you with an object of my gratitude.  I have created all of these works, and I hope that they will bring you as much joy as they bring me.
$5.00 – A handwritten thank you note on a card printed with
an image of one of my “Binary Bird” drawings.
$10.00 – A vinyl decal of one of my digital whales from the sculpture,
“Self-Referential Pod”.  The decals are
around 8"" tall and 18"" long and can be black or medium
grey: your pick.
$20.00 – A print from my “Super-vast” series.  Each print is 8"" tall and 22""
long unframed.  Each of five images is an edition

of ten.


$30.00 – An edition of my piece, “Interconnected Stones,” comprised of four individually hung, thread lake stone drawings set on a base
of clear-coated birch plywood. Each piece in the set of four is 6"" by

6"" and around 3"" deep, edition of fifty.


$50.00 – A large vinyl decal of my geometric buck mount
design. No deer were harmed in the making of this piece. This large piece comes
in black and is 36"" tall and 21"" wide.
column3:
/>


$60.00 - Will get you your own, ""My Little Friend"".  ""My Little Friend"", is a 3D printed, abstracted Chickadee on a custom made, wall mounted branch.  He is more than happy to hang out and keep watch over your place.

column1: drawing.  Most of the birds in the series
are songbirds native to Minnesota
column2: it will be a surprise to see what bird you

column1: will get.  The colored drawings are
18"" wide and 24"" tall.
All drawings are unframed. (Image below is a preparatory sketch)
column3:
/>


$200.00 – The sculpture “Split Decision”.  This sculpture is composed of three parts: a set of geometrically abstracted log vinyl

column1: decals, one mirror log, and one handmade and hand carved hatchet. The hatchet
and log together are approximately 20"" tall, 12"" deep and
6"" wide.  Your
sculpture will be one from an edition of ten
will be unique.
Infinity” and two “Binary Bird” drawings.
The sculpture is composed of a full sized double bit axe with a hand
carved design on the handle and a set of geometrically abstracted log
vinyl decals to install on your wall.
The axe is full sized, and the size of the decals on the wall can change
to the space available on your wall. Although the axe handle is real, I do not
advise using it for the felling of trees, just allow it to wow your guests as
it hangs onto the wall. Your sculpture will be one from an edition of ten

installation of this piece will be unique.


$1000.00-  For this
level, you will receive everything! That’s a thank you note, whale decal, one ""Super-vast"" print, buck mount decal, three ""Binary Birds,"" ""Split Decision,"" and ""Three Times Infinity.""
$2000.00 – At this level you will get the whole set from the
$1000.00 level plus a piece of your pick from the show Wooded Folk.
Other ways you can
help
I fully
realize that not everyone can help in the same way.  But there is one way that everyone can help!  That’s to help spread the word.  Please help by passing my campaign on to as
many people as you can.  This can be done
by spreading the word, passing on a link to this campaign, or by using the
Indiegogo share tools.
Thanks for
taking the time to look over my campaign Without community support, I
couldn’t be doing this.
-Steven J Read
