          ""The
supreme Art of War is to subdue your enemy without fighting.""
- Sun Tzu

What is Ethereality Art Book?

Ethereality Art Book is a photorealistic exploration of the art of war in the oneiric world of graphic novels.  Committed to exploring the noble causes of both heroes and villains from an unbiased and non-literal perspective, our novel privilege viewers the freedom and unique discretion to select a character and undergo a more personalized experience.
Express
the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.
Right
now everyone is volunteering their time for this project.  Everyone!
As anyone can attest to the trials of trying to develop art with a
microscopic budget.<span>  It is extremely
difficult but not impossible.
We
are truly blessed by the number people who have and continue to volunteer their
time and talent to our project.  They do so because they have seen some of
the images from previous shoots and strongly believe this particular project
has the potential to be really successful.
But
what does it mean to be successful?  Our initial goal is to develop a book
in conjunction with an art gallery exhibition.  Our long term goal is
showcase the work through various museums and exhibits around the world and
have the book available to a worldwide market of all ages and gender.
We
have a very resourceful group of individuals pulling together, obtaining and
transporting equipment and gear, providing and cooking food, and asking for
favors. But it is a small crew (just us five) with each person doing three to
four different jobs.
With
planned shoots locked down for January, March, May, July, August and September,
your contribution can help us alleviate the out-of-pocket expenses for the
location rental, production catering, any upfront expenses we may run up
against during production, and hopefully take some of the burden off us as we
are overwhelmed.
We
have a great project. We’re dedicated to it and are passionate about the work
but we need your help.
Explain
how much funding you need and where it’s going.
We
have 5 more photo shoots to complete the necessary amount of images to develop
our book.  Our shoots involve a load-in and pre-light day (Fri), shoot
days (Sat &amp
Funding is needed
for:
<ul>
• The rental of the shoot location.
<li>Gas for transportation for our team to pick-up and
return loaned equipment.  (Part of the agreement for us to get the
equipment needed for the shoot is we have to pick it up and drop it off.
Our location is in Van Nuys and we have to trek to Anaheim and Long Beach
for the equipment.)
<li>We need funding for food: craft services and production
catering.
<li>We need funding for kit fees for various departments
(i.e., make-up, hair, wardrobe).
We also need the necessary funding to help open
up our art gallery exhibit and publish copies of our book.
<li>The cost to develop our work for an art gallery exhibit
is under research. Each gallery has its own criteria. More information
will be provided when it becomes available.
• We are currently investigating publishing.  However, we will only publish a limited amount making this a rare collectable.
Describe
where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.
The funds go to where
exactly is stated above.  We will stretch every penny to complete all 5 of the next shoots.

Dr. Mohamed Abou ElNaga, one of Ashoka's
Fellows, founded a paper making centre in old Coptic Cairo in 2005
under the umbrella of his organization El Nafeza. Until now we have
trained 150 trainees, most of them women, and especially those  with
hearing and speaking disabilities show great skills in training and
working. Additionally we're trying to spread the idea of making handmade
paper using low-cost techniques throughout different communities in
Egypt, especially the agricultural communities responsible for the
yearly rice straw burnings that cause a 'black cloud' to hover over
Egypt every October. We have now more than 25 special trainers working

on establishing hand made paper centers in various places in Egypt. Now we need everybody's support to continue to have it open and so the workers, mostly young challenged people, don't lose their jobs

","Dr. Mohamed Abou ElNaga, one of Ashoka's
Fellows, founded a paper making centre in old Coptic Cairo in 2005
under the umbrella of his organization El Nafeza. Until now we have
trained 150 trainees, most of them women, and especially those  with
hearing and speaking disabilities show great skills in training and
working. Additionally we're trying to spread the idea of making handmade
paper using low-cost techniques throughout different communities in
Egypt, especially the agricultural communities responsible for the
yearly rice straw burnings that cause a 'black cloud' to hover over
Egypt every October. We have now more than 25 special trainers working

on establishing hand made paper centers in various places in Egypt. Now we need everybody's support to continue to have it open and so the workers, mostly young challenged people, don't lose their jobs",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

The Rundown:

We've had a good run this winter and managed to save a lot of money.  Got a new alternator for the bus and restocked all of our merchandise.  Paid off our credit cards in full and we've bought a good portion of our upcoming tour's hotel rooms.  Even better, we've hired a pro driver/mechanic to join us on this spring tour and keep the bus running!  But, even after all that good stuff, there's still more we need to take care of.  We need to get new plates, pay for our bus insurance, do a tune up/oil change/filter change, and replace our rotten staircase amongst many other little bits of tour prep.  Thats where you come in!

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We need roughly $2000 to be road ready.  We're asking you, instead of waiting for the show date, to buy tickets and merch directly from us in advance.  Buying in advance gives us a little safety net for this tour and prepares us for emergency.  Plus, you're gonna get bonus perks you wouldn't get at the show!!

column1:
The Impact

If we paid these last few bills out of pocket we'd basically be hitting the road with zero dollars in the bank, and that's risky.  The road is rough and unpredictable, we need a safety net of a couple grand in our pockets should we have some poorly attended shows or emergency bus repairs or emergency anything.  A year and a half ago we had a major breakdown in Arizona to the tune of 5 cancelled shows and $10,000 in repair/hotel/food bills while we were out of commission for almost a week
column2: we believe putting $2000 into the tour now will avoid serious debt later. Plus, If you buy our merch and tickets in advance you're giving us a major boost in coming to your town.

<h3>""A Beacon of Light""
The Agora Borealis opened it's doors last July with the hope of bringing
together some of the most creative and ambitious artists. Those
involved are inspired by the vibrant culture and history of Shreveport
and are constantly on the look-out to make the town more welcoming to
visitors. We try to be a ""beacon of light"" to those who desire a place
to showcase their work and discuss efficient ways to improve the art

community here.

Help us to beautify the  East facing wall under the Kansas City Southern Railroad, between Lake Street and Fairfield Avenue! We consider this a gate to downtown Shreveport, and have big dreams to make it as welcoming as possible! Stay tuned as ideas illuminate and first drafts are drawn. We assure you the unveiling will not be a disappointment!
Meet Nicholas Bustamante
""I am drawn to spaces and items that hold within them the evidence of
time.  Structures that at one time functioned, but now are broken down
to mere shadows of what they once had been.  I use these structures as a
stage to recreate a narrative history for these places."" - N. Bustamante
The Agora Borealis has big dreams
to invite Nicholas Bustamante to Shreveport so he may add some color to the
Marshall Street bridge, at the intersection closest to the store.  Nicholas currently
lives and works in Ruston where he teaches as an associate
professor of art at Louisiana Tech University. He has recently been working on an art installation in Monroe,
Louisiana. See the progress of his mural located at Luna Blue Yoga Center, 428 Desiard Street. We're confident he would be the right person for the job!
Check out how progress is made by visiting https://monroemural.wordpress.com/
You can see more of Nicholas Bustamante's work on his website at www.bustamanteart.com
Visit the Agora Borealis to see the concept art of
the ""Finding Home"" mural in Monroe, LA. You can also purchase one of his prints
to take home with you!
The Agora Phases

We've chosen to do 3 phases to help raise funds for this project. Feel free to contact the store and ask about details, dates, and other questions or concerns.
421 Lake Street, Shreveport, LA (318) 268-3011

PHASE 1 - Permits &
Risks &

We hope to have stations ready and paint in hand this coming June! This gives us only 18 weeks to get permission from Kansas City Southern Railroad, permits from the city (perhaps the state), prepping the environment and deep cleaning to prepare for priming! We will also require heavy duty equipment such as scaffolding or a lift to ensure safety for our artists. Hours of organizing, scheduling, and painting the mural itself. Last step will be sealing and finishing effects to make sure it will withstand the elements of time.

PLEASE NOTE: This project can only be completed if all phases are successful by May,
2015. Otherwise, funds collected will be safety tucked away for a later attempt.
Helping Hands

We know that pockets aren't always deep and sometimes all you can give is your time and energy. There will be a sign-up sheet available for anyone who wants to volunteer their efforts for the cause! Also, if anyone would like to graciously feed or offer supplies for the artist crew, we would love to schedule a day with you to help make it happen! Our experience thus far, with our neighbors and friends of Shreveport/Bossier City have been nothing less than kind, and heart-warming. Thank you for all you're generosity!

column2: >Xango Shola will orchestrate a ceremonial exhibition and prayerformance in London this September 2018 at the Heart &amp
column3:
Mind Festival.

The theme of the festival this year is ""From ME TO WE"". In the spirit of collaboration, Xango Shola of Made in Prayer will be weaving together ceremonial artisans from the global community to create a magical offering of art, music, fashion, ritual and beauty. 

The funds will be used for:

column1: <ul>
• Shipping costs to the UK
<li>Design &amp
• Renting Rehearsal Space
<li>Hair &amp
<li>Photographer &amp
• Materials, Fabrics, Notions
• Transportation
• Proper exhibition displays, mannequins, tables
• Advertising
• Props, Flowers, Candles, Special Lights

To fundraise for this project Shola will be selling prints of original works of art. All prints will be made with the best quality fine art Giclée printers and printed on either paper or stretched ""ready to hang"" canvas! 

Thank you for supporting the arts! This is a passion project which acknowledges all the beautiful ways in which these artists express their artistic gifts through adornment, music &
column2: visual arts. With your help we will be able to create something truly beautiful!

>


and more TBA....

column2:
>The Big Zombie Art Picture

Hi everyone, I'm Rob Sacchetto, inventor of the very first Zombie Portrait service, author, and creator of the most Zombie Artwork on planet Earth! I'm letting everyone who loves my work, know about this FOR FANS especially, new project I'm undertaking, 'Zombie Pinup Girls : Volume One!'

>Here it is folks, the perfect distillation of over a decade of creating Zombie Pinup Art!
The one thing I hear most now when I guest at Pop Culture conventions is, ""Do you have any more Pinup Art?"" The 'Zombie Pinup Divas' as I call them have always been a fun addition to the daily Zombie Art that I've posted online since 2008. They have more recently become a fan favorite which has led me to create Zombie Pinup Girls : Volume One, a gathering of some of the very best art from the beginning, right up to literally last week in this first book!

Of the many thousands of Zombie Art pieces I've created over the years, the Zombie Pinups have been my most personal, and the creations I've been incredibly passionate about! They are expressive, highly detailed and have always raised eyebrows and interest among fans!

This first volume will be 40 pages of the best work from day one, to the most recent! The book will be printed on beautiful bright white glossy stock, and will be presented in a magazine style format with interior pages perfect for clipping and framing should one choose to!

Contributes that help fund this project will of COURSE get their copy to cherish, plus any of the perks they've chosen of course, but will also facilitate the creation of more Zombie Pinup art for future volumes! This will go to further create the largest database of Zombie/Horror Art on our planet for ALL to enjoy!

ARTESTUDIO GINESTRELLE, ASSISI, ITALY

Ciao!

As a professional landscape
artist represented in galleries in the Midwest, I am excited to receive
a one month artist residency in the beautiful region of Assisi, Italy. It is located two hours south of Florence, and I will be a
guest artist in residence with ArteStudio Ginestrelle in the Regional Park of Mount Subasio. I will be painting on location throughout

the countryside and the historic city by bicycle. The residency hosts an international exhibit of its Artists in Residence in Assisi during 2016.

The one month residency which includes lodging, gourmet breakfast, weekly excursions, and train pick up cost is $1070. I will also have material and shipping expenses, lunch/dinners, and

other in-country travel expenses.

I believe it is valuable
to participate in encouraging each others gifts. I will be offering
perk paintings"" of Italy to those who support my residency and will keep you updated

through my facebook artist page. Please visit my art website at www.rachaelvandyke.com to view my artistic practice.

I have included the invitation letter from ArteStudio Ginestrelle.

Grazie!

Rachael Van Dyke

column2: >In 1987, I was reading a book on alchemy when I became fascinated by an alchemical illustration representing the Philosopher's Stone. It depicted the Stone as a type of mandala with a heart surrounded by a thorny wreath and placed in the center of a cross that divided the background into four sections. Each section contained an image representing one of the four ancient elements: Earth, Water, Air, and Fire. The heart had five drops of blood on its surface and a rose bud sprouting from its top. Besides the obvious connection with the Sacred Heart, the five wounds of Christ, and the crown of thorns, the image inspired a deeper connection. In a flash of insight, I realized that the symbolism of the design was entirely interchangeable with that of the Tarot's World card. The dancing nude on the World stands in the center of a wreath and she can be interpreted, like the heart, as a symbol for the soul. The creatures representing the four evangelists in the corners of the World are also symbolically connected to the four elements through their Medieval correlation to the fixed signs of the zodiac. This realization was like a key that opened a lock to a forgotten door. I sat mesmerized as images poured out of this new portal in my mind. They formed a parade of alchemical illustrations that were spontaneously paired with Tarot trumps and it became obvious that the trumps can be alchemical, and that the series of trumps describes the alchemical Opus.
column3: >This insight led me into research, writing, and drawing and after eight years the result was an uncommonly beautiful and meaningful deck.

column2: >From the beginning, The Alchemical Tarot's publication has been linked to magical synchronistic events and its reputation has grown over the years. Original art for the Alchemical Tarot was exhibited at the opening of the Tarot Museum in Riola Italy, in 2007, and at the LA Craft and Folk Art Museum, in 2010, and the cards have been displayed on numerous television shows. Due to popular demand, I want to reprint this deck.

>The Alchemical Tarot was originally published by Harper/Collins in London, in 1995. That edition is now out of print and, although it originally sold for $35, copies have now sold for over $2,000. In 2007, I regained the rights to the deck and published The Alchemical Tarot: Renewed. This edition was redesigned and improved. The line drawing of an archway that formed the border on the original cards was dropped so that the drawing could be enlarged. I made improvements in the drawings, added shading, and improved the coloring. I designed a new back for the cards. When I designed the Lovers card for the first edition, my editor felt that it was too sexy and asked me to tone it down. As an added feature, the second edition included both versions of the Lovers, the one that was previously published and the censored version. The 79 cards were 4.75” by 2.75” and came in a tuck box with a little-white-book. Now that edition is also out of print.

>Keeping the the changes from that edition, I have again made improvements to clarify the symbolism in this 79 card deck. This is particularly noticeable on the eight of swords where the beast now has wings. I have redesigned the back with an image that gives insight into the symbolism of the four elements and have added more description about the symbolism in the little-white-book. I am now ready to print this third edition. In conjunction with the printing, I am finishing an updated version of the companion book and I am working with software engineer, Tony Newell, to create an APP version of The Alchemical Tarot.

>This edition is ready to print and I need $5,000 for printing costs. If I do not receive all of this money, I can print a smaller edition and I will make up any balance in the payment myself. If you contribute you will receive your premiums.

>Donate $700 and you will receive the print, the deck, and a signed copy of the companion book, plus you can come to my house for a five-hour personal class on using The Alchemical Tarot.
>If you would like to see the Alchemical Tarot in print, please spread the word. Tweet, post to Facebook, your Wordpress blog,
column4: >Aeclectic Tarot Forum,

column1: Update:
We have reached the goal in record time.
Thanks so much to everyone who has contributed!

This covers the printing cost and we have also covered the shipping cost.  Every dollar above now will free up my time to finish the revised companion book for The Alchemical Tarot: Renewed and to finish the art for my new Tarot of the Sevenfold Mystery.  Needless to say, I will be excepting donations right up until the end of the campaign and I will be giving out the perks.  The prints can go out right away and the deck will be delivered in November. I hope to have the book ready by then also.  So keep donating.   

","My Story

In 1987, I was reading a book on alchemy when I became fascinated by an alchemical illustration representing the Philosopher's Stone. It depicted the Stone as a type of mandala with a heart surrounded by a thorny wreath and placed in the center of a cross that divided the background into four sections. Each section contained an image representing one of the four ancient elements: Earth, Water, Air, and Fire. The heart had five drops of blood on its surface and a rose bud sprouting from its top. Besides the obvious connection with the Sacred Heart, the five wounds of Christ, and the crown of thorns, the image inspired a deeper connection. In a flash of insight, I realized that the symbolism of the design was entirely interchangeable with that of the Tarot's World card. The dancing nude on the World stands in the center of a wreath and she can be interpreted, like the heart, as a symbol for the soul. The creatures representing the four evangelists in the corners of the World are also symbolically connected to the four elements through their Medieval correlation to the fixed signs of the zodiac. This realization was like a key that opened a lock to a forgotten door. I sat mesmerized as images poured out of this new portal in my mind. They formed a parade of alchemical illustrations that were spontaneously paired with Tarot trumps and it became obvious that the trumps can be alchemical, and that the series of trumps describes the alchemical Opus. This insight led me into research, writing, and drawing and after eight years the result was an uncommonly beautiful and meaningful deck.
The Impact

From the beginning, The Alchemical Tarot's publication has been linked to magical synchronistic events and its reputation has grown over the years. Original art for the Alchemical Tarot was exhibited at the opening of the Tarot Museum in Riola Italy, in 2007, and at the LA Craft and Folk Art Museum, in 2010, and the cards have been displayed on numerous television shows. Due to popular demand, I want to reprint this deck.

The Alchemical Tarot was originally published by Harper/Collins in London, in 1995. That edition is now out of print and, although it originally sold for $35, copies have now sold for over $2,000. In 2007, I regained the rights to the deck and published The Alchemical Tarot: Renewed. This edition was redesigned and improved. The line drawing of an archway that formed the border on the original cards was dropped so that the drawing could be enlarged. I made improvements in the drawings, added shading, and improved the coloring. I designed a new back for the cards. When I designed the Lovers card for the first edition, my editor felt that it was too sexy and asked me to tone it down. As an added feature, the second edition included both versions of the Lovers, the one that was previously published and the censored version. The 79 cards were 4.75” by 2.75” and came in a tuck box with a little-white-book. Now that edition is also out of print.

Keeping the the changes from that edition, I have again made improvements to clarify the symbolism in this 79 card deck. This is particularly noticeable on the eight of swords where the beast now has wings. I have redesigned the back with an image that gives insight into the symbolism of the four elements and have added more description about the symbolism in the little-white-book. I am now ready to print this third edition. In conjunction with the printing, I am finishing an updated version of the companion book and I am working with software engineer, Tony Newell, to create an APP version of The Alchemical Tarot.
What I Need and What You Get

This edition is ready to print and I need $5,000 for printing costs. If I do not receive all of this money, I can print a smaller edition and I will make up any balance in the payment myself. If you contribute you will receive your premiums.
Donate $30 and you'll get an 8.5” by 11” signed archival gyclee print of your choice of one of The Alchemical Tarot illustrations.
Donate $40 and you'll receive a signed copy of The Alchemical Tarot.
Donate $65 and you'll receive both the print and the signed copy of the deck.
Donate $120 and you'll receive the print, the deck, and a signed copy of the companion book when it is complete.
Donate $200 and you will receive the print, the deck, and a signed copy of the companion book, plus I will give you a one-hour Tarot reading with the deck over the phone or in person in Saugerties.
Donate $700 and you will receive the print, the deck, and a signed copy of the companion book, plus you can come to my house for a five-hour personal class on using The Alchemical Tarot.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to see the Alchemical Tarot in print, please spread the word. Tweet, post to Facebook, your Wordpress blog, Aeclectic Tarot Forum, or any other media you have access to. Thank you for your encouragement and support.
For More Information go to http://www.alchemicaltarot.com

This covers the printing cost and we have also covered the shipping cost.  Every dollar above now will free up my time to finish the revised companion book for The Alchemical Tarot: Renewed and to finish the art for my new Tarot of the Sevenfold Mystery.  Needless to say, I will be excepting donations right up until the end of the campaign and I will be giving out the perks.  The prints can go out right away and the deck will be delivered in November. I hope to have the book ready by then also.  So keep donating.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

The Tower of Transformation is an Installation/Interactive portable
art piece for the Burning Man 2011 theme-Rites of Passage. Based on a
Balinese cremation tower in form and intent, it will be modified for
presentation in Black Rock City.

In addition to traditional Balinese gold leaf stencil designs, the tower will be
covered in stencils by contemporary street artists from Bali, Java,
the U.S. and Europe. It will also contain a contemporary shadow puppet
theater.

Participants will be invited to join the Tower in procession around
Burning Man, adding their sentiments about the Rites of Passage in
their own experience to the piece through writing on or artistic
modification to the tower.

Our Journeys...



On May 13 I arrived in Bali where I spent a month working on the basic structure of the
Tower with my collaborator, Balinese contemporary painter Made Aswino Aji,
and his father I.Wayan Sika. In addition to being internationally collected painters,
this father and son team is my touchstone for keeping true to Balinese
culture while giving it a contemporary twist.  We have been learning from Aji's
family elders about the construction and traditions of the cremation towers of Bali.

My goal is to bring awareness of Balinese rites of passage to the citizens of Black Rock City. 
The Tower will be covered in canvas with stencils on the theme of Rites of Passage, merging
tradition with contemporary vernacular of street art and graffiti in a way that still shows full
respect for Hindu belief.  There is much we in America can learn from watching our attachments
spin away and burn, releasing our creative spirit.

Cultural Diversity


In my years attending Burning Man since 1999, I have been troubled by the absence of people of color and ethnicity.  For artists from developing countries, the exchange differential between their local currency and US dollars is enough to make it impossible for them to bring their art to America.  And if they are from a ""Muslim"" country, like Indonesia, the process for getting a visa is long, complicated and expensive. It isn't fair, and it's our loss as a nation.

I have never met anyone from a developing country on the Playa, have you?
That needs to change.

I believe that the inclusion of more diverse cultural communities in Black Rock city can greatly benefit the Burning Man artistic vision, and foster a more worldwide burner community.

With this project I hope to set a precedent for a more culturally inclusive Burning Man supported by private and foundation funding.  After this project is shown to be successful, I  hope it will be easier for future cross-cultural projects to be realized.

What does your donation support?


Because I believe so strongly in my vision for this project I am fronting all the expenses myself-no small feat for a massage therapist living in San Francisco!  With the help of my friends and the artistic community I hope to be able to concentrate much more of my time this month on making this project amazing,rather than having to scramble to make a living in one of America's most expensive cities.

Airfare for Made Aswino Aji and Octora Permana, my artistic partners, to come San Francisco from Jakarta $3000

Materials, shipping from Bali and storage in San Francisco for the Tower in it's final production stages $1000

Costs for bringing the Tower of Transformation to Burning Man, including truck rental $1000

Aji and Octora will be staying at my home in San Francisco and I will be covering all the project's incidental expenses myself.


See the sidebar for a list of fabulous perks you get for your contribution


How Else can you Help?


One of the most helpful things you can do to support this project is to spread the word!

Indie GoGo is more likely to feature my campaign if it shows a lot of action, shares and likes on Facebook, and contributions of any amount, no matter what size.  If you're feeling the recession, please don't hesitate to donate even a single dollar-it all adds to my GoGo Factor.  If you're feeling Financially Sassy, please donate at the higher levels and get yourself some awesome Bali-inspired perks!

And you can buy a beautiful Fair Trade Balinese parasol for Burning Man at http://www.thejademonkey.com
my importing company, also featuring fine quality wood carvings from Bali-they make great gifts!


Thanks for supporting us as we bring Bali to Burning Man!


Raven Nielsen
Made Aswino Aji
Wayan Sika
Octora Permana

Look for our C.V.s on our Facebook Page-Tower of Transformation

The Impact
<h3>What is the impact your campaign may have on others? What if your
campaign doesn't happen, what are the consequences? Make it real for
people.)

We are seeking to create a new format for interpersonal and community problem solving through mixed media art performances.  We will use your donations to support development costs of a character library, research and production of animation clips and costumes for performance, and choreography.  We want to take this work on tour and use it to help children and adults dance their conflicts away!
<h3>What We Need &amp

(Break it down for folks - how much money do you need and where is it going? Be transparent and specific and be sure to address where the money goes if you don't reach your entire goal. For example, do you have other funding sources? Does part of the campaign still happen? Ensure people they are not just buying you dinner. Use this area to tell people about your unique perks, too!)

I have been selected through an international jury of art reviewers to complete this work but have only been offered partial funding for up to two months at Camac.  The scholarship covers 750 euros but there is an additional program cost of 1250 euros per month (about $1633), airfare to Paris and trainfare to Marnay sur Seine (roughly $1100), supply costs (estimated $400) and mailing fees (estimated $250).  As you can see, even with the support of the center, this is a substantial cost for a teaching artist to take on!
A total amount of $3320 will cover the cost of a one month program at Camac.  I have the option (with extended cost) to extend up to two months of residency there.
In gratitude for your support, you will receive the gift of artwork.
For a donation of $15, I will mail you a set of 5 original post cards
for $25 handpainted ""recycled art"" postcards
for $65, a set of archival digital photographic prints with a theme of your choice
for $75 a private yoga lesson (Baltimore area only)
for $100 an original piece of artwork

and for $200 or more an original painting or puppet to your commission (aka, to match your couch, personal portraits, theme of your choice!)  Of course each is accompanied by a personal thank you note.  Please see my website at www.elisabethgambino.com to get an idea of pieces you would like.
Other Ways You Can Help
(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)
Art can heal communities and individuals but MAKING NEW ART IS EXPENSIVE.  HELP US MAKE IT HAPPEN.
We would love to bring our performance to your community or publish the clips and characters in an interactive online format.  WE NEED MONEY TO DO THIS!
Please help in any way you can by twittering, mass
emailing, facebook-ing and sharing with others about how they can
contribute and make this project a reality by using
your wonderful social media resources.  Any donation is truly
appreciated!  These things can multiply if you pass it along.
","Our Story
I have been accepted into an international
artists residency program at the Camac art center in Marnay-sur-Seine,
France  to develop a
new format for interpersonal and
community problem solving through mixed media art performances.  We
want to teach individuals and communities alternate ways of solving
problems through structured play experiences.  This will include
dance, theater, and visual art. The residency as well as the project is expensive! I need your help to
cover the remaining costs of the program, travel and materials.  I work
as a therapeutic art teacher and dance teacher as well as a yoga
instructor, and am already giving up a month of income to work on this project.
In
the past year, community artist Lindsey Bailey and I have developed a
dance-based technique of working to explore human relational
dynamics.   We translated personality and conflict into movement
patterns and types, then set the dancers up

in roles with set response patterns to stimuli.   When other  characters enter, they begin to interrupt each other's movement patterns and desire to achieve a certain outcome.  Dancers have to find a new solution or response pattern to meet their needs. The process reflects individuals’
tendency to resort to learned behavior when we encounter new
situations.   The audience will participate and help us to find the solution
column2: each performance will end differently.  I would like to play with this technique using puppets and

column1: digital manipulation to create interactive stories.   These manually developed, digitally sequenced
and edited images may even be reassembled with sound or text to
create an interactive “storybook” format that could be paired

with live actors or dancers to solve community problems.  We plan to take this work on tour next year and hopefully publish to other media like the internet and picture books.  This is a lot of work and new technology we need your help to develop!

""Do not dream our lives, living our dreams""
""And if we went for a drive Photographic Road Trip of the most iconic U.S. highway to create a book with unique pictures!""

We have implemented a project ""ROUTE 66"". For us, this project is a challenge ... a challenge to prove to the world that you do not have to follow the constraints that life imposes on you. If you wish, you can reach out and touch your dreams. It is never easy ... to break with the norm, leaving the security of what is familiar and safe ... and try something completely different, but it can be done.
Any contribution is greatly appreciated and will help me cover the costs for books, photographs and ROAD TRIP ROUTE 66. If you feel moved to do so, the sharing of this campaign is as easy as repost the link.
Make sure you choose your advantage if you donate. All items will be shipped at the end of the campaign.

Short Summary

LiftPlus Wheelbarrow is a Low Center of Gravity wheelbarrow with a unique undercarriage  design that keeps the wheelbarrow leveled while keeping it from flipping to its sides. Its low profile composition carries loads close to the  ground making loading and unloading an effortless task. LiftPlus  Wheelbarrow has been designed and developed by AQP - American Quality  Products, Inc., using high quality materials for durable and efficient  products that surpasses the applications and benefits of traditional  wheelbarrows.
LiftPlus Wheelbarrow has a dramatic innovative design featuring the following:
<ul>
• Low Center of Gravity for stability and control
• Higher leverage angle to displace the weight to the wheel
• Low profile design lays flat on the floor
• Side-to-side self leveling action
• Safe and balanced maneuverability
• Easy to load and unload materials
• Covers more applications than a traditional wheelbarrow
• Reliable solid one piece steel undercarriage
• Inflatable 4.80 / 4.00 – 8 tire provides great support and mobility

The LiftPlus Basic Frame Wheelbarrow has a cold-bent durable steel frame. It has been designed with a single steel tube to provide the wheelbarrow with a stronger frame. The steel  frame and its wheel are adaptable for different uses and it can easily  lay flat on the floor.
Tool boxes, pressure washers, small gas engine water pumps or electric  generators can be installed directly to the LiftPlus Wheelbarrow frame  making it easy to move heavy devices anywhere you need.

The LiftPlus Carry-All Wheelbarrow has a hardwood base with a front 8° angle support wall securely attached to our basic undercarriage for a non-slippery surface that will hold materials in place. Use it to transport barrels, construction materials (e.g. brick, stones, tiles),  produce crates, heavy boxes and more.
The low profile design keeps loads almost at ground level and allows for  easy loading and unloading. Heavy loads can easily slide on and off,  preventing the operator from unnecessary lifting.

The LiftPlus Steel Pan Wheelbarrow has a sheet metal steel bucket of 6 cubic feet and 300 lbs capacity  attached to our basic undercarriage. The sturdy steel bucket is perfect  for liquids and granular materials.  Its Low Center of Gravity design  provides better stability and control for the operator as it prevents  the wheelbarrow from flipping over.
Due to its low profile design, shoveling is considerably easier because the bucket is in a lower position than conventional wheelbarrows.

Due to its unique design features, the LiftPlus Wheelbarrow surpasses all the capabilities of a traditional wheelbarrow.

Key Features:
Low Center of Gravity

Basically this means that more of an object’s mass is closer to the ground,  therefore less likely to tip over. For example, race cars are very  stable because they have a very low center of gravity. Trucks are not  very stable because they have a higher center of gravity. The weight  should be as close to the floor as possible to achieve stability that  results into more efficiency, safety and less effort.

Leverage

When you lift the LiftPlus Wheelbarrow the weight is displaced towards the  wheel and the leverage angle is greater than in a conventional  wheelbarrow. Because of this, the operator lifts as low as 35% to 25% of the weight, which is less than the usual.

Low Profile Design

Thanks to the low profile design, LiftPlus Wheelbarrow will not easily tip  over on sloped surfaces. Since it lays flat on the floor, the load is as close to the ground as possible. Other wheelbarrows hold the load much  higher, therefore increasing the chances of tipping over and  consequently dumping the load to the ground.

Facing a fragmented competitive set, LiftPlus Wheelbarrows hit the consumer's  bullseye by delivering a balance of innovation, performance and value  that will make it one of the most popular wheelbarrows in America. Its  unique composition offers an intuitive design created to make everyday  life much easier for operators and improving productivity.

As endorsement to our LiftPlus Wheelbarrows, we have founded AQP (American Quality Products) and we have been granted the patent from USPTO.

We’ve sold a few units, but building one wheelbarrow at a time delays  production tremendously and therefore we wouldn’t be able to keep with  the demand. So, here is where we need your help. We believe this is a  great product, and in order to achieve industrial manufacturing level  and gain momentum to start production and launch it to the market.

Every pledge no matter how small will be immensely valuable to us. Above all, this will be a great opportunity to own a First Edition LiftPlus  Wheelbarrow.
We thank you for giving us the opportunity to present this product! For  more information, comments or questions feel free to visit www.liftpluswheelbarrow.com or email us at info@liftpluswheelbarrow.com

column5: we've partnered Maine artists with local CSA farms. The artists are busy creating art inspired by their farmers’ lives, work, landscapes, challenges and ideals.
column7: >Maine’s artist and farming communities are vibrant, idealistic groups, both key to our state’s unique sense of place, and t
column9: >he Kennebec Valley Art Association (KVAA) believes that artists can use the power of their artistic voices to effect social change.

column4: >Artwork by all fourteen participating artists will be exhibited at the Harlow Gallery in Hallowell, Maine through October 2012.  Additional exhibitions focusing on select artist/farmer groupings will take place at partner venues in Maine November 2012 to January 2013, including Frontier Cafe Gallery in Brunswick, Maine Farmland Trust Art Gallery in Belfast, Savory Maine Dining &
column5: Provisions in Damariscotta, Sheepscot General's Gallery at Uncas Farms in Whitefield,  and more to be announced soon. The timing of all the exhibitions is meant in part to help spread awareness about local CSA farms as they begin recruiting new members for 2013.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: #ffffff
column5:
>What is a CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) Farm?

Our partnering farmers are all operating CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) farms in and around central Maine.  In joining a CSA, folks make a financial commitment to their farm by investing in a share of the produce at the beginning of the growing season. In return farmers are committed to producing the freshest, most flavorful, high quality food possible for their members (most CSA farms adhere to organic standards as much as possible).  Typically each CSA member gets a weekly delivery of produce from early summer through harvest. Community Supported Agriculture is a grassroots response to the growing social and environmental problems of our modern industrial food system.  According to MOFGA, Maine’s CSA community includes over 150 farms and 6,200 shares and is transforming relationships between people, food and farms. Each farm is as unique as the community supporting it.

column1: <h3><span style=""background-color: #ffffff

column4: >CSA:Community Supporting Arts is a project of the Kennebec Valley Art Association, a 501(c)3 membership based arts organization.  Founded in 1959 in Augusta, Maine, we’ve owned and operated the Harlow Gallery in Hallowell since 1963. The KVAA is working in partnership with the Kennebec Local Food Initiative, an organization based in Gardiner, Maine that strives to strengthen community food security through access, education, information and advocacy.
>Video by CSA artist Scott Minzy.

column1: ","About CSA: Community Supporting Arts
The premise of this project is simple
column2: we've partnered Maine artists with local CSA farms. The artists are busy creating art inspired by their farmers’ lives, work, landscapes, challenges and ideals.  Maine’s artist and farming communities are vibrant, idealistic groups, both key to our state’s unique sense of place, and the Kennebec Valley Art Association (KVAA) believes that artists can use the power of their artistic voices to effect social change.

column1: Artwork by all fourteen participating artists will be exhibited at the Harlow Gallery in Hallowell, Maine through October 2012.  Additional exhibitions focusing on select artist/farmer groupings will take place at partner venues in Maine November 2012 to January 2013, including Frontier Cafe Gallery in Brunswick, Maine Farmland Trust Art Gallery in Belfast, Savory Maine Dining & Provisions in Damariscotta, Sheepscot General's Gallery at Uncas Farms in Whitefield,  and more to be announced soon. The timing of all the exhibitions is meant in part to help spread awareness about local CSA farms as they begin recruiting new members for 2013.

What is a CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) Farm?Our partnering farmers are all operating CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) farms in and around central Maine.  In joining a CSA, folks make a financial commitment to their farm by investing in a share of the produce at the beginning of the growing season. In return farmers are committed to producing the freshest, most flavorful, high quality food possible for their members (most CSA farms adhere to organic standards as much as possible).  Typically each CSA member gets a weekly delivery of produce from early summer through harvest. Community Supported Agriculture is a grassroots response to the growing social and environmental problems of our modern industrial food system.  According to MOFGA, Maine’s CSA community includes over 150 farms and 6,200 shares and is transforming relationships between people, food and farms. Each farm is as unique as the community supporting it.
What We Need & What You Get

In the true CSA spirit, we are inviting the community to invest in CSA: Community Supporting Arts and help us to connect and celebrate art, artists and the local foods community. The project has received grant funding from the Maine Community Foundation and from the Davis Family Foundation, and one of the reasons our grant proposals where successful was because we promised that the final fundraising effort would be this very cool grassroots Indigogo campaign!  Any amount helps, so please buy into our CSA: Community Supporting Arts today -- it's easy and we have great thank you gifts.
Other Ways You Can Help

We hope you'll chose to join our CSA project by donating today, but even if you haven't the means you can help us by spreading the word. Please hit the 'Share' button or email the link to this Indiegogo campaign to your friends. Also you can  start buying local today! Consider joining a CSA Farm and  buying locally produced food whenever you can.  Those of us who live in Maine have access to a fantastic listing of local foods resources at Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners Association.
Who is involved?

CSA:Community Supporting Arts is a project of the Kennebec Valley Art Association, a 501(c)3 membership based arts organization.  Founded in 1959 in Augusta, Maine, we’ve owned and operated the Harlow Gallery in Hallowell since 1963. The KVAA is working in partnership with the Kennebec Local Food Initiative, an organization based in Gardiner, Maine that strives to strengthen community food security through access, education, information and advocacy.
Video by CSA artist Scott Minzy.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

My GOAL: To complete my life-size sculpture, The Death of Vanity, and to donate her to the New Orleans Museum of Art.
About My Sculpture

My sculpture explores human nature. I like to question beliefs that we take for granted and tell the stories of the events, moments, emotions that we universally experience, even though we almost always feel like each is unique to us alone.

My work is classically based. I emphasize expression and subtle movement through my use of detail in hands, feet, facial tones and body language that I hope creates a piece that is both alive and meaningful to the observer.
About the Death of Vanity
The Death of Vanity is an exploration of the so-called vice of vanity. We call it a vice, but is it? How much vanity is too much?

As you approach Vanity, you see a very beautiful nude woman, life sized, who is gazing at you with a bit of disdain. You notice a mirror in her hand and you can’t resist taking a look at your own image. You notice that she is standing on a wood butcher block and, curiously, there is a crow at her feet, staring up at her as if trying to get her attention.

As you walk around Vanity you see the cause of her disdain. She has been stabbed in the back with a large kitchen knife. Why? Who would want to kill Vanity? Can Vanity be killed? Should she? Looking more closely, you see signs of decay from within. You notice the small garter snake clinging to a tendril of her hair, a spider that has made a home under another.  Is Vanity alive or isn’t she? As you circle back around to gaze upon Vanity’s face again you notice something new in her expression
My Goal for the Vanity Project

My goal for The Death of Vanity is to donate her to the New Orleans Museum of Art. I went to high school in New Orleans and developed my love of art and sculpture there. I think the piece is uniquely suited for both the city and the museum. New Orleans is a glorious and mysterious town, full with exterior beauty and grandeur as well as interior complexity. Katrina tried to kill New Orleans, but like Vanity, New Orleans can’t be killed. A little bit of vanity is a good thing, along with a heart like that of the city of New Orleans. The museum has a great and diverse collection of art ranging from ancient to cutting edge contemporary. It is my hope that this sculpture, which blends classical sculpture with contemporary narrative, will find a home in the sculpture garden adjacent to the museum. But in order for me to open discussions with the museum, Vanity has to be cast and complete.

The sculpting for the Death of vanity is substantially completed. But that is only about 30% of the process. After a bit of clean-up work from me, the next step will be to work with Smart Castings foundry in Sarasota to create the multi-piece mold and then to cast the piece in bronze using the lost wax method. For more information about the casting process, click HERE.

I anticipate that the transformation from clay to bronze will take 8 to 10 weeks and will commence after the donation period ends, assuming I fully reach my goal. Even if I don't fully reach my goal, I can complete phases as you see below - the stages of the casting and delivery process and the cost for each.
The Death of Vanity will eventually be an edition of 5, however this project is intended to create the mold and the first casting only, which will be donated to the museum.

This process is very expensive, and that is why I am asking for your help! I hope you will see it in your heart to donate even a small amount towards her completion - and that you will be a co-donor with me to the city that I love. Even if you can't participate financially, If you believe in The Vanity Project, please share this campaign with your family and friends! Spread the word! Thank you all very much!
Here is the breakdown of costs associated with the completion:
Phase I- sculpting in clay- complete
Clay and armature: $0, ($1350 was paid for by me)
250 hours of sculpting: $0, (equivalent $50/hr donated by me)
Phase II- Creating the rubber molds- 2 to 3 weeks
Molds: $5,160
Phase III- Casting the sculpture- 5 to 6 weeks
Casting through to Patina: $13,550
Phase IV- Mounting, presentation and photography- 1 week
Base and mounting: $1100
Photography: $200
Phase V- Presentation and delivery to museum
Shipping and transportation: $4,860
Total required: $24,870
Project donation request: $24,000

In addition,  I pledge to reinvest 5% of any profits over and above costs associated with The Vanity Project back into other IndieGoGo.com projects to keep the creative juices flowing around the world!

column2: >To help you make your decision I have put together a few choice perks! See images of many of them under the Gallery Tab.

column1: For more information and additional images for editions 2 through 5 of The Death of Vanity, click HERE.

HELP!
Arts in the Alley is a community project in Richmond VA to turn rundown city streets and alleys into bright outdoor art galleries by painting murals.

Our next project is THIS weekend - October 6-7 - and half our funding needed for supplies just fell through. We have a few donations we know will be coming in, but we still need to raise an additional $500 by this Friday (October 5).

So: this is an emergency campaign.... can you help us? If we have 50 people who can spare $10 we have what we need. Or 20 people who give $25. It's a tall order, in four days. But we hope you can help us.
Jeanine Guidry
Executive Director, Arts in the Alley

The Mission (Dun...Dun...Dun!!!)
We are raising funding to build an interactive effigy for an outdoor
festival.  This effigy will use perspective and imagination to create a
hidden message to the public viewer.  This is a temporary installation
which will be removed after the festival end date but will become a
focal part of the environment and artistic movement during the open
gates.  The structure will be burnt as an effigy should be in
celebration of the festival's closing hours.  The structure stands in
three totems within a large field as a series of organic wooden shapes.
The tallest of these totems being approximately 12 foot tall, the
shortest being 8 foot tall with a lit design under each will offer a
nice ambient tone to the artistic village.
Come play in the Forest of Ray LaGarto

In 2010 nine amazingly resilient teens were cast in the documentary film brooklyn bridges- to bethlehem &
column2:
back (bb). They had traveled from Brooklyn to Bethlehem in the Occupied Territories to experience the value of writing for releasing their daily struggles.

Now, in 2012 their creative growth through the documentary has inspired the creation of breaking walls, a writing-performing program for teens all over the world.

column1:
On July 5th in Berlin, Germany they’ll come together again, this time guiding equally resilient and hopeful teens from Brooklyn, Bethlehem and Berlin as they create an original Theater Piece in a nine-day writing-performing workshop. For the bb teens, transitioning from participants to leaders is a challenge, but these young men and women are eager to use breaking walls to help these kids find their voices.
breaking walls needs your help to make this Berlin workshop happen.

In thanks for your generous support, we’re offering some cool and personal perks: social network Shout-Outs, an online copy of our complete Berlin video, daily YouTube updates straight from Berlin, even an original “thank you” poem written by a breaking walls participant.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get
We need $9,300.00 to cover the cost of our housing at the Amstel House, Berlin Passes and daily expenses for the entire group of 20 participants, leaders &
column3:
chaperones from Bethlehem and Brooklyn while in Berlin.

Five lucky contributors (chosen at random) will receive a special, personal poem written by Ryan Smith from Brooklyn.

The Impact

Making connections with a broader world through writing and performing empowers breaking walls teens to dedicate themselves to being strong, well-rounded individuals and making a difference in the world.

Starting July 5, 2012 young men and women from our long-term partners (ACORN Community High School in Brooklyn, NY and Al-Rowwad Center in Aida Refugee Camp near Bethlehem) will collaborate with students at Nelson Mandela International High School in Berlin for a nine day writing-performing, cultural exchange and peacemaking workshop. A total of six facilitators and twenty new writer-performers will participate in our initial breaking walls workshop in Berlin.

Al-Rowwad Director Abdel Fattah Abu Srour says of the program: “It’s so nice to see our kids and the Brooklyn kids, who are usually seen as the ones in need of an intervention, taking their place on the world stage as creative leaders.”

This is an inspiring message for our times especially delivered by emerging 21st century leaders. breaking walls can’t help but encourage its supporters and audience to wonder and marvel at how some human beings find the resilience to channel their dark side into a mechanism to move forward.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help our campaign grow by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise
column4:
our Indiegogo campaign can easily be shared (using the ""share tools"" provided) on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, gmail status, etc. Get all of your friends, sons, daughters, nieces, nephews, and neighbors to visit us at http://breakingwalls.org

YouTube http://www.youtube.com/user/frantarr11?feature=mhee
Our online adolescent literary magazine Speak Reach Peace Out http://www.srpoutmag.com/www.srpoutmag.com.

Then, join the discussion on Facebook http://facebook.com/bbdocumentary
and Twitter http://ttwitter.com/bbdocumentary

","In 2010 nine amazingly resilient teens were cast in the documentary film brooklyn bridges- to bethlehem & back (bb). They had traveled from Brooklyn to Bethlehem in the Occupied Territories to experience the value of writing for releasing their daily struggles. Now, in 2012 their creative growth through the documentary has inspired the creation of breaking walls, a writing-performing program for teens all over the world.

column1: On July 5th in Berlin, Germany they’ll come together again, this time guiding equally resilient and hopeful teens from Brooklyn, Bethlehem and Berlin as they create an original Theater Piece in a nine-day writing-performing workshop. For the bb teens, transitioning from participants to leaders is a challenge, but these young men and women are eager to use breaking walls to help these kids find their voices. breaking walls needs your help to make this Berlin workshop happen.In thanks for your generous support, we’re offering some cool and personal perks: social network Shout-Outs, an online copy of our complete Berlin video, daily YouTube updates straight from Berlin, even an original “thank you” poem written by a breaking walls participant.What We Need & What You GetWe need $9,300.00 to cover the cost of our housing at the Amstel House, Berlin Passes and daily expenses for the entire group of 20 participants, leaders & chaperones from Bethlehem and Brooklyn while in Berlin.Five lucky contributors (chosen at random) will receive a special, personal poem written by Ryan Smith from Brooklyn.The ImpactMaking connections with a broader world through writing and performing empowers breaking walls teens to dedicate themselves to being strong, well-rounded individuals and making a difference in the world.Starting July 5, 2012 young men and women from our long-term partners (ACORN Community High School in Brooklyn, NY and Al-Rowwad Center in Aida Refugee Camp near Bethlehem) will collaborate with students at Nelson Mandela International High School in Berlin for a nine day writing-performing, cultural exchange and peacemaking workshop. A total of six facilitators and twenty new writer-performers will participate in our initial breaking walls workshop in Berlin.Al-Rowwad Director Abdel Fattah Abu Srour says of the program: “It’s so nice to see our kids and the Brooklyn kids, who are usually seen as the ones in need of an intervention, taking their place on the world stage as creative leaders.”This is an inspiring message for our times especially delivered by emerging 21st century leaders. breaking walls can’t help but encourage its supporters and audience to wonder and marvel at how some human beings find the resilience to channel their dark side into a mechanism to move forward.Other Ways You Can HelpYou can help our campaign grow by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise
column2: our Indiegogo campaign can easily be shared (using the ""share tools"" provided) on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, gmail status, etc. Get all of your friends, sons, daughters, nieces, nephews, and neighbors to visit us at http://breakingwalls.orgYouTube http://www.youtube.com/user/frantarr11?feature=mheeOur online adolescent literary magazine Speak Reach Peace Out http://www.srpoutmag.com/www.srpoutmag.com.Then, join the discussion on Facebook http://facebook.com/bbdocumentary and Twitter http://ttwitter.com/bbdocumentary",2.0,0,"3 Campaigns

column1: |","New York, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-brooklyn-teens-breaking-walls-around-the-world-this-time-in-berlin/pica

What would I like you to do?
Most simply, I would like you to take a moment and consider making a donation to my fundraiser.
I have less than three weeks to raise these funds, so if you would, please consider making your donation sooner rather than later.  Thank you!
So, what I am doing this fundraiser for?

I am asking for your donations to cover the costs of traveling, registering, lodging, and feeding myself in Fayetville, Arkansas.  Why I am I going to Arkansas, of all places?  Well, I recently became the Phoenix Individual Poetry Slam Champion.  And this offers me the chance to represent the city of Phoenix at the 2012 Individual World Poetry Slam (IWPS)!
Why is this important?

IWPS is one the world's largest stages for performance poetry.  Poets from across the nation will converge on Fayeteville, Arkansas, between October 4 and October 6 to compete for the title of World Champ.  This is no small event: a platform as far reaching and respected as this has catipulted many poets to the next level of their pursuits as artists.  And with the notoriety gained, poets can often help solicit new and extra resources for the community they represent--exactly like the community I organinize for.

I have never had the opportunity to compete at IWPS.  It has been a dream of mine for over five years now to compete at this level, but I don't have the resources to make this dream a reality all on my own.
So, I need your support.
Where will your money be going?
1. All funds will be going directly to me
2. The funds will cover the cost of:
A. A plane ticket to Arkansas from Phoenix ($500+)
B. A shared hotel room for four nights ($230 approx.)
C. Remaining registration fee for the event ($100)
D. Basic food needs for the four days of travel ($120)
E. If possible, a minimal monetary coverage for days off from work ($150)
*(This is important, because I do not have paid time off at my job)
3. My best estimate is that I will need approximately $1,150 in total
How about a little info on me?

I am a restaurant worker, arts organizer, and poet.  My job and life ventures are humble, but I enjoy the principals of serving. I may not make a great deal of money, but I am passionate about what I do.
My life as an artist:

I started writing poetry in college. After my first performance at a coffee house reading on my college campus, I started writing and reading in the greater Los Angeles area on a fairly regular basis.  Upon moving to Arizona after college, I was introduced to slam poetry.  About 18 months later, I was hosting and organizing my own slam poetry show.  I ran this slam  from 2007 to 2009, in which time I was also the Grand Slam Champion in '07, and runner up in '08.  I represented Phoenix both years on a team of poets at the National Poetry Slam.  As of the summer '09, I took a haitus from slam for about three years.  Around March of this year, I returned to the slam that I am now helping to host and organize in Phoenix.  Slam poetry is something that I respect and value a great deal, and as a result, I have felt nothing short of privileged to be able to help develop and give back to my local community of poetry lovers, writers, and performers.  I have given a lot over my years in slam poetry, and the majority of it has offered me some of the greatest satisfaction I could ask for as an artist, performer, community leader, and person.
Will you get anything in return?
Please see the posted categories.  When you make your donation, indicate whether or not you would like to receive the stated gifts.

    My Dirty Paint Brush is Never Dusty

         Only wet with anticipation...

It's so HARD being an artist at times. I struggle, and yearn, to pick up a paint brush, and express to the world how I desperately feel inside! I want to PERFORM  and inspire others to do the same.  I want to unleash EXPLOSIVE energy that comes from within each and every one of you! So PLEASE... reach down DEEP into your pockets and help me grab some fresh supplies!

(""Bona Dea: Sacra Opertum"" by Lisa Little Art)

Size doesn't really matter, but the Bigger the Better

 Your money will buy me a RIDE straight to the art store where I will slide my hands over every tool of the trade and use them without regret. I plan on buying paint brushes of every size... AFTER ALL, it's not the size of the paint brush that matters, but how you stroke the canvas.  Will also buy many fresh tubes of paint, and canvas that I can slap some color on.  Don't leave me to just my hands. Help me to achieve my highest ecstasy.

Pamplona International Performance Art Festival eres tú.

PIPAF es un festival internacional abierto a todas y todos en la ciudad de Pamplona con más de veinte eventos, talleres, conferencias gratuitos para todas las edades creado para acercar el arte de la performance a cada artista, espectador y habitante.

Con la cabeza puesta en los Encuentros de Arte de Pamplona del 72, un colectivo de artistas y comisarios dentro de International Platform of Performance Art han elegido Pamplona como ciudad referente del arte del performance. Este evento internacional pretende como entonces dar un nuevo impulso a la vida cultural de la capital navarra.  Estos encuentros del 72 al igual que PIPAF se ofrececieron de forma gratuita al público de Pamplona, en aquel caso en la semana previa a las fiestas de San Fermin desarrollandose en dieciséis espacios, varios de ellos la propia calle. La intención era involucrar a la ciudad en un gran happening con la intención de informar de las últimas tendencias y sobre todo establecer un debate directo entre el artista y el público.

Este es el espíritu de PIPAF, crear, investigar, aprender, difundir...PIPAF realizará sus actividades durante todo el mes de Noviembre en colaboración de los espacios culturales más importantes de Navarra, tales como Museo Oteiza, Centro de Arte Contemporáneo de Huarte, Universidad Pública de Navarra, Galería Canvas, Escuela de Artes, la asociación cultural el Vértigo de la Trapecista, librería y espacio cultural Mequiero vivir, Hegan &

El término Performance, se ha difundido en el ámbito de las artes plásticas a partir de la expresión inglesa performance art , con el significado de “arte en vivo”. Esto es lo que va a suceder en PIPAF, se realizaran diferentes eventos, muchos de ellos con una intención docente pero en los cuales siempre estara presente la acción, la corporeidad y su investigación, de la mano de talleres como los que tendran lugar en CAC Huarte, Hegan &
column2: Dream y quizas más activamente, en las acciones de calle que el artista Abel Azcona realizará por el casco viejo de Pamplona con todo aquel que quiera asistir al taller.

column1: En PIPAF también habrá cabida para las muestras de trabajos de artistas nacionales e internacionales de primera línea tales como Maria Jose Arjona, artista Colombiana  graduada en 1999 en la Academia de Artes de Bogotá. Quería ser bailarina y se preparó para ello. Pero luego descubrió que cuerpo y arte podían estar unidos de otra forma: el performance. Sus acciones -en las que siempre está ella de cuerpo presente-han sido vistas en Colombia, China, varios países de Europa y Estados Unidos, donde Arjona vive desde hace diez ańos. Su obra se ha caracterizado por su sobriedad y su impacto. Ella misma define su obra con estas palabras: “Mi obra tiene un proceso similar al que hace el cuerpo al digerir alimentos: pasa de la forma a la síntesis y, como resultado final, genera energía"".

El artista americano Ron Athey también será una pieza importante dentro de las muestras de videoperformance que exhibiran los espacios participantes. El trabajo de Athey explora temas difíciles como las relaciones entre el deseo, la sexualidad y la experiencia traumática. Muchos de sus trabajos incluyen aspectos relacionados con el sadomasoquismo con el fin de hacer frente a las ideas preconcebidas sobre el cuerpo en relación con la masculinidad y la iconografía religiosa.  Con ideas relacionadas con el accionismo vienes, Athey usa su cuerpo como soporte para la práctica artística, en muchos caso también el dolor como via para comunicarse con el público. Actualmente vive en Inglaterra y es colaborador habitual de revistas y periódicos como LA Weekly.

Siguiendole de cerca encontramos al artista y director de este festival, Abel Azcona. Es considerado un artista interdisciplinar pero su principal campo de actuacción es el de la performance, sin embargo Azona da una tremenda importancia a el soporte y resultado plástico de su obra la cual relaciona así con la fotografía, el video, la instalación y la escultura.

Su obra se puede definir bajo dos ejes explorados entre sí a través de una constante sinergia: el autobiográfico y el crítico. Esto hace que obra sea algo ambigua y esté considerada un retrato personal. Utiliza el arte como una herramienta crítica y a su vez de autoconocimiento. Su exploración artística considerada altamente autobiográfica indaga en su infancia marcada por experiencias de abandono y maltrato infantil, siendo su madre biológica referente clave de su experiencia y por tanto de su creación artística. Azcona es conocido por abordar el dolor y la resistencia física, sometiéndose a azotamientos, intoxicaciones, agresiones y diferentes torturas tanto físicas como psicológicas y no duda en enfrentarse a sí mismo. Azcona cuenta que cuando el dolor interno es tan fuerte, el dolor externo llega a desaparecer. En el terreno crítico de su obra, Azcona aborda temas como el feminismo, la sexualidad, las desigualdades, la política o la religión buscando poner en evidencia estos temas en lasociedad.

Su obra ha sido presentada en diversos museos, centros de arte contemporáneo, galerías y espacios artísticos de países como España, Portugal, Francia, Italia, Dinamarca, Reino Unido, Alemania, Grecia, México, Colombia, Venezuela, Perú, Ecuador, Argentina, Estados Unidos, China, Filipinas y Japón.
El artista español Abel Azcona realizando un performance art en Bogotá (Colombia).

“En esta sociedad pasteuriza, prefiero provocar repugnancia, odio, rechazo, desconcierto, hartazgo, angustia, hostilidad, miedo... que seguir fomentando la asepsia mental.” Con estas palabras se peresenta Rocio Boliver, siguiente artista de nuestro cartel. Ícono de la cultura underground en la ciudad de México, nacida en la misma ciudad en el año de 1956, Rocío Boliver es una artista de performance que concentra su propuesta artística en la crítica a las cargas ideológicas represivas que viven las mujeres, principalmente en México. En 1992 inició su carrera de performance a partir de la lectura de sus textos de corte porno-erótico, desde entonces su obra se ha presentado en Festivales de Europa, Asia, Norte y Sudamérica. En los últmos siete años ha impartido talleres de performance en espacios culturales de Lisboa, Barcelona, Nueva York y Ciudad de México.
La artista mexicana Rocio Boliver ""La congelada de uva"" realizando un performance.

Desde Madrid contaremos con Yolanda Dommínguez, artísta visual licenciada en Bellas Artes por la  Universidad Complutense de Madrid.  Becada por el Ministerio de Cultura de España para la Promoción del Arte Español en el exterior (2010) ha presentado su trabajo en diferentes instituciones y festivales como Photoespaña 2012, JustMad Arte Contemporáneo, Contemporary Culture Festival NOVA in Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro y Barcelona, etc...Su labor artística trasciende al ámbito social y educacional, colaborando con distintas instituciones y organismos oficiales en programas de igualdad y género a través de talleres y conferencias y actualmente es profesora y tutora del Master Concepto y Creación de la Escuela de Fotografía EFTI de Madrid.

Trabaja desde la incomodidad manejando situaciones sensibles e inquietantes para el espectador con el objetivo de generar una crítica social y una reacción. Utilizando herramientas como la ironia o la descontextualización crea situaciones o escenarios en los que el espectador se ve involucrado y puede participar. Estas experiencias se insertan en contextos de la vida real con el objetivo de impactar emovional y mentalmente al espectador involucrando a este en la propuesta.
Performance Art "" Pido para un Chanel"" de Yolanda Dominguez en el centro de Madrid.

La siguente artista en nuestro cartel es Francesca Fini, trabaja la performance canalizandola a través de diferentes medios de comunicación como por ejemplo el video. Sus proyectos, siempre dirigidos a publicaciones sociales y politicas, son mezclados con la tecnología usando así por ejemplo audio en vivo. Muy interesada en la videoperformance tiende a crear desde su obra materia gráfico, lo que ella llama “relquias”.  Sus videos y trabajos tangibles los considera capñitulos de una historía interminable de la cua ella misma es la protagonista. Fini, con una educación profunda como artista digital  trabajó durante 15 años en el campo de la televisión, en el años 2000 después de conocer al artista americano Kristin Jones crearon juntos el proyecto “Tevereterno”, en el cual crearon instalaciones para la ciudad de Roma. Con él y otros artistas asistió en 2008 al Festival del Río en Nueva York proyectando su animación “el lazo de la luna”. Ha participado tamibién en la Bienal de Polonia en 2011, y ha sido finalista en los premios Laguna Internacional de Arte de Venecia así cmo en el Festival de cine de Montpellier.
La artista Francesca Fini realizando la performance "" Blind"" en la ciudad de Roma.
Continuamos con Regina José Galindo, nacida en Guatemala destaca por ser una poetisa que experimenta con nuevos escenarios fusionando la literatura con la performance.

Su trabajo se caracteriza por el contenido político que rescata elementos propios de su contexto cultural y de su condición femenina. Ganadora en 2005 del León de Oro en la bienal de Venecia por su video “Himenoplastia”, en el cual la artista es sometida a una intervención ilegal de reconstrucción de himen. Fue una propuesta sumamente fuerte y gracias a ella también se le otorgó años más tarde el Príncipe Claus. En su obra resalta la denuncia contra el sistema político, tan presente en la historia del arte latinoamericano, y un claro mensaje feminista.

Nadia Granados, artista colombiana interdisciplinar. Se dedica principalmente a la performance utilizando habitualmente la instalación. Su obra se caracteriza por la resignificacion de contenidos extraidos de los medios de comunicación mezclados con temas relacionados con la lucha antiglobalización.

Francesca Leoni, artista italiana, creció en Brasil. Graduada en Ciencias de la Comunicación en la Universidad de Carolina del Norte en Wilmington. Durante su época universitaria se involucro en el mundo del teatro. Al volver a Italia comenzó a trabajar en la producción de videos y siguió formandose en teatro y performance.

El artista belga Robin Pourbaix en un instante de una de sus performances.
