www.artots.com
meets all highest standard online security criteria.
about our team
My
name is Maciek Szymanski. I am Polish. I am 25. I have been involved
in community actions for over 5 years now. In 2010 I was engaged with
active support for people who suffered from flood and lost their
life's achievements. I have also been helping all people who are
affected by diseases and have difficulties finding proper medical
assistance. I want to change the surrounding reality with a little
help from good people. I am not a foundation. I do not wish to gather
money to give it to the disabled. I wish to create a tool that will
generate income for them and inspire them for big things, which can
change their life for good. I spent all my money for this project as
I believe that together we can reach this ambitious target. The
disabled artists have shared their work with www.artots.com
as their active participation in the project is what can make this
dream come true. It would not be possible without them. I would also
like to encourage all entrepreneurs, marketing agencies, IT
specialists, online auctions like e-bay to join our project. Any help
counts. Not only financial, although this is what we need to help
their being. Also a large Facebook community who will pass this
information to others makes a difference. If
you are an IT specialist, a marketing agency or you can simply help
in any technical aspect or wish to help us any other way, please
contact us.Any
symptom of support will be highly appreciated by the disabled
artists. Here are some of them:
Piotr, 35. Piotr has been paralyzed from waist down since he was a
kid. He does not work. He finds his motivation in art. He lives of
disability pension, which in his case is $271 whereas $150 is his
rent and utilities. Please note that this are Polish rates. We are
not downgrading it to make the situation even more dramatic. The same
applies to...
Anna, 47. She is also making the ends meet for $271 a month. She is a
blind artist and sculptress. “There are a lot places all over our
world where disabled people do not receive enough support. Let's
change it.” She says.
Mateusz, 71. He is moving on a wheelchair as a result of an accident.
He also finds his relief in art. Just like...
Maria, 34. She suffers from torso paralyze. She does not move her
arms, which does not stop her from painting with her mouth and feet.
“I would like to know that my art is appreciated by others. But
first they need to find out that this is what I do”. Let's help
people like Maria making this dream come true...
","...or
have you ever tried to imagine what red
color does look like? Have you ever wondered how difficult it must be
for someone who never has and never will see any color?
Hello everyone!
Thank you
for finding time to have a look at our campaign.
Let's start with some numbers:
650,000,000 - this is the approximate number of disabled
people living today
15% of them declares painting and sculpturing to be their
passion
100,000,000 is the number of active disabled artists, whose
works have never seen the daylight
Would you like to change it?
What is
our project about?
Artots is the name that comes from Art of the Soul. I have been
working with disabled people for few years now. Before that I was not
aware how important role in their life plays the art. For many of
them this is the only way to communicate with the world, others feel
appreciated and needed. We have to remember that their financial
position is sometimes very difficult. There are countries around our
world were disabled people do not receive as much support as they
need.  Artots wants to change it.
Our project is dedicated to all disabled
artists who want to manifest their talents and sometimes even just
presence. I have come to the conclusion that it is not enough to
organize a charity event where they can occasionally present and sell
their work. That helps only some of them without any regularity.
Artots online gallery is supposed to be the place where disabled
artists can display their work and sell it. They have proven to me
that there is no such term as “disabled” when it comes to art.
Let them prove it to the world as well! The main idea behind the
project is creating the possibility to gain finances for their
activity. Every one of them needs tools, sometimes especially
designed for their needs. If they are given an opportunity to
sell their work regularly, they will be given a chance to continue
their work and enjoy their lives, regardless numerous turbulence they
have to face on daily basis. Disabled athletes
have their Para Olympics. Let's create Art Gallery for disabled
artists as well!
What is
our aim?
It is very simple. www.artots.com
will be the place where they can publish their work
to the world. It does not matter whether
it is a painting, a sculpture or any other piece of art.
Regardless if the artists are using their mouth, feet or hands
to create, they will be capable of sharing their passions with
millions all around the world. This unique gallery will be the place
where they can also sell their work and earn money for further work
or medical treatment and physiotherapy -
Anything that can make their life better. Atrots
is a non-profit organization. Not a
single artist will be charged for displaying their work. All
money is kept by them. This is how we want to help. This is our way
of changing the world for better. At least one aspect of it.
Can you
help?
The money that we will gather will be spent on creating the fully
functioning online art gallery. So far we have created Beta Version
of our service, Facebook Application Beta Version and we also have
contacted the disabled artists and collected their work that will be
displayed and offered as our perks if you decide to help our project
become reality. Crowdfunding is the best method of
providing support for our ideas, moreover,
it makes people aware of the problem.
If you can not support us financially we encourage you to spread the
project using social media and tell as many people as possible about
it. Any form of support means a lot for our artists. Together we can
give them the chance to defeat many barriers that make their life
even more difficult.  Please note that this project
is not just a Christmas event that will finish in January. Although
we have chosen to start our campaign before Christmas to give you the
chance to use your perks as Christmas e-cards which you can send to
your family and friends, this is a long term plan which will help
change the life of many for better. The main reasons we gather money
for are:
the online service www.artots.com
the Facebook App http://artots.com/facebookapp
the marketing campaign
art tools for the artists
current expenses related to the gallery
functioning
As you can see, we need quite a lot of money to
make it all happen. The exact breakdown is done below.
What happens to the money?
Just have a look on how much is possible with your help!
This estimation is based on the
real cost of every aspect of our initiative.
We went for the Flexible Founding, here at Indiegogo. Every single
Dollar will be invested in our project. It depends on you guys how
much we can spend, how big percentage of our plan will be achieved.
So far we have spent our personal budget for the layout, Facebook
Application Beta Version and gathered the pieces of art from the
disabled artists. We still need to create the fully functioning
online service, Facebook Application final version and the mobile
Artots app. We need your help in order to make this all happen. The
artists need your help to make their lives better. Let's make future
worth waiting for all those who we can inspire! Let's appreciate
their efforts!
If we gather …
More than $125,000 we will complete the online service, the
Facebook App and the mobile version. The service will be available
in 23 languages. It will be supported by the worldwide marketing
campaign. Fully working and recognizable service will be operating
in December 2014 and the FB App will be available in February 2015.
More than $85,000
but less than the above, we will complete the online service, the
Facebook App and the mobile version. The service will be available
in 23 languages. It will be done the same time as above.
More than $55,000
but less than the above, we will complete the online service and the
mobile version. The service will be available in 23 languages. It
will be done the same time as above.
More than $45,000 but
less than the above, we will complete the online service available
in 23 languages. It will be done in November 2014.
More than $40,000
but less than the above, we will complete the online service
available in English, German, French, Spanish and Polish. This money
will cover the cost of creating and running it.
Less than
$40,000, we will provide
art tools such as paint, paper, brushes, easels designed for
disabled people and everything else, that such artist may require in
order to create. This money will be enough to help 1000 artists. The
due date for the dispatch of all goods is April 2014. Please note,
that any extra money we have left, regardless the final amount, will
also be donated for such cause. Let's help as much as we can!
What do you support?
Fully
functional online gallery creation. It will be located at
www.artots.com and
it will be a very special place where disabled people can display
and sell their art.
Facebook Application. Such application will be available to everyone
who wants to display their paintings in Facebook. You
will be able to share the paintings with all your friends in
Facebook. Here is what it will look like: http://artots.com/facebookapp
3) Worldwide marketing campaign to make people aware of the new
chance that has appeared. All disabled artists will be capable of
presenting their art. If they only want, there will be no borders
nor limits in their Art of the Soul promotion.
What will it work like?
We have many ideas about the way we would like the gallery to
operate. Here they are:
Paintings will be available in electronic or traditional version.
You can request any that you like to be done by the chosen artist
with the chosen method. You can even request a painting to be done
for your individual request. All electronic replicas will be
available as .jpg files ready to put into the FB app, wallpapers,
screensavers, e-cards, posters, paper and canvas replicas or
original issues. Any .jpg image will be fully convertible to other
formats so that transferring it to canvas was easy and manageable.
All paintings come from limited collection. They are not an effect
of any sort of mass production.
Sculptures will be sold in their original form or made to order by
the chosen artist.
All people who decide to support us
financially will receive the unique code for their paintings as well
as for their Certificate of the 21st
Century Artots Patron of Art. Using your personal code you will be
able to take part in discussion forums that will decide over the
further Artots development. You will receive such authority by
becoming Artots co-founder.
Everybody is the
winner!
Here, at Artots we believe that every person involved in our activity
is the winner. From the very beginning they make a contribution into
making this project successful. Here is the benefit breakdown:
FAQ:What are your perks?Perks are the paintings.
How long does it take to receive my perk?
All perks 1 – 9 will be  delivered within 1 to 5 days. We will not
be waiting for the campaign to finish. You will receive a link which
will take you to the download section instantly.
Delivering perks 9 – 12 takes longer as they are not
„manufactured”. These are the effect of a disabled artist's
handwork. After you have decided to get one of them, we will notify
you via email about it expected time of delivery.  Please note, the
artist whose picture you have chosen will put a lot of effort to
make this work a real masterpiece so that you could enjoy not only
the picture itself, but the fact you have supported someone just as
gifted as life experienced.
What is the Certificate and how to become Artots Patron of Art?
Every
co-founder, regardless the perk value receives Artots
Patron of Art Certificate. Artots Patron of Art,who
we also call The 21st
Century Patron of Art, is any person of good will who decides to
contribute into our idea implementation. Such person has proven
their concern for the disabled artists fate and wants to help them
create a place where they could enjoy their lives the way they
appreciate it the most. All of you can become the Artots Patron of
Art.
What is the unique code?It
is the unique number for every single Artots co-founder. Each
picture, certificate or card has been given this unrepeatable
number. You can be certain that each image you have received is
unique, original and it will last forever in the history of modern
art. On top of that the number will also allow for expressing
yourself in special co-founders' forum which has been designed so
that all of us could decide over www.artots.com
development's path.
How do you know which perk I want and how I want it to be made?
It
is simple! All details of the chosen perk will have to be specified
in an email sent to: info@artots.com
Here are few examples of possible options:*
After
choosing your perk you need to email us with the perk's ID which you
can find at www.artots.com
and tell us the email address you want to have it sent to.
* Also if it is a paper or canvas replica you will have to tell us
the exact address for the delivery.
* If you choose an e-card you need to tell us which one it was.
* If you choose the wishes from our gallery you will have to tell us
the wishes number.
* If you want to have your own wishes on the card, please email them
to us and we will place it on your card.
How much are the shipment costs and where do you deliver?
No matter where you are from, we will deliver your perk without any
extra charges. We fully appreciate your support to our action,
therefore, we do not see any reason to charge you extra for the act
of good will.
Limited collection paintings. Where do they come from?
Those
paintings come directly from the disabled artists. It was their
input into www.artots.com
development.
Which electronic format my paintings will be delivered in?
It
will be .jpg format ready to place your picture in your FB gallery.
What is more, if we gather $85,000 we will create special FB
application which will allow for convenient management of your own
21st century FB art gallery. You
will receive a link which will help you download the package with
your paintings, cards and the certificate. It will be delivered to
your email address.
In
case of any further questions we will be happy to answer them asap
via email.You
may also look for further info on our web site www.artots.com
and follow us on Facebook. In case of any doubts, please do not
hesitate and write to us on info@artots.com

","Hi! I'm Jasmine Greene, born and raised in Detroit, MI. I moved to NYC to continue to pursue my journey with Christ. I am I received a call back to attend the AMTC SHINE Conference, which is a talent conference presented by Actors, Models and Talent for Christ. AMTC is non-profit, 501(3) Christian ministry that has been in business for over 30 years. They have helped launched thousands of careers. I am trying to raise money to continue my training and help pay for my trip. I'm extremely excited God has opened this door for me! Being an actor and model for Christ is a gift
column14: a gift I treasure and will multiply to His honor. I will get seen by agents from all over the world. This opportunity to attend the SHINE conference not only catapults my career as a Model and Actor, but it allots me the opportunity to be a light for Jesus in the entertainment industry. Because of your contribution, I will be able to receive industry specific online training, modeling and acting workshops/seminars taught by top level modeling coaches and directors, professional photo shoot, and perform at the AMTC SHINE Conference.

Who We Are
We
are a group of 18 young designers in the Class
of 2015 in the College of Fine Arts at the University of Texas - Austin. We have dedicated one of our design classes
this semester to creating this publication which showcases 18 unique
perspectives of different cultures within Austin. We have spent the last two
years together, honing our design skills and becoming a tight-knit group that
strives to learn from each other. We have a wide variety of design interests
but our collaboration has brought us closer together and allowed us to create
something unique that would have been impossible to do on our own. We hope to
share this publication throughout Austin and beyond as a way of showcasing our
individual work, and more importantly the city we love.
512stew
512stew is a book showcasing 18 unique
perspectives of different cultures within Austin. In the past there  have been songs, movies, and photographs inspired
by the city. But as young designers who live and breathe Austin we had the
opportunity to delve deeper than the surface – we had the opportunity to have intimate
one-on-one experiences and show Austin’s wonderfully diverse nature. Austin’s
diversity is reflected in the book itself as we all developed our own unique
understanding of these different cultures, as well as our own styles – we have
everything – from video to photography, paintings to graphic design
Through
exploring individual definitions of “culture” in Austin we are showcasing
Austin and honing our design skills. We are hoping to celebrate Austin in a way
that is unlike a typical publication, as our 18 perspectives will provide you
with an in-depth and unique view of this wonderful city.
The book is divided into sections of 12-20 pages dedicated each designer. Below are examples of some of the page spreads:
Amanda Czarnik— Religion is…
<div>
Edward Rendon— Sync
Mimi Richardson—Brew
Laura Levisay—Dog Blog
Daniel Shipley—Austin by Perspectives
Gabriela Velez—Figure 1
Sarah Micheletti— Red State, Blue City

column2: >Each section will have a unique introduction page which includes ""keyword ingredients"" for their stew:

column1: <h2>What We Need &amp
All
of the money raised goes purely into printing and shipping. Each perk’s
donation quantity has taken into account the cost of producing the items that
you will receive. Our goal is to get 512stew distributed across the country and
not making a profit on the physical printing and distribution of the book will
allow our book to reach a larger audience.
Any
money raised from donations of $20 or less or more than $250 will go towards
printing and circulating our publication throughout the faculty as a way to
give back to UT Austin. Ideally, we would continue on to distributing the book
throughout Austin. Depending on the nature of donations, we could be able to
publish 80 books to distribute throughout Austin if our goal of $5,000 is met.
However, if we do not meet our goal, we will merely distribute less books.
While
not everyone can contribute financially, everyone can help by getting the word
out! Share on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, anything you can think of, every
little helps!
If you want to find out more about us and about our book, please visit www.512stew.com

throughout Austin. Depending on the nature of donations, we could be able to
publish 80 books to distribute throughout Austin if our goal of $5,000 is met.
However, if we do not meet our goal, we will merely distribute less books.
While
not everyone can contribute financially, everyone can help by getting the word
out! Share on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, anything you can think of, every
little helps!
If you want to find out more about us and about our book, please visit www.512stew.com",11.0,0,"1 Campaign

Hello! This is our first campaign, so we're lowballing a bit, and being personal is my personal  forte I suppose. If you want to understand us, then we're on the right site.

Hi, my >
column6: Lotus Vine. We've been friends for several years and room together in a smallish apartment
column7:
I found living on my own wasn't as easy as I'd hoped. During this time, we started developing stories together, just random little things, no big deal. Lotus designs her own costumes and clothes and cosplays original characters that are amazingly real-feeling because of the time and thought she put into each of them to make them each unique, and she's lamented about not having the space for the right equipment to really shine. I've gotten by easier: I'm an artist. I literally need a table and a pencil and I'm good to go. So in our limited space, between rearranging everything to make way for two artsy people, I began drawing her characters or seeing drawings from others of them and she fell in love with my art style and started bragging to some friends. I was tempted to dabble in being a commission artist for conventions, but had no idea where to start, and as much as everyone has said yes, I don't want to be just commission work, and she doesn't want to be just another one making small tails and paws for people in a hall full of them.

Maybe we have big aspirations, but when we started doing a gag comic based on a roleplay we did with some friends, it ended up flowing very smoothly
column8:
it doesn't have many fans yet and we didn't want to leak the personal information present in the text, so we cancelled it prematurely as an art demo. Then we started playing again. For whatever reason, we sat down and wondered to ourselves ""If we could make our own, completely original Pokémon region to pitch to Nintendo, what would it be?"" Now, that's not to say we're asking for bribe money here! Not even close! While we developed a theme and the Pokémon, they came alive, much more than we'd ever intended. I began purchasing (expensive) markers to color with and she started playing with resin casting and needle felting models of them just for fun.

Five months passed, working almost every day. We were making something. Her costumes stopped, and my original comics ceased, while this took over everything we had time for. When it became clear this could be a legitimate thing, we sought advice from some friends who thought the concept would be great as a Pokémon game, bus as neither of us work for Nintendo and they supposedly have enough on their plates to deal with, we took off on the principal that, though Pokémon is trademarked, the concept of ""find creature, catch creature, fight with creature"" isn't so we launched into the way of changing this Pokémon spin off into our own story, our own idea. Yes, it'll look a lot like Pokémon, I'll say that now, but what we really want to get across is the message and story, not the principal it's based on.

We needed a name to work under. Clever Fox Studios and Lotus Vine Creations, both still-dead pages buried on DeviantArt, needed to come together to ensure proper rights for what we were doing. We had a lot of projects together, a lot of possibility. But how? I always enjoy drawing unique characters more than pre-existing ones because it's less pressure to be correct
column9:
she has the same mentality for OC costume. No one can say you're wrong, which is a huge relief on its own. By pitching back and forth on the principals of storyboard, character and design, how to not Godmode and stay interesting, we came up with ""Original Character Concept Creations"" then Lotus blurted out (it was in reference to herself since she is 85% of the think-tank between us, I just use pretty colors) ""I am O-C-C-C, I'm OC^3 (cubed)!"" and we grabbed that and made it our joint title. It stuck, it worked... now what? We could put ""Insert Title Here"", our RP comic, under it since we both worked on it, then we started posting our Fakemon designs. People like them well enough, but now that we're running them under than banner ""Crystal Capture Creatures"" or ""C-Cube"" as the flagship of our business, we realize we need money in order to have time.

So much happens in life, let me tell you. Between rent, a car accident, Lotus needing corrective eye surgery and both of us working the same bleh job (anyone who knows the feels, raise your hand) and so much emotional duress, we barely have time to eat and sleep. We want--no, NEED--out. We want to work for ourseves, to bring our stories to life, to be known for our skills and love of creating, not our customer service. Again, we're lowballing at 5k just to see if we're considered a worthy cause, but the idea of being able to make a living doing what we want is a dream everyone has the right to pursue, right? If you need further convincing, please check out our referred DeviantArt pages under Clever Fox Studios or Lotus Vine Creations to see our baby slowly hatching.

Anyone that draws knows it's time-consuming and messy, and anyone that costumes knows that's even more so. Our jobs (health problems related to work stress aside) don't pay enough to be able to shift focus to a new business alone. We need supplies and the money to make time, and anything helps. Printers, markers, lead, paper, fabric, felt, wool, needles, resin and TIME--we need it, and in exchange we want to hopefully entertain you donors, patrons and future-fans, by bringing something fun, exciting and meaningful to the world. Though not every project we make will be piloted under the banner of OC^3, everything we gather will be put toward gathering the supplies we need to get the gravy train rolling as we slowly try to transfer to being full- or mostly-time artists. That's why everything counts, even if it's just publicity. Anything, really. Likes, favorites, a dollar, a mention to someone that likes Pokémon, Digimon or Yokai Watch. We want to do this.

Hit up Lotus for costumes, ideas, stories or encouragement. Hit me up for prints and commissions. Anything given will go into the OC^3 pool and used to further OC^3 and ""C-Cube"". Later on, maybe individual projects under Lotus Vine and Clever Fox? We'll even give a list at the end of projects both of us are working on or potential ideas for anyone reading this. If you think this is a cry for help, you're half right, but I can promise I'm not exaggerating.

We'll be hitting up conventions in our area as well, hopefully starting this year and every year after, so if you want a personal look I'll be at Anime NebrasCon 2016, hopefully at my own booth with another friend, piloting Clever Fox and OC^3 art. Next year we'll be shooting for an actual OC^3 booth for both of us. If you want to start picking favorites, the first rounds of color beta images are on our DeviantArt pages, and the first comic will be out in the next few weeks.

UPDATE05/24/2016: We've decided that the creature will be called creastals (creatures+crystals) (KREE-stahlz) and that our equivalent to ""shiny"" will be ""mirage"". Also, today or tomorrow Lotus will begin working on some plushie concecpts, look forward to those updates!

Future ideas under the Lotus Vine Creations logo:

Lotus does tails for costume pieces, hand sewn.

She also designs for OCs.

She also wants to dable in the art of fursuiting, but this plays into the ""we need time, space and money"" issue as stated previously.

Future projects under the Clever Fox Studios logo:

""Phoenix Heart"", the story of a young harpy princess that dreams of being a warrior and coming-of-age in a foreign world.

""DragonStory"", a young woman kidnapped from Earth to help a small band of magical creatures over throw the human population that threatens their world and the discovery of her heritage and power.

""Arcana Demonata"", a love story for the ages, a pair incarnated again and again to defend against demons and monsters while uncovering a prophecy that changes everything they knew about their world.

Projects under OCCubed's logo:

""C-Cube: Crystal Capture Creatures"", for anyone that knows and loves Pokémon, Digimon and Yokai Watch, another adventure into a world of powerful beasts and their human friends and the true nature of their world.

If any of these seem at all interesting, please look forward to them by helping us reach our goals! Thank you so very much!!

What do you see when you look at that picture? Do you see an artist at work? Because that's what we see and we want all artists to continue working and creating and bringing their visions to you, wherever you live. We're not just raising money for this one artist. We're raising money for a group of artists. Working artists that want to continue creating beautiful things for you to enjoy, need your support in order to get their work into the public eye.

We
only need $2,000 to build the foundation for our nest egg. From that we
can fund several artists at a time so they can participate in their
communities. Each donation you make, no matter how small, or how large

will put us closer to adding art to your community, or one nearby.

How Will Your Contribution Impact the Art Community?
Think
for a moment what your world would be like without the beauty of art.
Art broadens the mind and stretches the limbs beyond possibilities to
the impossibilities. Art offers the opportunity to think on a different plane
and to consider new ideas that might not occur to you otherwise.
Thought provoking, stimulating and beautiful. A community without art
may never live up to, or even come close to it's potential.
column2:
>

Our Story

Welcome to Donors for Art! We got started on this campaign in a most unusual way. It didn't start out as a project, but with time and understanding, it became one. We hope it will become something you'll get behind and support because we need people just like you!

A group of friends got together and created Open Call Group on Facebook after realizing there were enough open calls for artists to support an entire group. Elizabeth Musgrove Hanlin designed the group as a place to share open calls for artwork submissions, all in one place, so that artists looking for a gallery, a show or an installation venue to show their work, could apply for the openings, across the country, suited to their art medium. Each one of the original members added their own friends that they knew produced art in some form. Then those friends added their friends. To date, we have 67 members in all mediums of the art world, from sculpture to music, and it's still growing.

Open calls come from all over. It could be a community looking for beautification or a gallery with open space available. They put out open calls asking for participants to submit their work for the open space. Thousands of artists answer these calls everyday. Submission usually requires an application that gives the artist's background and details and a way for the artist to show what they have to offer. Most open calls for artists also have a fee attached to them. It's usually between $20 to $70 to cover administrative costs to the art venue. Many art venues are 501c3, non-profit organizations, so this fee is a necessary part of their world and it's what assists them in bringing new and interesting art to your town and community.

When we began posting open calls with fees, the feedback we received from the artists was to find more open calls that were free submissions because the cost of the fees was not always in their budgets. Unfortunately, not many of those exist. So how do we continue to submit art to venues when our artists can't afford the fees?

The answer is a simple one. We raise the money to pay the fees and increase your awareness of the importance  of supporting our cause for the health, well being, beautification and benefit of your community.

Art is life.

Here are some examples of the projects available that
column3: >our group of artists would like to submit work for:
column4:
>Strengthening Civil Society Through Arts and Culture

The Arts and Culture Program works at the nexus of arts, culture,

column1: human  rights, and social advocacy. Through its grants, the program
strives to  encourage broad-based critical reflection and catalyze
social action in  parts of the world where open societies are absent or
weak, and where the cultural rights of minority groups are endangered.
In particular, the program provides grants to strengthen alternative
and autonomous cultural infrastructures and innovative arts initiatives
in Central Asia, the Caucasus, Afghanistan, Moldova, Mongolia, and
Turkey.
Piedmont Triad Film Commission invites videographers and filmmakers to
submit 30-second video shorts that inspire location managers, producers
and directors to film their next production in our region. The contest
winner will be awarded a $5,000 contract to produce a three-minute
version of the video which will be posted on the Film Commissionï¿½s
website and sent to film professionals. Contest entrants must be
residents of the 12-county Piedmont Triad region.
Palo Alto Public Art Commission is seeking qualifications for artists
or artist teams to create artwork(s) at the Main Library and the Art
Center. The combined budget will be between $130,000 and $150,000 and is
intended to commission artwork(s) that will foster a more cohesive flow
to the combined campuses while reflecting the history and programming

of these sites.


These are just a few of the thousands of venues calling for artist submissions worldwide. Your contribution could be the beginning of a budding, productive career.
column2: >Our team members for this campaign are:
column4:
>Elizabeth Musgrove Hanlin, Team Member

Elizabeth's experience in the banking community gives our team the necessary reality check when it comes to distribution of funding. She will assist us in maintaining a standard of quality with checks and balances along the way to ensure our funding nest egg stays viable.
column6:
>Katy Shultz, Team Member
Katy has a BA in Fine Arts and spends her time looking for the beauty in life around her. Her keen organizational skills and attention to detail give her the ability to manage large scale art projects and installations with professionalism and panache.
column7: >Katy has worked in the motion picture industry as a coordinator for the art department, including construction, set dressing and props. She is the Principal for Papillon Fine Art and an avid collector.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us by spreading the word using social networking like Facebook and Twitter. Consider sending this link to your friends and family in an email asking them to donate too. Your kindness and your support are greatly appreciated. Thank you for checking us out.

P21 Gallery presents 'Autonomy of Self', a publicly funded group exhibition bringing together film and photography from across the former Ottoman territories to explore how individuals are using the human image to refuse violence and conflict.
""For political oppositions, democratic representation merges with
visual representation. For people, possessing political agency means

possessing the ability to be seen, not only heard""

- Lina Khatib, Image Politics in the Middle East

Opening April 16th 2015

P21 Gallery, London, Kings Cross
column3:
/>



The Concept

Autonomy of Self unites individuals contending with conflicts across Eastern Europe, the Middle East and North Africa in their shared history through the Ottoman Empire. Conflicts in Bosnia, Crimea, Armenia, Lebanon, Palestine, Iraq, Egypt and Tunisia are considered in the artworks. Each has faced the consequences of the collapse of the Empire and the destruction of interventions from the UK, US, France and Russia, and the implications of these actions resonate in the identity of these countries today.

The exhibition is inspired by, and a response to the writings of theorist Ariella Azoulay.


The Artists

column1: Joy Stacey (Image from 'The Tourist')
<div>
Joy Stacey is the curator behind Autonomy of Self, and
the exhibition concept was developed as a progression
from her work developed in Palestine
Stacey is an artist and curator based in the
UK, with a Masters in Photography from the University
of Brighton.
Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari (Image from 'Tracing Back')
<div>
Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari is the descendant of Armenian refugees and was born in Greece.
She is an MA Photography graduate from Central Saint Martins, currently studying for a Research
Degree (PhD). Her research focuses upon photographic archives and their relation to memory and
identity, specifically in relation to her family and the Armenian Genocide.
Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige (Image from 'Khiam')
<div>
Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige collaborate as filmmakers and artists, producing cinematic
and visual artwork that intertwine. For the last 15 years, they have focused on the images,
representations and history of their home country, Lebanon and questioned the fabrication of
imaginaries in the region and beyond. Their artworks have been shown in museums, biennials and
art centres around the world, in solo or collective exhibitions, and are part of important public and
private collections. The artists live between Beirut and Paris.
Sadik Kwaish Alfraji (Image from 'Born April 9th')
<div>
Sadik Kwaish Alfraji was born in Baghdad and is based in the Netherlands. He is a visual artist,
print maker and designer, and studied art and philosophy. He has exhibited internationally and his
work is held in collections across the world.
<div>
Moufida Fedhila (Image from 'Super Tunisian')
<div>
Moufida Fedhila was born in Tunisia and Lives and works in Paris and Tunis. Fedhila graduated
from the École Européenne Supérieure d'Art de Bretagne, and studied philosophy at the Sorbonne
University and theatre at the University of Caen before moving to Paris to be trained in film
directing. She practices drawing, painting, cinema, photography, poetry as sound, installation and
performance.
Nadia Mounir (Image from 'Soutk' [Your Vote] )
<div>
Nadia Mounir is an emerging lens-based artist living and working in Cairo. Her work explores the
Egyptian uprising and the impact of it as it unfolds.
Femen (press image, ©Getty Images)
<div>
Femen is a controversial feminist protest group founded in Ukraine in 2008. The organization has
become internationally known for organizing topless protests against sex tourism, religious
institutions, sexism and other social, national and international topics. The organisation describes
itself as ""fighting patriarchy in its three manifestations - sexual exploitation of women, dictatorship
and religion”.

Aims and Goals

This exhibition aims to encourage and
promote knowledge and debate on several levels. Visitors will be invited
to consider the major themes running through these works, such as the
significance and legacy of the Ottoman Empire and colonialism, the
intricacies and history of contemporary conflicts, responses to all

types of violence, and the strength of the voices of those facing it. 

Autonomy
of Self seeks to encourage understanding of the power of those deemed
powerless, and to encourage knowledge and debate around the political
and visual representation of those facing the consequences of global

politics. 

The show calls for the audience to revaluate
understanding of human rights by exploring how individuals are

responding to a lack of them, caused by their state or statelessness. It also draws attention to how the lens operates as a democratic tool.

All the artworks will be documented and the
events will be recorded so that as much as possible of Autonomy of Self

will be made available online.



What We Need and What You Will Get

We are fundraising for the production costs of the exhibition and we need your generous
donations to help us carry out this exceedingly important exhibition. There are a multitude of exciting rewards that we have put together for

you, and any funds we make beyond our target will go towards our Public Events Programme. (Read more about these events at the bottom of the page).

Your kind donations will be spent as follows:

Printing Costs - £2,700

Wall building (1 sculpture and 4 video instalations, construction, panel hire and removal)- £4,000

Website design - £600

Video Production - £500

Shipping - £100

Lighting - £350

Transport - £300

Audio Visual support - £1,000

Paint, nails and related supplies - £500

Vinyls for wall captions and front windows - £700

Translation - £250

Total - £11,000


Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Our challenge is to raise the full funds in time for the opening on October the 23rd. We are applying for a variety of grants, funds and donations, and P21 Gallery has a strong track record of success doing so. In the extremely unlikely event of funds not being raised in time, the exhibition will simply be rescheduled, and your funds will not go to waste.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help us achieve our goal in other ways then please share our fund on social media!

exhibition, and seeking support in all varieties be they in media promotion, partnership,
collaboration or assistance with funding.

If we exceed our goal...

If we raise more than our target then the money will go to producing our programme of public events!


Public Events
<div>
Throughout the 7-week exhibition, a series of corresponding public events will be carried out to
encourage a wider audience, and academic and public debate around the issues discussed in the
show. This is under development and the following
have been confirmed:
Exploring Armenia, with Louis de Bernieres, Nouritza Matossian and Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari
<div>

column7:
/>
 

Louis de Bernieres is an internationally acclaimed best-selling author, best known for his novel

column1: Captain Corelli’s Mandolin. In 2004 he published his ‘magnum opus’ (-British Library), Birds
Without Wings, which explores the impact of war through the eyes of a small Turkish town during
the collapse of the Ottoman Empire. De Bernieres will read an extract from this novel in which he
explores the rounding up and removal of the Armenian community through the eyes of his
characters.
Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari is exhibiting her artworks on the Armenian genocide and exodus
within the exhibition, and will lead the conversation
with de Bernieres to explore his writing and the recording and accounting of memory associated
with the genocide.
The event will then be open to a Q&
column2: A, and followed by acclaimed writer and director of the Armenian Institute Nouritza Matossian, who will present her film 'Heart of Two Nations: Hrant Dink'. The film records conversations between herself and journalist Hrant Dink who was assassinated in Turkey in 2007.

column1: Screening of '1395 Days Without Red' by Šejla Kamerić, courtesy of Artangel

column2:
>


An elegant young woman makes her way through an empty city. At every crossing she stops, looks and listens. Should she wait or should she run? Should she wait for others or take the risk on her own?

The city is Sarajevo, and the route the woman takes became known as Sniper Alley during the siege of the city endured by its citizens for 1395 days between 1992 and 1996. The woman, played by Spanish actress Maribel Verdú, is reliving the experience of the trauma of the siege. It is her individual journey through the collective memory of the city.

The Siege of Sarajevo lasted for 1395 days. The citizens were bright colours, for fear of alerting their movements to the snipers watching from the hills above.

column1: Memories of
Lebanon and Tunisia: Transformed Cities and the Family Album, with Leslie Hakim-Dowek (Plymouth University) and Dora Carpenter-Latiri (University of Brighton)
Leslie Hakim-Dowek was born in Beirut and immigrated to
Britain at the beginning of the Lebanese Civil war. She trained at Camberwell
School of Art in Fine Art and at the Slade School of Art (Fine Art/Painting). Her
work is now mainly lens-based and sometimes combined with text and oral history
methods. Hakim-Dowek is a senior lecturer at the University of Portsmouth and a
member of Ottoman Cosmopolitanism research group.
Dr Dora
Carpenter-Latiri was born in Tunisia and has lived and studied in Paris. A
photographer and researcher, she has a wide knowledge of the Arab world, with
periods in Sudan, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia. She began teaching at the
University of Tunis in 1994 and moved to the University of Brighton in 1997,
where her experience in North Africa led her to research in the interface
between France and the Maghreb. Her publications deal with language and
intercultural issues, migration, representations of minorities in film and
literary productions, memory and first person narratives, and she is a member of
Understanding Conflict research cluster.
Symposium with International New Media Gallery
<div>
Founded in 2012, the International New Media Gallery (INMG) is an internet-based museum
showcasing the latest moving image, photography, and digital art. Recent exhibitions have
included acclaimed artists such as Thomson &amp
column2: Craighead, Ursula Biemann, and Amy Balkin. The

column1: INMG’s aims are to expand and increase art audiences, evolve the nature of gallery going, and
explore the latest art historical debates, and is founded and run by young emerging academics.
INMG are developing a symposium to correspond with the artworks and themes of the exhibition.
The Gallery
column2:
>


The P21 Gallery is an independent

column1: London-based non-profit organisation established to promote
contemporary
Middle Eastern and Arab art and culture. The two-story venue in central
London has been identities recently designed by the award winning
Egyptian
architect, Professor Abdul Halim Ibrahim, as a place where contemporary
artistic statements are experienced and appreciated by a global artistic
community. The facilities at P21 are planned to maximise the potential
of contemporary art as a discourse, through multimedia exhibition spaces
on
two levels with supporting facilities for public functions in addition
to workshops for training and education. In addition, the P21 Gallery
hosts
a reference library, meeting rooms, a lecture hall as well as a
specialised café. In short, it provides for a much needed meeting place
in the heart
of London.

","P21 Gallery presents 'Autonomy of Self', a publicly funded group exhibition bringing together film and photography from across the former Ottoman territories to explore how individuals are using the human image to refuse violence and conflict.
For political oppositions, democratic representation merges with
visual representation. For people, possessing political agency means
possessing the ability to be seen, not only heard""- Lina Khatib, Image Politics in the Middle East

Opening April 16th 2015P21 Gallery, London, Kings Cross                                      The ConceptAutonomy of Self unites individuals contending with conflicts across Eastern Europe, the Middle East and North Africa in their shared history through the Ottoman Empire. Conflicts in Bosnia, Crimea, Armenia, Lebanon, Palestine, Iraq, Egypt and Tunisia are considered in the artworks. Each has faced the consequences of the collapse of the Empire and the destruction of interventions from the UK, US, France and Russia, and the implications of these actions resonate in the identity of these countries today. The exhibition is inspired by, and a response to the writings of theorist Ariella Azoulay.The Artists
Joy Stacey (Image from 'The Tourist')
Joy Stacey is the curator behind Autonomy of Self, and
the exhibition concept was developed as a progression
from her work developed in Palestine
Stacey is an artist and curator based in the
UK, with a Masters in Photography from the University
of Brighton.
Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari (Image from 'Tracing Back')
Armenoui Kasparian Saraidari is the descendant of Armenian refugees and was born in Greece.
She is an MA Photography graduate from Central Saint Martins, currently studying for a Research
Degree (PhD). Her research focuses upon photographic archives and their relation to memory and
identity, specifically in relation to her family and the Armenian Genocide.
Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige (Image from 'Khiam')
Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige collaborate as filmmakers and artists, producing cinematic
and visual artwork that intertwine. For the last 15 years, they have focused on the images,
representations and history of their home country, Lebanon and questioned the fabrication of
imaginaries in the region and beyond. Their artworks have been shown in museums, biennials and
art centres around the world, in solo or collective exhibitions, and are part of important public and
private collections. The artists live between Beirut and Paris.
Sadik Kwaish Alfraji (Image from 'Born April 9th')
Sadik Kwaish Alfraji was born in Baghdad and is based in the Netherlands. He is a visual artist,
print maker and designer, and studied art and philosophy. He has exhibited internationally and his
work is held in collections across the world.
Moufida Fedhila (Image from 'Super Tunisian')
Moufida Fedhila was born in Tunisia and Lives and works in Paris and Tunis. Fedhila graduated
from the École Européenne Supérieure d'Art de Bretagne, and studied philosophy at the Sorbonne
University and theatre at the University of Caen before moving to Paris to be trained in film
directing. She practices drawing, painting, cinema, photography, poetry as sound, installation and
performance.
Nadia Mounir (Image from 'Soutk' [Your Vote] )
Nadia Mounir is an emerging lens-based artist living and working in Cairo. Her work explores the
Egyptian uprising and the impact of it as it unfolds.
Femen (press image, ©Getty Images)
Femen is a controversial feminist protest group founded in Ukraine in 2008. The organization has
become internationally known for organizing topless protests against sex tourism, religious
institutions, sexism and other social, national and international topics. The organisation describes
itself as ""fighting patriarchy in its three manifestations - sexual exploitation of women, dictatorship
and religion”.

Short Summary
<div>

ON THE WALL will be Kingston's first street art festival! From August 18-23 2014 we will be celebrating visual artists, graffiti artists, musicians, performers and the community of the neighbourhood of Douglas Fluhrer Park.
The festival is being organized by a small team of volunteers, including artists, members of Friends of the Inner Harbour, art advocates, educators and community activists.

ON THE WALL will feature 21 graffiti murals. These will be painted during the week of August 18-23. On Saturday August 23rd we will hold an Artist Celebration Day. From 3-8pm the park will be host to numerous participatory musical and performance acts, including Salsa dancing, contemporary 'flocking' dance, 3 drumming circles, acoustic musical performances, belly dancing, b-boying, fruit carving, kids circles and more.
What We Need &
<div>
We need your support to help us raise $6000 that will go towards covering the expenses of the Artist Celebration Day on August 23rd.
Your donations will go towards: honorariums for performers, stage, chairs, tables, and a solar powered sound system.

With the donations we would like to recognize the contributions that artists make to our society. If we surpass our goal of $6000, it would allow us to increase the artists honorariums. With 40 artists currently scheduled to perform on August 23rd, even with a $6000 goal they would be coming away with very modest compensations.

With a donation of $25-$99 you will receive one of the t-shirts shown below (to be picked up at the event), one sporting the branding design for this years festival and the other bearing a special indigogo design.
t-shirt 1
t-shirt 2

With a donation of $100 and over you will receive one of the two t-shirts, your name will be announced at the Artist Celebration Ceremony, your name or logo will be printed on a large poster which will hold the map of the Park with the layout of the day's events, AND your contribution will also be acknowledged in the Kingston Whig Standard.

When you claim your perks please leave us 1)your name, 2) your size and 3)a note about which t-shirt you prefer. If you're sponsoring the event and would like your name announced and logo printed on map, please leave us a note about that and email the specs to inverarymary@yahoo.com by Thursday August 21.
T-shirts will be available for pick up at the event on August 23rd between 3-8pm.
The Impact
<div>

This street art festival will be the first of a kind here in Kingston. It's no small matter that due to the efforts of several community members our City Council has lifted its ban on graffiti to allow us to hold this festival.

Street art and urban art is a new type of expression for Kingston. It does happen, but its relegated to rooftops and hard to reach places, its often rushed and gets painted over, as the landlords have to conform to anti-graffiti laws.

Due to the tough restrictions on graffiti, local artists and local street artists have very limited spaces to practice this vibrant and striking art form. As a result Kingstonians have not been exposed to the type of urban art that can flourish under supportive conditions.

This festival will be able to reveal the street art aesthetic and the artistic abilities that currently do not have an outlet. We will be able to support our youth, the lovers of graphic arts, and the numerous musicians and performers who will come out to support and celebrate the spirit of urban street art. The Artist Celebration Day is an integral component to the festival, for during that day we will be able to 'toast' to the success of this very first street art festival and enjoy the variety of art forms that Kingston artists have to offer.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

One of the biggest challenges of this festival has already been overcome - that of lifting the graffiti ban for the duration of the festival.

column1: The other challenge, of raising modest honorariums for the visual/graffiti artists, is currently addressed by personal sponsorship solicitations by members of the organizing team. These honorariums, though again very modest, seem presently attainable.

The biggest challenge currently is that of being able to offer some form of compensation to the musicians and performers and to provide them with the tools necessary to perform in the park, such as a stage and a power supply.
We would also really like to secure a solar powered sound system, or some other form of green energy for the event, the logistics of which is currently being worked out.
Other Ways You Can Help
<div>

If you can't pitch in, you can always help out by sharing this indigogo campaign on your Facebook, social media and email. The more people hear about this event the better are our chances of reaching our goal. It also helps us get the word out about what's in store. Hope to see you August 23rd!
Contact us through inverarymary@yahoo.com for charitable receipts.

About the Installation

Bonnie Crawford Kotula’s studio practice is part science experiment, part meditation, and part mischief. Employing both cerebral and sensual faculties, she makes sculptures and installations that combine tiny LED lighting with simple materials like brightly colored trash and cheap craft supplies. or if there be flooding serves as an imagined response plan to a potential catastrophe. The title of this piece is a fragment from Advice to a Wife and Mother, published in 1878. Flooding, in the context of the book, refers to postpartum hemorrhaging. However, this euphemistic language can be more literally interpreted to reference natural disasters or rising sea levels. Blinking lights aimed at shadowy vignettes of accumulated detritus in the installation signal tenderly to the viewer a warning, a lament.

","About the Installation

Bonnie Crawford Kotula’s studio practice is part science experiment, part meditation, and part mischief. Employing both cerebral and sensual faculties, she makes sculptures and installations that combine tiny LED lighting with simple materials like brightly colored trash and cheap craft supplies. or if there be flooding serves as an imagined response plan to a potential catastrophe. The title of this piece is a fragment from Advice to a Wife and Mother, published in 1878. Flooding, in the context of the book, refers to postpartum hemorrhaging. However, this euphemistic language can be more literally interpreted to reference natural disasters or rising sea levels. Blinking lights aimed at shadowy vignettes of accumulated detritus in the installation signal tenderly to the viewer a warning, a lament.
About the Prints
The patterns designed for these prints comprise flat colors and shapes with macro imagery from the artist's skin, including hair and moles.
Each print will be printed on Photo Tex, a repositionable adhesive fabric.
The printing will be executed by artist-run Color Wheel Digital, so any money raised will stay within the Baltimore arts community.

Every funder will receive a small print on the Photo Tex material of an image of one of the artist's moles. There are up to five different images of moles, so you may receive more than one, depending on your level of contribution.
Contribute today and enjoy an intimate experience with a small part of my monstrous maternal body.

I fell in love with an artist from New York. We’ve been collaborating artistically ever since. Though we’re only able to see each other months at a time, our relationship has grown into one of my most meaningful friendships. Although we grew up in very different places culturally, artistically and aesthetically we are travelers on the same journey. The greatest challenge we have encountered is traveling across borders. While she can travel to Porto, the economic differences between our countries do not afford me the same opportunity.

Since leaving high school, I have been working as a tattoo designer and artist at a historic Barbearia in Porto’s City Center. I am completely self-taught want to research and broaden my craft to reflect my growth as a multinational artist. I have been directly inspired by the life and aesthetics of New York’s culture and hope to create a unique brand and style to share with the world. I also seek to be a cultural ambassador for my city.

Porto has seen a surge in tourism and as a result our city is changing rapidly. I want to preserve what is unique and beautiful about my city and my culture. Through my art I would like to share the magic that courses through the cobblestone streets of Porto, from the joyous celebrations of Sao Joao festival to the nostalgic romance of Fado music.

We have a rich history and lineage of story telling through our tile-work, music, architecture and decorative arts. I seek to carry on this tradition and I am proud of my heritage as a Portuguese artist. I feel a responsibility to uphold these cultural practices while also expanding and evolving what it means to be a Portuguese artist.

Please donate how ever much you can to help me in my journey across the Atlantic (no amount is too large or too small)! If you choose to donate, you will already be a part of my art, my journey, and my dream. Ultimately, I just want to share love, and I believe that we are all connected.


BUDGET: ($800)

- Train ticket Porto to Lisbon and back ($30 each: $60 total)
- Plane ticket Lisbon to New York in October (approx. $700)
- Travel expenses (transportation/food) $40


","I fell in love with an artist from New York. We’ve been collaborating artistically ever since. Though we’re only able to see each other months at a time, our relationship has grown into one of my most meaningful friendships. Although we grew up in very different places culturally, artistically and aesthetically we are travelers on the same journey. The greatest challenge we have encountered is traveling across borders. While she can travel to Porto, the economic differences between our countries do not afford me the same opportunity.

Since leaving high school, I have been working as a tattoo designer and artist at a historic Barbearia in Porto’s City Center. I am completely self-taught want to research and broaden my craft to reflect my growth as a multinational artist. I have been directly inspired by the life and aesthetics of New York’s culture and hope to create a unique brand and style to share with the world. I also seek to be a cultural ambassador for my city.

I seek to carry on this tradition and I am proud of my heritage as a Portuguese artist. I feel a responsibility to uphold these cultural practices while also expanding and evolving what it means to be a Portuguese artist.

Please donate how ever much you can to help me in my journey across the Atlantic (no amount is too large or too small)! If you choose to donate, you will already be a part of my art, my journey, and my dream. Ultimately, I just want to share love, and I believe that we are all connected. Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

• Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

column1:
• Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

• Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

column1:
• Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

• Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

     Chalk About AC was a grass-roots effort that took place in the City of Atlantic City on October 17, 2015.   Teams

column1: of over 100 volunteers created chalk drawings in every ward of the city to show that Atlantic City is a great place to live, work, and play! Chalkers created over 150

drawings near historical markers, in front of churches and firehouses, on the Boardwalk - wherever they were inspired.  Teams continue to tell stories of walking through the city and talking and sharing chalk with residents and visitors - it was a wonderful day!

You can see many of the drawings and chalkers online on facebook - https://www.facebook.com/AtlanticCityArtsFoundation?ref=hl - or on instagram at #chalkaboutac. Watch the video here - https://youtu.be/44GCu7R-BzU.

In August, the Atlantic City Arts Foundation created ARTeriors: 121 S. Tennessee Ave.  This pop-up exhibition featured installations by four Atlantic City artists and the South Jersey Poets Collective.  This exhibit was free and open to the public.   You can watch our ARTeriors video here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBv_m__g78g
<h4><b>      The mission of the Atlantic City Arts Foundation is to
foster an environment in which diverse arts and cultural programs enrich the
quality of life for residents of and visitors to Atlantic City.  Please support us with your tax-deductible contributions.

Short Summary

Hello, my name is Dalton Bissell and I am an artist in the Pacific Northwest of the USA. I have a great passion for the outdoors, often loving to hike and explore the Cascades. Much of my art is influenced by the incredible examples of nature that humble me with their beauty everyday.

When I am stuck inside working, my spinning tops are a breath of fresh air for me. They are a very welcome distraction from the stresses of life. I want to share the these wonderful little works of art with everyone!

Today I will be sharing The Hive Top with the world in the hope that I can make it a better and more beautiful place for us all to live. To that end, I will be donating a portion of the proceeds to sponsoring live beehives across the world. If the bees disappear, many of the things I love about the great outdoors will vanish with them!

Bees are facing a rapid decline in many areas of the world because of harmful commercial practices like insecticides. Just ""bee-ing"" aware of whats happening to them is half of the battle, so spread the word so we can take care of our little flying friends! After all, the busy pollinators take care of you all the time.
What You Get With Your Contribution
For every top that is sold I am going to donate $5 to sponsoring beehives.

For your contribution you get a steel Hive Top with a 3 mm ruby contact point. The steel is durable while the ruby is incredibly smooth and scratch resistant. This makes for one good-looking top as well.

A successful campaign for me would be $500, which is just a few tops. It's also enough for me to sponsor a single beehive. If this happens, I should actually be saying ""For all of us to sponsor a beehive together"". Maybe lots of them! I am filled with hope and excitement at the possibility.

If my campaign is wildly successful, I will use the funds to buy new tools and equipment for my workshop. This will allow me to make more intricate works of art and to work with exciting new materials. It may be even bring down the cost of manufacturing. I would love to offer several material choices like Brass or Titanium as well.
A successful campaign would make a big difference in the daily struggle to not be the starving artist and help me to create another work of art that I can be proud of.
The Impact

Contributing to this campaign will not only be helping out the bees in a small way, it will be helping a small artist work towards his dreams. Independent and self employed, I am 26 and determined to spend the rest of my life creating art for a living. For the next 75 years, I hope to cause meaningful and beautiful change with my art. I'll be starting with just 1 beehive. Wish me luck!
<h3>Risks &amp

One of the real risks I face is in shipping. There are all sorts of problems that can occur when shipping a small, valuable product like this one. The main concern is making sure that the package arrives and is undamaged on arrival. With tracked shipments I can assure safe arrival, and if the top is damaged in anyway I am prepared to replace the top for you, just send it back and a replacement will be on the way.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help out the campaign but don't have the funds to contribute, that is just fine! Like I said earlier, just knowing about it is half the battle... so spread the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools to share my campaign with your friends on Facebook or Twitter.
Do you want to help the Bees even more? Then check out this extremely informative youtube video called ""Bee Informed"" and be just that. https://youtu.be/9gASaI8F4cs
You never know who might be moved to action by simply noticing there was a problem. I was... were you?

Hi! My name is Pía and art is my passion.
When I create, I feel alive. I draw, paint and photograph - then I exist.

It doesn't matter which medium I use. The creator IS the medium. One just has to let ""it"" out, let it pass through: that feeling, that thought... that perception. When creation flows and the resulting artwork touches somebody else's heart, BOOM! ...  magic happens. This is the most precious reward as an artist.

On January and February 2019 I will be exhibiting a series of photographs called REFLEXIONES. The images found me, not the other way around (as usual). For me, their beauty lies in the fact that you do not always know what is inside and what lies outside the glass, just as we do not always know what lies inside us. ""Who are we, and if yes, how many?""
The funding will go to...
<ul>
• Print the photographs in fine-art quality  (expensive!)
• Frame the photographs (more expensive!)
• Print invitations and advertising material (flyers, posters)
• Cover costs for the vernissage / finissage
• Prepare and print a catalogue
• Every cent counts! No matter if the campaign reaches its goal or not.
• I have prepared some nice perks - to show my appreciation and share my art with you.
Other ways you can help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
<ul>
• Even if you can't contribute financially, you can always spread the word!
• You can also use the Indiegogo share tools for this.

I am working....but am making very little money. If you have a few free dollars and an open heart. Please accept my gratitude for helping me out...
ANY EXCESS DONATIONS WILL BE DONATED TO BOSTONS CHILDRENS HOSPITAL.

In gratitude for them saving Elijah's life.
