The Zine

40 pages, 3 color Risograph printing, A5 size.
print run limited to 150 *
The colours will be MEDIUM BLUE, FLUORO ORANGE, AND GOLD.
* If the amount of support far exceeds what we need to fund this quantity, we will increase the print run to make sure orders are met. Each copy will be signed, stamped, and numbered by us :)
column4:
>

Part of the work by Daniel Wesseik (Israel/The Netherlands)
column6: >Part of the work by Susannah Garden (Australia/Germany)
column8: >Part of the work by Harry Wyld (UK)
column9:
> 

The Participating Artists

We're thrilled to have artists from all over the world participating. The participants are:

column1: <li>
Chloé Bertron (France)
<li>
Boilingman (China)
<li>
Nicolás China (Argentina)
<li>
Sander Ettema (Netherlands)
<li>
Fred Fivaz (Switzerland)
<li>
Susannah Garden (Australia/Germany), curator
<li>
Yuki Kitazumi (Japan)
<li>
Karolina Lubaszko (Poland)
<li>
Anastacia Sholik (Ukraine)
<li>
Borbála Tompa (Hungary), curator
<li>
Daniel Wesseik (Israel/Netherlands), curator
<li>
Harry Wyld (UK)

The Theme

All of the participating artists were given a single theme as a (loose) starting point for their work, which was FORGOTTEN NAMES.

The title “Forgotten Names” is related to a sub-field in magic that is all about knowing the real (true) name of things.

This practice in magic means that everything in the world — from a plant to a seahorse to a human being — has a true name. This true name correlates perfectly with its essence.

The true name of things is referenced in many cultures and religions. It is also commonly mentioned in fairy tales and folktales, in literature, or in occult writings.

 

Printing the Zine

If funded, Forgotten Names will end up being printed in 3 colours on a Risograph printer, on  105g. Metapaper paper stock. We’ve chosen to print with Drucken3000 in Berlin, who produce high quality artistic prints. Risograph results in some stunning colour gradations, textures and always adds a unique feel. The result will be a great-looking 40 page art zine.

 

What is Risography?

Risograph is a retro, high-speed digital printing system from the 1980s that has made a big comeback in recent years. The original risograph printer was manufactured by the Riso Kagaku Corporation. Designed to be a high-volume, fast and low cost photocopier and marketed for schools, churches, prisons and political parties, the risograph has a very unique aesthetic, with beautiful color blending. It sits somewhere between screen printing and offset lithography. Using a stencil-based printing process and real inks means that riso-prints have beautiful bright colours.

 

Timeline

All of the participating artists have completed their work for this project and the zine itself has been laid out and prepped for printing. Therefore, once we achieve our funding goal, the process of printing and shipping will happen fairly fast. The printing and drying of the pages will take about 2 weeks. There will be another 2 weeks for binding and assembly.

So, within 4-6 weeks of achieving our funding goal, all the backers should receive their gifts for funding the project!

 

Why Support This Project?

Many artists, designers and illustrators tend to produce work for clients that is subject to external demands. This project reflects a group of motivated, creatives producing work in a non-commercial capacity that we are sure others will appreciate too.

The purpose of crowd funding for this project is to see the project realised. This is also your chance to support independent publishing!

Please note: None of the participating artists have been paid for their work, nor are we (the curators) receiving any payment for our time. None of the money from backers will go towards anything other than the production of the zine/associated merchandise  — our main aim is not pay for the production costs out of our own pockets. If the amount raised exceeds what we need, the extra funds will go into a print run of higher volume :)

 

Who Are We?

 

Borbála Tompa

I’m a Budapest based animation filmmaker and illustrator. In 2007-2015 I gained my animation BA and MA degree at Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design, Budapest. Since graduating I have been working as a freelance animation director and designer. I have worked on many children’s short films and series, and for clients such as TED-Ed and The School Of Life. I was a participant in the “Animation Sans Frontières” program in 2017-2018.

As well as this, I'm one of the curators of a Hungarian feminist fanzine called ""Zina"", which is also a risograph-printed publication.

 

Daniel Wesseik

On 2015 I relocated from Israel to the Netherlands to pursue a Master in Animation, and I've been based there ever since. I met Bori during a course we took together back on 2017, called ASF, for European and European based animation directors and producers.  In my work I focus on experimental and character based animation and character design. My passion for risograph printing increased significantly after visiting some zine festivals around Europe and am especially influenced by my Tilburg based neighbours - Wobby magazine. Last year I participated in the ""Hydra"" issue by Popper Publishing and I'm currently working on a solo exhibition of  Riso prints that will be launched on November in Porto, Portugal. 

 

Susannah Garden

I’m an Australian freelance illustrator based in Berlin. I have a BA (hons) Illustration degree from the British Higher School of Art and Design (BHSAD), Moscow and a BA (hons) Creative Arts from the University of Melbourne, Australia. I relocated to Berlin in 2018, and I’m currently working on a children’s book, some poster designs, and creating some wall murals, plus I'm one of the organisers of Sunday Sketching Berlin — regular themed drawing workshops held in different locations around the city.

I very much enjoy making hand-drawn, graphic work, and I’m also interested in non-linear as well as traditional narrative in illustration. My passion for risograph printing emerged while I was living in Moscow and in 2018 I made a zine with my collective WES and I also produced riso-posters for the ""Print Addiction"" market.

 

 

On behalf of us and on behalf of our fellow artist-collaborators, we want to thank you for supporting our goal! Let the magic happen!

 

 

","The Zine40 pages, 3 color Risograph printing, A5 size.print run limited to 150 *The colours will be MEDIUM BLUE, FLUORO ORANGE, AND GOLD.* If the amount of support far exceeds what we need to fund this quantity, we will increase the print run to make sure orders are met. Each copy will be signed, stamped, and numbered by us :) Work by Boilingman (China)Part of the work by Daniel Wesseik (Israel/The Netherlands)Part of the work by Susannah Garden (Australia/Germany)Part of the work by Harry Wyld (UK) The Participating ArtistsWe're thrilled to have artists from all over the world participating. The participants are:
Chloé Bertron (France)
Boilingman (China)
Nicolás China (Argentina)
Sander Ettema (Netherlands)
Fred Fivaz (Switzerland)
Susannah Garden (Australia/Germany), curator
Yuki Kitazumi (Japan)
Karolina Lubaszko (Poland)
Anastacia Sholik (Ukraine)
Borbála Tompa (Hungary), curator
Daniel Wesseik (Israel/Netherlands), curator
Harry Wyld (UK)

The ThemeAll of the participating artists were given a single theme as a (loose) starting point for their work, which was FORGOTTEN NAMES.The title “Forgotten Names” is related to a sub-field in magic that is all about knowing the real (true) name of things.This practice in magic means that everything in the world — from a plant to a seahorse to a human being — has a true name. This true name correlates perfectly with its essence.The true name of things is referenced in many cultures and religions. It is also commonly mentioned in fairy tales and folktales, in literature, or in occult writings. Printing the ZineIf funded, Forgotten Names will end up being printed in 3 colours on a Risograph printer, on  105g. Metapaper paper stock. We’ve chosen to print with Drucken3000 in Berlin, who produce high quality artistic prints. Risograph results in some stunning colour gradations, textures and always adds a unique feel. The result will be a great-looking 40 page art zine. What is Risography?Risograph is a retro, high-speed digital printing system from the 1980s that has made a big comeback in recent years. The original risograph printer was manufactured by the Riso Kagaku Corporation. Designed to be a high-volume, fast and low cost photocopier and marketed for schools, churches, prisons and political parties, the risograph has a very unique aesthetic, with beautiful color blending. It sits somewhere between screen printing and offset lithography. Using a stencil-based printing process and real inks means that riso-prints have beautiful bright colours. TimelineAll of the participating artists have completed their work for this project and the zine itself has been laid out and prepped for printing. Therefore, once we achieve our funding goal, the process of printing and shipping will happen fairly fast. The printing and drying of the pages will take about 2 weeks. There will be another 2 weeks for binding and assembly.So, within 4-6 weeks of achieving our funding goal, all the backers should receive their gifts for funding the project! Why Support This Project?Many artists, designers and illustrators tend to produce work for clients that is subject to external demands. This project reflects a group of motivated, creatives producing work in a non-commercial capacity that we are sure others will appreciate too.The purpose of crowd funding for this project is to see the project realised. This is also your chance to support independent publishing!Please note: None of the participating artists have been paid for their work, nor are we (the curators) receiving any payment for our time. None of the money from backers will go towards anything other than the production of the zine/associated merchandise  — our main aim is not pay for the production costs out of our own pockets. If the amount raised exceeds what we need, the extra funds will go into a print run of higher volume :) Who Are We? Borbála TompaI’m a Budapest based animation filmmaker and illustrator. In 2007-2015 I gained my animation BA and MA degree at Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design, Budapest. Since graduating I have been working as a freelance animation director and designer. I have worked on many children’s short films and series, and for clients such as TED-Ed and The School Of Life. I was a participant in the “Animation Sans Frontières” program in 2017-2018.As well as this, I'm one of the curators of a Hungarian feminist fanzine called ""Zina"", which is also a risograph-printed publication. Daniel WesseikOn 2015 I relocated from Israel to the Netherlands to pursue a Master in Animation, and I've been based there ever since. I met Bori during a course we took together back on 2017, called ASF, for European and European based animation directors and producers.  In my work I focus on experimental and character based animation and character design. My passion for risograph printing increased significantly after visiting some zine festivals around Europe and am especially influenced by my Tilburg based neighbours - Wobby magazine. Last year I participated in the ""Hydra"" issue by Popper Publishing and I'm currently working on a solo exhibition of  Riso prints that will be launched on November in Porto, Portugal.  Susannah GardenI’m an Australian freelance illustrator based in Berlin. I have a BA (hons) Illustration degree from the British Higher School of Art and Design (BHSAD), Moscow and a BA (hons) Creative Arts from the University of Melbourne, Australia. I relocated to Berlin in 2018, and I’m currently working on a children’s book, some poster designs, and creating some wall murals, plus I'm one of the organisers of Sunday Sketching Berlin — regular themed drawing workshops held in different locations around the city.I very much enjoy making hand-drawn, graphic work, and I’m also interested in non-linear as well as traditional narrative in illustration. My passion for risograph printing emerged while I was living in Moscow and in 2018 I made a zine with my collective WES and I also produced riso-posters for the ""Print Addiction"" market.  On behalf of us and on behalf of our fellow artist-collaborators, we want to thank you for supporting our goal! What is OuterSpace?
column3:
>OuterSpace is a contemporary art gallery (housed in a customized cube van). A small, personal exhibition space with a reach not accessible by brick and mortar galleries. The flexibility of the gallery allows for pop-up shows and honest immersion within the community. The gallery currently resides on the West Coast of Canada, in the capital city Victoria.

The OuterSpace mobile gallery was built and funded by Ryan Thompson over the course of a year and
column4: > launched in 2013 with two exhibitions.

*Above - (Left) 6 months into the project, engine work and government safety inspections complete, entire truck stripped to the bones and ready to build. Feeling a little in over our head... (Right) After 12 months our first show!

column9:
>

Our second exhibition ""The Many Faces of Koyama Press"" a show highlighting the beautiful art books &
column10: comics published by Annie Koyama. The show featured artwork by Patrick Kyle, Jesse Jacobs, Luke Ramsey, Tin Can Forest, Alex Schubert and Allister Lee.
column11:
>

The development of OuterSpace happened out of necessity due to the lack of outlets for artist books and galleries willing to exhibit unconventional artwork on Vancouver Island. The goal of OuterSpace is to create a unique, efficient space that allows artists to experiment and show art that may not be accepted in a traditional commercial gallery. We are interested in utilizing funds that would traditionally go towards rent to produce art books/zines, prints, murals and other projects which support the artists we collaborate with.
column15:
>We are very excited to announce the first 3 exhibitions lined up for 2014!

April, 2014 - OTHER (Troy Lovegates) - San Francisco
column23: >- Troy Lovegates' book is well on it's way through production. Here's a sneak peak of some of the drawings in the book, the design/production process + the finished die-cut cover. Grab one of these book perks now, there are only a small number being made.

column36:
schema=vimeo"" width=""580"">

An integral part of OuterSpace's mandate is to collaborate with artists to produce books and prints. We will be working with each of these artists to produce an art book for their exhibition. This is where we truly need your help.

We had originally thought of starting a fundraising campaign to build the OuterSpace Gallery in 2012, but decided to put in the work and fund the project out of our own pocket to prove what was possible. With two successful exhibitions under our belt, we are now calling out for help to exhibit the work of these three amazing artists and to produce a book to show their artwork outside of this little gallery in Victoria.

What we are doing, How you can help &
column37:
How we will thank-you for making this happen.

April, 2014
column39: > be having an exhibition of new drawings, lino-prints, paintings and carvings. We will be showing this work and launching a new art book in the OuterSpace gallery. Victoria and Vancouver showings. (Artist in attendance
column42: >Luke Ramsey will be having a book launch for his new Lineage Edition title as well as exhibiting new artwork in the OuterSpace gallery. (Artist in attendance)
column44: >Hiro Kurata will have a book launch for his new Lineage Edition title as well as exhibiting a selection of new experimental paintings in the OuterSpace Gallery.
column46:
>

We are asking for your support to help fund the cost of printing an art book and exhibiting the new work by these artists.
column47:
>

Minimum Goal $4500

Our minimum goal is to raise $4500 which will cover the basic cost to print and bind a handmade edition of books for three artists. That's three books and three artshows! As co-founder of Anteism Publishing Ryan Thompson has years of experience producing art books, access to equipment and high-end, economical printing services. We are able to make unique art books for these artists on a very small budget. 

*UPDATE - We have completed the prototype Troy Lovegates book. The artist designed a pattern which was then cutout of 140lb acid free watercolour paper. The book highlights 40 pages of recent drawings by Troy Lovegates. Secure your copy of this limited edition book with a $35 donation.
column59: >A major aspect of OuterSpace is the outer gallery wall, a dedicated mural space for artists exhibiting in the gallery. We wish to provide a space for artists to paint a legal mural that can be enjoyed by the public. We appreciate the work that goes into a mural and want to provide an artist payment for this work. If we can raise $2000 beyond our minimum goal we will be able to commission these three artists to paint a mural for their exhibition. As a Thank-You for helping us get to our stretch goal we will give everybody who has donated $50 or more a bonus print of one of the finished murals on top of any perks they are already getting. Please help make this happen by spreading the word.
column61:
>

*Above - OuterSpace set up on location with James Kirkpatrick mural.
column64:
>Our minimum goal provides us the ability to produce a book for each artist. There are however many other costs that are incurred through running the gallery such as vehicle maintenance, gallery supplies, promotion, insurance/license, travel costs, framing etc. We hope that we can go beyond our minimum goal to ensure successful exhibitions without the worry of a flat tire. We are in the early stages of developing this gallery space and do not receive any other funding or grants. This is a crucial time, we need your help to get some momentum.

Perks

We are excited to be bringing these artists work into the gallery but also into the form of books and prints. Our goal is to share the artwork of artists we truly admire and believe in. We hope that you can help us make this project happen and in return you will be given unique artwork, a book or t-shirt that you can't get anywhere else. Many of these perks are created just for this fundraising campaign and supporters will be the first to get the books and other perks which may not be available after the exhibition due to the limited number produced.

column2: > want to promote new style called ""Miniature Glass"". A combination of Eastern and Vitrail miniatures.
>Miniature Glass (A combination of Eastern and Vitrail miniatures)

column1: I'm Sarah Garner.I live in Arkansas, USA. One of my favorite arts is miniature paintings which I practice in addition to my daily work. I became interested in the art at school and tried to keep this feeling within myself to improve at a higher level. I chose Graphics as my field at University but I do paintings as well as the graphical work. I’m interested in painting Persian or eastern miniatures in a professional manner.

I think miniatures painted with oil is a unique art in its own style. You can demonstrate in all the lines and colors, the elegance and the beauty. Through this art a painter can show deep emotions and creativity to the outside world and build a relationship.
Actually I am working on my own creativity with a combination of miniature arts and the art of stained glass. A new style and a new art which has its own system and it’s completed.
new style of miniature galss
The name of this style of work is ""Miniature on glass"", a combination of Eastern style with vitrail. (Painting on glass)
My work was liked and supported with great interest among my friends. Those enjoying this new style asked me to improve my work and encouraged me to try more to promote it.
miniature bird painted on an egg. Almost used for traditional ceremonies

column2:

painting decoration on porcelain vase

>

little porcelain dish
So I decided to upgrade my paintings from a hobby to a professional job. Let me underline this important point. Of course it's not just a painting on paper but I also do painting on glass and other common simple objects such as glass, eggs, vases....

column6:
>

Update, April 7: Wow, thanks everybody! We've hit our initial target, thanks to your generosity. We're floored by your support of photography and of Capture. Since we've got three weeks left on the campaign, let's see if we can edge in on our stretch goal: $30,000!

column1: Vancouver + Photography =
<span style=""font-size: 12px

column2: >Jessica Eaton, DG Weave, 2015, Dal Grauer Substation installation mock-up. Capture 2015 public installation.

column6: >Capture Photography Festival is Vancouver’s first citywide photography festival.
column12: >You can expect photography exhibitions, public installations, and events to take over Greater Vancouver every April from now on. Capture is here to promote awareness of Vancouver’s unique history of photoconceptualism, inspire community engagement with photography, and create platforms for showcasing local and international artists.

column7: >As a new festival that is not-for-profit
column12: >, Capture relies on the generosity of public and private supporters, such as yourself, to bring its varied and accessible programming across the lower mainland.

column1: What We're Asking For

This year we bit off a little more than we could chew with respect to programming, and we find ourselves underfunded by $30,000. Rather than cancel anything, we decided to proceed and have faith that we could get support from our community.
column2: >The money raised by this Indiegogo campaign will go directly toward Capture’s 2015 programming.

column1: How Capture Works

Capture acts as an “umbrella” for dozens of galleries, museums, and organizations to come together to celebrate photography and lens-based arts by individually programming exhibitions and events that fall under this mandate.

Alongside the participating galleries, Capture programs its own feature exhibition, public art installations, and events each year—and this is where we need your help. Artists’ fees, curators’ fees, speakers’ fees, venue rentals, printing costs, all the way down to the hiring of a boom lift to install public artworks are just some of the costs Capture incurs.

column2: >Scotty Massey, Spectrum Study 4 (infrared), 2014, 11.5"" x 12.5"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.

column1: The Payoff

column2: >When you donate, Capture gets to bring photography-focused events and exhibitions to Vancouver, and you—who we will just take a guess, loves photography—also get some great photography-based perks in return. Whether its voting membership in the Capture Photography Festival Society
column3: a tote bag that proclaims your love for Capture and for photography
column4: an audience with someone from the photography community
column5: or a limited-edition print from one of our four 2015 Mini Edition artists, our thank-you perks offer some pretty great swag at every donation level.

column3: >Birthe Piontek, Trouts, 2013, 8"" x 10"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.

column1:
The Impact

Vancouver has a lot to take pride in, and its photography scene is most definitely one of those things. The legacy of the ""Vancouver School"" (the likes of Stan Douglas, Ken Lum, Jeff Wall, and Ian Wallace) is just one piece of the city’s contribution to the international art scene. Vancouver’s current art scene has a lot to offer too, and we need to shout it out loud—to Vancouver and to the world. 
That’s why Capture is leading the charge to celebrate Vancouver’s photographic past but also, importantly, its present and its future. We think this is a pretty important goal for Vancouver, its artists, and its art lovers—and we hope you do too.

column3:
>Christos Dikeakos, Winter Banana Apples 1, 2013, 23"" x 30"". Edition 2 of 7. Courtesy of the artist.
Showing at West Vancouver Museum during Capture 2015.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate cash money. Luckily, there are a number of other ways you can help Capture flourish!
<ol>
• SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN! Help spread the word about Capture’s crowdfunding campaign on your social media.
• Come out to this year’s exhibitions, events, and other programming, and show your support for Vancouver’s photography scene.
• Volunteer with Capture, or one of our not-for-profit partner organizations. Just shoot us an email to express your interest! (info@capturephotofest.com)

Capture Photography Festival:
2015 and Beyond
<div>

column3: >Jessica Eaton, DG Weave, 2015, 9.8"" x 14"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.

column1: Capture 2015 has a packed program!

The 2015 Capture feature exhibition, Images That Speak, curated by Christopher Eamon, hinges around a work by renowned video artist and Academy Award–winning director Steve McQueen and features artworks by Susanne Kriemann, Michele Abeles, Arthur Ou, and Stephen Waddell, among many others.

Up-and-coming Canadian photographer and Emily Carr graduate Jessica Eaton has created a site-specific public installation for the BC Hydro Dal Grauer Substation on Burrard Street, and the 2015 Canada Line public art project explores the Vancouver region’s Indigenous history. We’re also hosting a family-friendly Tailgate Party in Mount Pleasant with Other Sights for Artists’ Projects (April 18), and the Cinematheque is screening a double-bill of Michael Snow’s Wavelength and Michelangelo Antonioni’s Blow-Up (April 22 and 24).
… And this is just a very small snapshot of the 100+ exhibitions and events the 2015 festival has to offer.

column2: >Danny Singer, Trossachs, 2005/14, 6.25"" x 23"". Courtesy of the artist and Gallery Jones. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.

column1: What will Capture 2016 look like?

Capture tries to offer something for everyone precisely because photography is for everyone. We hope Capture only grows to include more exhibitions, more events, and more public installations and events. The Capture team has already cooked up some exciting plans for next year’s festival. We’re dreaming big!
We've got plans to reach out to early-career artists in a big way in 2016—stay tuned for opportunities for emerging artists to be featured in a future Capture exhibition.
Supporting artists, curators, and the photography community at large is what we're all about here at Capture. We're all in, and we hope you'll join us.

column8: >Christian Nicolay and Ya-chu Kang, Boom and Bust. Capture 2013 public video installation. Presented by Capture Photography Festival and Vancouver Live! Video Screen Advertising Program. Sponsored in part by Lamar Advertising.

column1: showi","Update, April 7: Wow, thanks everybody! We've hit our initial target, thanks to your generosity. We're floored by your support of photography and of Capture. Since we've got three weeks left on the campaign, let's see if we can edge in on our stretch goal: $30,000!
Vancouver + Photography = A Vibrant City
Jessica Eaton, DG Weave, 2015, Dal Grauer Substation installation mock-up. Capture 2015 public installation.

Capture Photography Festival is Vancouver’s first citywide photography festival. You can expect photography exhibitions, public installations, and events to take over Greater Vancouver every April from now on. Capture is here to promote awareness of Vancouver’s unique history of photoconceptualism, inspire community engagement with photography, and create platforms for showcasing local and international artists.

As a new festival that is not-for-profit, Capture relies on the generosity of public and private supporters, such as yourself, to bring its varied and accessible programming across the lower mainland.
What We're Asking For

This year we bit off a little more than we could chew with respect to programming, and we find ourselves underfunded by $30,000. Rather than cancel anything, we decided to proceed and have faith that we could get support from our community. The money raised by this Indiegogo campaign will go directly toward Capture’s 2015 programming.
How Capture Works

Capture acts as an “umbrella” for dozens of galleries, museums, and organizations to come together to celebrate photography and lens-based arts by individually programming exhibitions and events that fall under this mandate.

Alongside the participating galleries, Capture programs its own feature exhibition, public art installations, and events each year—and this is where we need your help. Artists’ fees, curators’ fees, speakers’ fees, venue rentals, printing costs, all the way down to the hiring of a boom lift to install public artworks are just some of the costs Capture incurs.
Scotty Massey, Spectrum Study 4 (infrared), 2014, 11.5"" x 12.5"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.
The Payoff

When you donate, Capture gets to bring photography-focused events and exhibitions to Vancouver, and you—who we will just take a guess, loves photography—also get some great photography-based perks in return. Whether its voting membership in the Capture Photography Festival Society
column2: a tote bag that proclaims your love for Capture and for photography
column3: an audience with someone from the photography community
column4: or a limited-edition print from one of our four 2015 Mini Edition artists, our thank-you perks offer some pretty great swag at every donation level.

column1: Birthe Piontek, Trouts, 2013, 8"" x 10"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.

The Impact  Vancouver has a lot to take pride in, and its photography scene is most definitely one of those things. The legacy of the ""Vancouver School"" (the likes of Stan Douglas, Ken Lum, Jeff Wall, and Ian Wallace) is just one piece of the city’s contribution to the international art scene. Vancouver’s current art scene has a lot to offer too, and we need to shout it out loud—to Vancouver and to the world. That’s why Capture is leading the charge to celebrate Vancouver’s photographic past but also, importantly, its present and its future. We think this is a pretty important goal for Vancouver, its artists, and its art lovers—and we hope you do too.
Christos Dikeakos, Winter Banana Apples 1, 2013, 23"" x 30"". Edition 2 of 7. Courtesy of the artist. Showing at West Vancouver Museum during Capture 2015.
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate cash money. Luckily, there are a number of other ways you can help Capture flourish!
SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN! Help spread the word about Capture’s crowdfunding campaign on your social media.
Come out to this year’s exhibitions, events, and other programming, and show your support for Vancouver’s photography scene.
Volunteer with Capture, or one of our not-for-profit partner organizations. Just shoot us an email to express your interest! (info@capturephotofest.com)
Capture Photography Festival: 2015 and Beyond
Jessica Eaton, DG Weave, 2015, 9.8"" x 14"". Courtesy of the artist. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.
Capture 2015 has a packed program!

The 2015 Capture feature exhibition, Images That Speak, curated by Christopher Eamon, hinges around a work by renowned video artist and Academy Award–winning director Steve McQueen and features artworks by Susanne Kriemann, Michele Abeles, Arthur Ou, and Stephen Waddell, among many others.

Up-and-coming Canadian photographer and Emily Carr graduate Jessica Eaton has created a site-specific public installation for the BC Hydro Dal Grauer Substation on Burrard Street, and the 2015 Canada Line public art project explores the Vancouver region’s Indigenous history. We’re also hosting a family-friendly Tailgate Party in Mount Pleasant with Other Sights for Artists’ Projects (April 18), and the Cinematheque is screening a double-bill of Michael Snow’s Wavelength and Michelangelo Antonioni’s Blow-Up (April 22 and 24).
… And this is just a very small snapshot of the 100+ exhibitions and events the 2015 festival has to offer.
Danny Singer, Trossachs, 2005/14, 6.25"" x 23"". Courtesy of the artist and Gallery Jones. Capture 2015 Mini Artist Edition.
What will Capture 2016 look like?

Capture tries to offer something for everyone precisely because photography is for everyone. We hope Capture only grows to include more exhibitions, more events, and more public installations and events. The Capture team has already cooked up some exciting plans for next year’s festival. We’re dreaming big!
We've got plans to reach out to early-career artists in a big way in 2016—stay tuned for opportunities for emerging artists to be featured in a future Capture exhibition.
Supporting artists, curators, and the photography community at large is what we're all about here at Capture. We're all in, and we hope you'll join us.

Christian Nicolay and Ya-chu Kang, Boom and Bust. Capture 2013 public video installation. Presented by Capture Photography Festival and Vancouver Live! Video Screen Advertising Program. Sponsored in part by Lamar Advertising.

<span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-size: 16px

FIGMENT is an annual free public art event where all of the art is somehow interactive and the public is invited to bring their own art, play with everything they find at FIGMENT, and enjoy public space in a unique way. In our first year in Boston/Cambridge, we entertained over 5,000 people along the banks of the Charles River with nearly 100 interactive art pieces including dance, sculpture, chalking, live music, DJ music, art cars, art bikes, storytelling, giant bubbles, costumes, and much more!

Founded in 2007 on New York City’s Governors Island with a handful of projects and a few thousand enthusiasts, FIGMENT has grown exponentially into a multi-day, multi-city event that drew over 30,000 participants in NYC and Boston in 2010. With the addition of Jackson, Mississippi in 2011, FIGMENT continues its mission to offer free, inclusive and participatory art to entire communities, removing the barriers of museum and gallery walls and entrance fees and blurring the lines between those who create and those who enjoy art.

This indiegogo campaign will help fund FIGMENT Boston for its 2011 year.  This is our second year in Boston and this year we are excited to have a new home right in the heart of the city on the Rose Kennedy Greenway!  This year, FIGMENT's unique free public art experience will take place on two days, June 4 and 5, along the Greenway parks from Chinatown to Rowes Wharf.
The Impact

FIGMENT is 100% free and volunteer run and accepts NO advertising or corporate sponsors, we rely entirely on donations and foundation support for our modest budget.  This year, we are trying out indiegogo for the first time.  Our indiegogo campaign goal of $5000 is approximately half our operating budget for 2011.  This money goes for the basics: insurance, security, equipment rentals, permit fees, and signage.

Nobody at FIGMENT makes any money, so every dime of your donation (after indiegogo and paypal fees) goes directly to our expenses!  We are also raising money through several great fundraising parties (certain contributions at this site will get you tickets to the first party as a thank-you).  Check our website for more details.

Even if we don't reach our full $5000 goal, your contribution will still help bring FIGMENT to Boston. If we meet our goal, please keep donating!  We can always use any excess for bigger art or roll it into the budget for 2012.
Donations to FIGMENT Boston are tax deductible to the full extent of the law.  FIGMENT Boston is organized under FIGMENT Project, Inc., a New York based 501(c)(3) corporation.
Other Ways You Can Help
These are the most important ways you can help make FIGMENT Boston happen:
#5: Donate!  FIGMENT is largely funded through the generosity of people like you.
#4: Volunteer!  We are a 100% volunteer driven-organization.  Join us!
#3: Tell your friends! Help spread the word about FIGMENT, and follow us on Facebook and Twitter.
#2: Bring your art! Decorate your bike, wear a costume, grab a hula hoop...whatever it is you do, bring it to FIGMENT!  Submit your projects here until April 15.
#1: Come play! The single most important thing you can do is to grab your friends and come join us on the Greenway on June 4 and 5!

My name is Dustin Spagnola. I am a visual artist based out of Asheville, North Carolina. I make large scale public artwork.
I have been invited to be a part of Kolor Kathmandu, a project that aims to create 75 site specific public murals in Nepal.
I believe everyone has a right to art, including the people of Nepal.
With your help I will be able to share my knowledge about creating public art with Nepalese artists, and in turn, together we will create over 75 pieces of public art.
In order to achieve this I need a plane ticket to Kathmandu, Nepal for February of 2013. They cost between $2000-3000.
I have set a goal of $1500 towards my ticket. All money raised will go towards my travel expenses to and from Nepal.
If you contribute to this project you will receive artwork from Kolor Kathmandu.
Even if you cant contribute to this project, please share this with your friends.  The more people who are aware of Kolor Kathmandu, the easier it will be to reach our goal.

by brilliant writers and journalists alongside some of the best short
comics and illustration you can find.
So if you want to see gobsmacking visuals and thought-provoking belly
laughs then we'd love you to help us launch this groundbreaking
publication.
<ul>
• We hand-pick and invite our writers and creators to make sure this will be like nothing produced in the UK before.
<li>Includes articles on wide ranging topics and experiences by some of
the best writers currently being published in major newspapers,
magazines and websites.
• We want to change the way people see the relationship between comics and writing. So even if you aren't much of a comic reader, this mag is the best way to give it a go!
<li>A magazine in the truest sense: a range of
interesting, informative and addictive content which looks stunning. See
just some of the comic contributors so far...
e want Save Our Souls for be something you are proud to own.<ul>

as easy as possible to get your mitts on our thrilling magazine and
every contribution is hugely appreciated. Thank you.

Short Summary

“Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once he grows up.”  -Pablo Picasso
Artists are a dying breed. With all the other  available career paths, kids are losing interest in becoming artists.  Are we willing to live in a concrete world devoid of arts warm caress. NO!

column2: >Embrace 802 Art is a non-profit organization dedicated to bringing more community involved art to burlington while at the same time bringing recognition to younger talented artists.

>By contributing to our project you can help leave an impression on Burlington that will last for years while also jump starting the career of a young underexposed artist.

What We Need &
column3:
What You Get

We need $500 to get this project completed.  All the money will go towards paint supplies and any extra will go to the young artists who painted the mural.

column1: Passionate about this project? If you donate $50 or more to our campaign, then we will include your name on the mural wall.  That way you can show it off to all your friends.

If we don't reach our goal of $500 the money will be split evenly amongst the artists we are working with to help them buy art supplies for future projects.

The Impact

We are currently working with talented young artists Mariah Hill, Dylan Herbert, and Harrison Holmes.  Because this mural is being painted on Pearl Street Beverage it will have a lot of visibility.  By contributing to our campaign you are helping these artists get their art and names out there for the world to see.  You are helping to keep them passionate and moving forward with their careers.
Risks &

Our goal is to have this project completed by the end of April.  Needless to say we are crunched for time.  We believe that because Brian Clark, local muralist, is advising our project we will be able to overcome these time constraints.  The faster we can get to $500 the faster we can make progress on this project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?  That doesn't mean you can't help!

column2: >You can help us out by volunteering.  We need all the painters we can get.  You don't have to be an artist to paint.  Whether your filling in a large empty space with a paint roller or helping layout tarps, volunteering is a helpful way to get involved.  You can also help by sharing our campaign on social media or by word of mouth.
>email us at embrace802art@gmail.com to get involved in other ways!

Short Summary
• We are the Guild of St. George North, a 501c3 educational non-profit organization whose mission is to bring the history of the renaissance to life for the enjoyment and education of the public.

• The Director and Guildmaster of St. George North, Rydell Downward, has for the last many years portrayed Robert Dudley, The Earl of Liecester at various fairs throughout northern California. After many years, his current costume that has served him very well has come to the end of its life.

• Your generous contribution will make it possible for the guild to present to Rydell a new costume as a token of our thanks and appreciation to everything he has done over the years, not just for our guild, but for the reenactment fair community as a whole.
What We Need &

• Our lead costume designer, Jennifer Erlichman (aka Lucrezia Vivaldi), has put together an estimate based on her past experience of $4,000 USD. This estimate goes to the cost of fabrics, trims, buttons, notions, interfacing, interlinings, notions, and all the various and sundry material needs.  This does include  labor cost for the creation of the costume, which is being generously discounted by her!!!
• We are asking for $4,360 to cover the campaign and credit card processing fees.
• If we do not reach our final goal, we will be forced to scale back the project, as well as possibly be forced to ask Rydell to make up the difference out of his own pocket.
The Impact

• The renaissance fair in northern California is an institution like no other. Education is blended with entertainment to bring the history to life before your very eyes.  To create a courtier costume of the highest caliber gives us the unique opportunity to educate and entertain the public on the haute couture of the 16th century.

• While this is our first Indiegogo campaign, this is not our first time working on a project such as this.  Jennifer Erlichman is a consummate professional costumer, who is not only responsible for the creation of several court costumes for herself, but also is responsible for attiring Bob Collier in his role as Thomas Radclyffe, 3rd Earl of Sussex.
Risks &

• The largest hurtle facing us as this moment is simply the sheer cost of the materials needed to properly replicate the costume as presented in the portrait of Lord Leicester.  Some of the fabric is still made by hand on looms that have not changed in design since the 1400's.  We must import silks from Venice, just like the Courtiers of Queen Elizabeth's court.  Gilt braiding will come from England.

• We've been blessed by the generous commitment of several members of the guild and renaissance fair community who have graciously volunteered their skills, dedicated research and effort into producing the costume. Our team has a combined experience well in excess of 50+ of participating in fairs and producing supremely high quality costumes for various courts.
Other Ways You Can Help

• Even if you cannot contribute monetarily to our campaign, there are still quite a few ways you can help.  The biggest way you can help is to volunteer to help in the construction of the costume.  Jennifer estimates anywhere betwen 200-500 person hours of  work will be required in the physical construction, let alone in the time and effort to track down and source the specific components from various international suppliers.

• As important as your generous monetary donation is to the project success, donating your social media network could be even more valuable.  The renaissance fair community is a small, but extremely close-knit and wonderful community.  Using your social media presence to extend our message of love and thanks to Rydel, who has been a pillar of the northern California fair community for many years would be the most joyous gift we could give to a man who gives so selflessly of his time and effort.  Please help us make this project a wonderful success.

Thank you very much for your support!

We are the Guild of St. George North, a 501c3 educational non-profit organization whose mission is to bring the history of the renaissance to life for the enjoyment and education of the public.

The Director and Guildmaster of St. George North, Rydell Downward, has for the last many years portrayed Robert Dudley, The Earl of Liecester at various fairs throughout northern California. After many years, his current costume that has served him very well has come to the end of its life.

Your generous contribution will make it possible for the guild to present to Rydell a new costume as a token of our thanks and appreciation to everything he has done over the years, not just for our guild, but for the reenactment fair community as a whole.

This estimate goes to the cost of fabrics, trims, buttons, notions, interfacing, interlinings, notions, and all the various and sundry material needs.  This does include  labor cost for the creation of the costume, which is being generously discounted by her!!!
We are asking for $4,360 to cover the campaign and credit card processing fees.

Risks & Challenges

The largest hurtle facing us as this moment is simply the sheer cost of the materials needed to properly replicate the costume as presented in the portrait of Lord Leicester.  Some of the fabric is still made by hand on looms that have not changed in design since the 1400's.  We must import silks from Venice, just like the Courtiers of Queen Elizabeth's court.  Gilt braiding will come from England.

We've been blessed by the generous commitment of several members of the guild and renaissance fair community who have graciously volunteered their skills, dedicated research and effort into producing the costume. Our team has a combined experience well in excess of 50+ of participating in fairs and producing supremely high quality costumes for various courts.
Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute monetarily to our campaign, there are still quite a few ways you can help.  The biggest way you can help is to volunteer to help in the construction of the costume.  Jennifer estimates anywhere betwen 200-500 person hours of  work will be required in the physical construction, let alone in the time and effort to track down and source the specific components from various international suppliers.

As important as your generous monetary donation is to the project success, donating your social media network could be even more valuable.  The renaissance fair community is a small, but extremely close-knit and wonderful community.  Using your social media presence to extend our message of love and thanks to Rydel, who has been a pillar of the northern California fair community for many years would be the most joyous gift we could give to a man who gives so selflessly of his time and effort.  Please help us make this project a wonderful success.
Thank you very much for your support!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Sacramento, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/lord-leicester-s-new-suit/pica

Well friends, the Soul Train needs your help again.  The Soul Train and The Caboose suffered a lot of damage last year.  Individually these problems aren't much of a big deal, but when I added them together, it turned into a huge sum that made me consider not bringing it.  Still, I know how much joy it brings people, so I'm asking for help.

Seeing how much joy it brings people year after year makes it all worth the trouble.  Thanks for your help!

column2: >Big Texas trees are storytellers. After our 1300-mile road trip to paint and photograph Texas' largest and most historic live oak trees, we knew we had to share them. Please help us publish our book, Witness Trees of Texas: a tribute through paintings, photographs, and essays to the magnificent trees that have witnessed so much colorful Texas history. This is the experience of being amidst these beautiful trees as seen through the unique, modern style of Jill's Lear's images and the words of Bill Fowler, published in a museum quality, coffee table book.

column1:
What We Need - What You Get:

  • $7,500 is needed to print our 72-page coffee table book. (The creative and design work is done!)
  • Great rewards for your generosity! Check out the limited editions of Jill Lear's work or reserve your copy of the book.
The Impact

Texans are not only great preservers of their history, but of their champion trees, too. Witness Trees of Texas honors and recognizes this natural history while exhibiting a singular artistic vision of their preservation through the collected paintings and photographs of Jill lear. Your contribution helps us create a book that displays these ornate, twisting, huge trees in ways that brings awareness to this wonderful and lesser known aspect of Texas natural history.
$4000--you get the Halfway Oak I,  original mixed media on paper. (22 inches x 30 inches, framed or unframed). and a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.
$1500--you get the Goose Island Attendant B&
column2: W Limited Edition Print (17 inches x 36 inches including 2 inch white border). Framed or unframed. Plus a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.

column1: <div>
$750--you get an original mixed media on paper on birch panel.  Runaway Scrape Oak (8 inches x 8 inches x 2 inches). Plus a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.
$750--you get an original mixed-media on paper on birch panel. Cart War Oak, Goliad, TX. (8 inches x 8 inches x 2 inches)  Plus a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.
$250--you get the Kyle Auction Oak printed on maple panel (Limited Edition of 10 prints (8 inches by 10 inches). Plus a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.
<div>
$350--you get the Rio Frio Landmark Oak printed on metal panel (8 inches x 8 inches x1.25 inches (Limited edition of 10. Ready to hang). Plus a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas.
<div>
$125--you get a signed copy of our book Witness Trees of Texas!!
$75--you get a Live Oak County Charter Oak limited edition print on panel (8 inches x 8 inches x 2 inches) (edition of 10)
$50--you get a groovy luggage tag with Goose Island Oak imprint.
About the Authors

Jill Lear is a painter whose large works on paper have been exhibited in San Francisco, New York, Seattle, Austin, and Sun Valley, and have been acquired by the permanent collection at Wright State University. She trained formally at the New York Studio School and holds degrees from Southern Methodist University and the Chambre Syndicate of Haute Couture in Paris.

Bill Fowler is founder of Silver Creek Writers Residency, Inc., a nonprofit that gives writers time and space to complete their literary projects. He holds an MFA in Creative Writing from Ohio State University.

The Trees
Many of these paintings were exhibited by Gallery Shoal Creek, Austin, Texas in April 2015. Our book collects these paintings and brings awareness to historic trees located in (or near) the following great Texas towns:
Parker Oaks     - Hurst
Halfway Oak     - near Eastland
Heart O' Texas Oak - near Mercury
Matrimonial Oak - San Saba
Austin Treaty Oak - Austin
Kyle Auction Oak - Kyle
Founders Oak   - New Braunfels
Alamo Oak  - San Antonio
Landmark Oak  - Rio Frio
Tombstone Oak  - Uvalde
County Charter Oak  - George West
Baptist Oak - Goliad
Cart War Oak - Goliad
Urrea Oaks - Refugio
Goose Island Oak - Rockport
Hallettsville Hanging Tree - Hallettsville
Columbus Oak - Columbus
Nothing Oak - Columbus
Old Evergreen Tree - Giddings
Century Tree - College Station
Runaway Scrape Oak -  Gonzales County

par l’art rehausse notre estime de soi, notre plaisir et libère l’esprit!
column4: >Il y a plus de 15 ans, j’ai débuté par peindre à l’aquarelle de manière autodidacte. Plus

column1: tard, j’ai appris la fabrication des vitraux et suivi une formation pour la
production de mosaïques artistiques. Depuis plus de 5 ans maintenant, je peins
à l’acrylique et utilise toutes sortes de techniques bien particulières à moi.
column4: >Pour la petite histoire, je suis fibromyalgique, ce qui fait que je ne travaille pas depuis plus de 5 ans. J’habite un petit appartement avec mes deux filles toujours aux études. Vous comprendrez que l’on se sent coincées parmi toutes les peintures, soit sur les murs, soit appuyées au mur. J’aimerais beaucoup pouvoir me trouver un atelier et ainsi retrouver un peu d’espace de vie de famille. La proximité de toutes mes toiles nuit aussi à mon inspiration et à ma créativité.

column1: Viser un marché  plus grand, entrer dans les galeries, être de
plus en plus professionnelle dans mes expositions

agent

techniques
Un automne bien chargé, à voyager d’un
événement à l’autre, amène des frais de déplacements et d’organisation considérables.
Mon but serait de conserver la cadence actuelle et de développer un marché à l’extérieur
de l’Estrie

Tournage de petits clips sur différentes techniques

événements publicitaire, cartes blanches, toute papeterie

qualité) et matériel associé

toile, pinceaux, crayons aquarelles, médiums mixtes, vernis, quincaillerie,
divers objets de la vie courante)
Matériel de communication, informatique,
photographique et téléphonique

atelier
Possibilité d'échanges entre artistes à l'international
Possibilité d’aller étudier auprès de
mentors
Possibilité de résidence d’artiste

Ma démarche et mon parcours

Je suis une artiste peintre authentique,
sympathique et unique. Je suis une femme passionnée qui aime explorer
diverses formes de créativité artistique. Autodidacte en peinture depuis plus
de 15 ans, j’ai fait mes débuts avec l’aquarelle. Je développe plus tard une
passion pour l’acrylique et les techniques mixtes qui me permettent de danser
avec la peinture, de mélanger des styles, des textures, des contrastes. Voilà
comment j’ai évolué, grandit et je peux maintenant me permettre de vous offrir mes
créations uniques, inspirées et inspirantes. Une partie de moi.
Ma
façon de peindre est intuitive, émotive, physique et sensorielle. Ce sont les
couleurs, les textures et les contrastes qui me conduisent à en extraire une
idée ou une histoire, une émotion. Que ma peinture vous touche, qu’elle vous
parle et vous donne envie de la regarder encore et d’y renouveler le plaisir.
Peindre est devenue vital pour moi,  afin
de m’exprimer, de me permettre d’explorer, de découvrir, de me sentir vivante.
La profondeur des couleurs, leurs vibrations, leur onctuosité, leur luminosité
et l’infinité de possibilités de création sont mes muses. Je laisse aller mes
pinceaux. Parfois pour me rendre compte que je pourrais mieux faire, mieux
représenter mes idées, mes rêves et ma folie. Et c’est reparti! Souvent les
idées me viennent au fur et à mesure, comme si c’était la toile elle-même qui
guidait mes pinceaux.
J’aime peindre avec des pinceaux, bien sûr, aussi avec des spatules,
brosses à plancher, laines d’acier, essuie-tout, cure-dent et très souvent avec
mes doigts. Oui, mes doigts, mes mains. Ce sont des outils faciles à manier,

intimes, au résultat unique, chaleureux et heureusement lavables.

Pour vous parlez de ma démarche
artistique je ferai référence à deux souvenirs d’enfance enfouis quelque part
et pourtant si instinctifs et si authentiques. Le premier vient d’une époque
pas si lointaine où l’on prenait encore le temps de se coucher sur l’herbe
épaisse et riche de l’été ou encore tranquillement allongé dans un hamac
les tas de feuilles de l’automne
column2: s’étendant l’hiver pour imprégner la marque

column1: d’un ange. On lève immédiatement les yeux au ciel et on admire le passage des
nuages. Notre imagination innocente nous amenait à voir toutes sortes de formes
des plus douces aux plus menaçantes. Des visages, des éléphants, des lapins,
des rêves de toutes les couleurs selon l’heure et la saison.
La deuxième inspiration me vient d’un
jeu tout simple qui consiste à faire un gribouillis quelconque sur une feuille
puis l’autre joueur doit en tirer un dessin reconnaissable. Vous souvenez-vous
de toutes les idées farfelues qui en découlait et parfois même quelques
résultats surprenants. Le tout était enivré par les rires, la complicité, la
légèreté de l’âme.
Voilà deux de mes principales démarches
créatives mais la texture et la richesse des couleurs me font aussi réagir, mes
sens sont inspirés par la peinture. La vue évidemment, le toucher car je peins
souvent avec mes doigts, mes mains. Les odeurs de peinture oui mais aussi les
odeurs qui flottent autour de moi, surtout lorsque je peins dehors dans un parc
ou au bord d’un lac. L’ouïe puisque ma façon de bouger au rythme de la musique
et de m’inspirer de l’émotion me font voir un éventail de possibilités. Le goût
un peu moins je l’avoue sauf lorsque je me permets de boire un bon café bien
corsé pour m’accompagner devant le chevalet.
J’ai également été élevé dans l’amour
de la beauté, l’amour du frisson qui donne envie d’harmoniser son environnement
par la décoration de son nid. Ayant été initiée toute jeune à la photographie
de manière artistique, pour immortaliser certaines situations de mon
environnement, des voyages ou des personnes qui me sont chères, j’ai acquis un
regard sûr pour l’équilibre du cadrage d’un cliché.
Sans pouvoir intellectualiser ma
démarche, sans vouloir d’ailleurs l’intellectualiser mais plutôt la laisser se
développer au rythme de mes émotions, je vous présente mon travail. Le fruit de
l’instinct, de l’amour et de la liberté plutôt que celui de la réflexion intellectuelle.
Je n’ai aucune prétention en regard de mes œuvres sinon celle d’espérer vous
faire vivre des sentiments variés, forts et authentiques. Voilà ce que j’ai à

offrir : Moi

","S’exprimer
par l’art rehausse notre estime de soi, notre plaisir et libère l’esprit!Il y a plus de 15 ans, j’ai débuté par peindre à l’aquarelle de manière autodidacte. Plus
tard, j’ai appris la fabrication des vitraux et suivi une formation pour la
production de mosaïques artistiques. Depuis plus de 5 ans maintenant, je peins

à l’acrylique et utilise toutes sortes de techniques bien particulières à moi.Pour la petite histoire, je suis fibromyalgique, ce qui fait que je ne travaille pas depuis plus de 5 ans. J’habite un petit appartement avec mes deux filles toujours aux études. Vous comprendrez que l’on se sent coincées parmi toutes les peintures, soit sur les murs, soit appuyées au mur. J’aimerais beaucoup pouvoir me trouver un atelier et ainsi retrouver un peu d’espace de vie de famille. La proximité de toutes mes toiles nuit aussi à mon inspiration et à ma créativité.Je suis rendue à la croisée des chemins et je me dois d'investir pour le futur, pour avoir la vie à laquelle j'aspire en tant qu'artiste et en tant que femme.C'est ce qui me fait grandir, m'épanouir, me dépasser et me fait plaisir tout simplement!Votre précieuse aide servira à :
Viser un marché  plus grand, entrer dans les galeries, être de
plus en plus professionnelle dans mes expositions

What is Black Mountain College?

Black Mountain College was an innovative educational haven for the mid-20th century. Tucked away in the mountains of Western North Carolina, the school used Art as a centerpiece for their liberal arts curriculum, with a foundation inspired by educational reformist John Dewey. The school has remained relatively unknown, but celebrated names in Art such as Willem DeKooning, Buckminster Fuller, and John Cage all have called it home.
What is {Re}Happening?

In honor of the progressive minds who taught and studied there, Asheville’s Black Mountain College Museum and Arts Center, along with Asheville’s Media Arts Project, curates an annual art event, {Re}Happening. Born in 2009 and steadily growing in recognition, the show consists of artists who are pushing the limits of installation, performance, sculpture, and interactive art. As an artist working in photography, installation, and performance, I created a proposal, along with a team, that was accepted for the April 2014 event.
What is our project?

We are building a camera obscura – the ancient predecessor of the modern camera. The camera obscura is simply a room with a small hole in one wall, which naturally projects an image of whatever exists by outside the room onto the opposite wall. The resulting image is reversed both laterally and top-to-bottom. Our camera obscura will be large enough to fit four viewers and a musician inside, who will witness a dramatic performance of actors from our team outside the room , narrated with a musical soundtrack.
Why do we do this?

We are proud to embody Black Mountain College’s spirit of cross-disciplinary art experiments by merging music, performance art, and camera-based visuals in our project. We are also combining old and new technologies, from the camera obscura’s beginnings which date back to Aristotle, to its common use during Renaissance times as a viewing room, to our modern adaptation of creating a performance that is shaped by its optics. The viewers will be given instructions that allow them to choose either moods or dialogue that lead the performers through the performance art aspect of the project, creating an art experience that is participatory for the viewer rather than passive.
My team consists of dedicated artists, but we need to fundraise for ensured success with this project.
Who are we?
<li>Jason Clements -- Working artist, Co-Director of
The Asheville Darkroom
• Bridget Conn -- Co-Director of The Asheville Darkroom, Professor of Photography, Blue Ridge Community College
• Samantha Stewart -- Stage Manager Toy Boat Community Theatre, Theatre Department of Warren Wilson College Work Supervisor
• Alison Tippins -- Stage Manager, Roving Theatre Geek
• Eric Velleca -- Blacksmith and owner of Velleca Metal Design Inc.
How Are We Using The Money?
The money would be budgeted and distributed to cover the cost of the many materials needed for this project, including:
<ul>
• Metal beams, drapery, and roofing material to create a simulated, enclosed stage for the actors
• Lighting equipment for the nighttime event
• Generator rental for the power of lights needed
• Costume creation and makeup
<li> Materials to create aspects of camera obscura such as the plane for the aperture,
focal plane, additional slide projector for performance, etc.
• Seating for the viewers
• Props for the performance
• Unforeseen necessities to complete the project

The Arc of Luzerne County (The Arc) is a not-for profit 501c3
with the mission to improve the quality of life for people with intellectual
and developmental disabilities (I/DD). We believe all people are equal and
deserve to be treated with dignity and respect, including people who have I/DD.
We believe people with I/DD have the right to participate in the community of
their choice alongside their peers.  We believe people with I/DD want to
live fulfilling lives, and participate as active, contributing members of the

society. 


The Arc needs
to raise $5000 to publish a book of artwork created by people with disabilities. Art is a universal language and in
many ways, offers everyone the opportunity to witness genuine acceptance.
Art is viewed and valued by others in a way that does not discriminate. The
beautiful collection of artwork contained inside this book was created by
people with disabilities of all ages. It is their voice. It is the visual image
of their hopes and dreams for the future. This book is about more than just
showcasing great artwork. It is an opportunity for people with disabilities to
share the vision of the future they dream of with future generations through
creative expression.
distribute the book to public libraries so that future generations will see the
vision created by these talented artists in the hope that one day all people

will be included in their communities. 

Help us spread the word. Share our page with your friends. The future is ours to create.

It Began March 24th, 2014

Jacqueline Goehner's car was broken into while visiting a friend in Oakland, CA. Inside the trunk of her car was a black duffle bag that contained two completed costumes worth almost $4,000. It was stolen from the trunk of her car and though she was able to recover a few pieces of the costume thanks to a kind homeless man named Kalifornia, the remaining pieces are still missing.

This crowd funding is to cover the material cost of the stolen pieces of the ""Link"" and ""Zelda"" costumes. Though tools, supplies, and personal items were also stolen, she has made it her top priority to finishing these costumes
column2:
funding will go towards real leather, rings for chainmail, silk, boot-making supplies, resin, silicone, notions, buckles, and anything that will help finish these two costumes.

Jacqueline is a dedicated costume designer, artist, cosplayer and a wonderful person with a huge heart. She is always willing and ready to help anyone, and has always been there when needed. As part of her request, we have set up reward levels for anyone who wants an extra incentive for their generosity. Any donation, big or small, is tremendously appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can donate or not, sharing this funding page will help! So signal boost this page as often as you can with as many people you know! Thank you!

STRETCH GOAL!!!

We are very pleased to announce that we have made our goal in funding the materials to remake the stolen pieces! Now, our stretch goal is $2,200 to help cover the stolen tools, materials, Jacqueline's prescription contact lenses and glasses, as well as the damages to her car windows. If we make our stretch goal, every contributor will receive a signed 8""x10"" print of Jacqueline in her Witchblade cosplay!

Any bit of help is extremely appreciated!

Imagine an animated series that keeps you laughing throughout an entire show, while tackling serious issues that the average person encounters on a daily basis. Well that show is here in, “My Crew is a Zoo.” Better Days Movements presents: “My Crew is a Zoo,” an animated series featuring a gaggle of dimwitted, sophomoric teen animals, that take you on a comedic rollercoaster with their daily activities.

Set in an undisclosed city in America, “My Crew is a Zoo” will feature more than 22 uninhibited, loose cannons that take on political figures, pop culture and typical teenage angst. Each episode throws these characters into a mix of compromising situations streaked with hysterical banter and outrageous adventures. Yet, there is a final undertone of each episode that teaches a positive lesson.

In 2014, “My Crew is a Zoo” debuted its first two episodes on You Tube, where they have accumulated 1,500 views respectfully. However, due to both of the episodes being financed out of my own pocket, the audio and visual artistry were limited. I did all of the writing
column2:
every voice (except one) sang the introduction and even some of the sound effects (WITH MY OWN MOUTH). But, with your generous donations I will be able to fully animate the cartoon (USING 2D ANIMATION), hire other voice actors, and also hire singers to create original songs for the cartoon. Animation is very expensive, and I want to make sure any musician or animator who works on the cartoon is fairly compensated. I’ve already written 15 episodes, with topics ranging from obesity and dieting, gangs, loving oneself, positive and negative stereotypes and more.

I feel it would be an injustice to myself not to get these episodes out to the masses. I humbly ask that you help bring my vision to fruition!! I truly believe with your generous donations, “MY CREW IS A ZOO” will exceed its potential and be a huge success. Thank you in advance and Better days.

British artist Kashif
Nadim Chaudry collaborated with Los Angeles based artist Patssi Valdez during
her 2013 month long residency at the Nottingham Contemporary for the
exhibition, “Asco – No Movies”.
Known for his highly
structural fiber pieces, the pairing was a perfect compliment.<span>  While in Nottingham for the exhibit, Patssi
conducted workshops creating Paper Fashions.
She and Nadim created the new Paper Fashions idiom for the 21<sup>st</sup>
Century.
This campaign will bring
this important and highly noted British artist, Kashif Nadim Chaudry to Los
Angeles to conduct a workshop to showcase two of his favorite techniques, smocking and shibori, both of which will turn a flat piece of fabric into a
rich, 3D structured surface.
Smocking is an ancient
technique involving gathering and pleating of fabric and was developed in
England during the middle ages.<span>  It was
used as a means of providing elasticity for fabric and also for creating
insulation.  There are a variety of
different smocking techniques which are both within the fashion industry and
the world of interior design.
Shibori
is a Japanese technique that is equally as ancient as smocking with some of the
earliest examples dating from the 8<sup>th</sup> Century.<span>  The technique was used originally as a form
of resist dyeing and involves pleating, folding, stitching and binding of
various fabrics in a multitude of different ways to create surface
patterns.  The development of synthetic
fabrics, however, has enabled some of these shibori techniques to be used as a
means of permanently shaping fabric in a variety of exciting patterns.
Chaudry states:  “There are two parts to my working practice
which hold equal weight and have been consistent throughout
materiality.
Coming from a family
heritage in tailoring has instilled a sense of craftsmanship and I have come to
value the many processes of making, especially repetitive and labor intensive
work.  There is something in the stillness of these ways of working which
allows me to think about the world and my place in it.
Growing up with a tailor
also meant growing up with scraps of fabric and lots of them.  This is
where my love for materials and especially texture, comes from.  I believe
that all matter can conceivably be considered a material and therefore belongs
in an artist’s toolbox.”
To view more of Nadim’s works
visit his website

Short Summary

Hi there, I am Marcy. I am an aspiring artist looking to do a bit of upgrading. My current equipment is not cutting it anymore. And with a cross country move, along with the broken items due to said move, fresh on my shoulders, I am calling out to those who can spare a moment to help.

The wily tablet, a real piece of equipment, I hope you all will help me capture will help lighten what workload I have and push me further to what I have always wanted to be, a real professional artist. Working digitally as well as cleanly is essential and sadly with the lack of funds, slow work and now ruined equipment lumbering around what little nickels and dimes I have, I am finding it difficult to work towards my potential. You can find my current works at the bottom of this page in the links and the link of my name.

To step up the game I humbly and happily ask and in turn thank, for again, even a moment of spare time. Pass this on if you don't mind as well, the more the merrier. All and any help is more than appreciated! I just wish to do the best I can, won't you help me do so?

What We Need

I need $700 to fund the tablet that I want and cover the fees/shipping. Meanwhile if we do not reach our goal together then I will stuff it in a piggy bank and continue working towards this goal.
Goodies for You!
On the other hand! If we manage to do this together!
<ul>
• A gigantic thank you on my site with names of those kind people.
• Choose 1 print out of a pre-selected batch. (1/3, signed, 8.5"" x 11"")
• Commission Sketches. (Digital)

The Impact

This campaign is really something to help me grow to be a better artist. To gain an advantage towards increasing my consistency and professionalism. Which as any type of artist it is all you really have other than your skill. It is said that tools do not make the artist, you use what you have and appreciate it. And I truly do, but it is time to move it to the next level and take that step up. Again thank you all for making a difference in my life.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help, that is more than OK. I know life can be a bit crazy, money isn't always there or maybe this cause hasn't quite caught your interest. This is alright, all I ask is to please share this with others. As I said before, the more the merrier!
Thank you again!

column6:
> is Katrin Inga Jonsdottir Hjordisardottir, I am an Icelandic artist living in New York. I am fundraising for the project ART WE LEARN! 

ART WE LEARN! is my fine art master´s thesis project for School Of Visual Arts. I am very excited about it because it frames a specific theme I have been researching for the past two years of studies. 

The theme is art education from my personal experience and from various articles and theory text written about that issue in the past years. 

The art works will be inspired by my classmates, I have 25 classmates and they are all different artists. I will create artworks influenced by each one of them. In that way my thesis project ART WE LEARN! is a kind of group exhibition done by one artist. 

The ART WE LEARN! project is very much related to my past works where I often work from a site-specific perspective, and find the systems within each site fascinating. I often like to think about how the system works and the way it works.

For your support I have artworks from the series You Are In Control in 7 different sizes and you are welcome to pick more than one if you like, because I think the pieces work very well in a group.

The fundraising is for various art material costs - all of my classmates works are created with all kinds of material and that is a challenging extra cost for my studies. The fine art masters studies in School Of Visual Arts is very expensive and I very much think ART WE LEARN! is important for my art practice development. 

I sincerely think the artwork You Are In Control is well worth for your support. It is beautiful artwork and you won't regret supporting my project either. 

My goal is $2.000 - for varies material and tools to create 26 different pieces inspired from each classmates of mine.  

Anything over my minimum goal is stellar! I will use everything above my goal for printing cost of my thesis paper and school fees. 

My thesis paper is about art education from my point of view and it´s importance in our society! The school fees for spring semester is $18.000 and all support is grateful  and you will have a beautiful art work for your goodness.

I would like to see all of the pieces from the series You Are In Control getting new homes.

column1: Katrin I Jonsdottir Hjordisardottir lives in
Brooklyn and is a 2012/13 Fulbright Grantee. Her subjects often include the social and political landscape and
ecology of the art environment, which she funnels into her practice in unusual
and personal ways, through various methods and mediums, such as writing, performance,
drawing, sculpture making among other forms. She
received the Dungal Art Fund award in 2012 and the Gudmunda Andresdottir

scholarship in 2013.
